(b)  Failure to act. Failure by the board of appeals to hear an appeal and file a decision within the time limit is deemed a denial of the appeal for the purpose of authorizing the institution of an appeal to the state construction code commission. 
(c)  Notice to appealing party. A copy of the decision and statement of reasons therefor shall be delivered or mailed before such filing to the party taking the appeal. 
(Code 1976, § 5-01.06.03(A))  
Sec. 18-74. - Record of decisions. 
A record of decisions made by the construction board of appeals, which shall be properly indexed, shall be kept by the building department and shall be open to public inspection during business hours. 
(Code 1976, § 5-01.06.03(B)) 
State Law reference— Appeal to board, procedure, MCL 125.1514, MSA 5.2949(14).  
Sec. 18-75. - Variances. 
(a)  Authority. After a public hearing, the construction board of appeals may grant a specific variance to a substantive requirement of the code adopted by this article if the literal application of the substantive requirement would result in an exceptional, practical difficulty to the applicant, and if both of the following requirements are satisfied: 
(1)  The performance of the particular item or part of the building or structure with respect to which the variance is granted shall be adequate for its intended use and shall not substantially deviate from performance required by the code of that particular item or part for the health, safety and welfare of the people of the city. 
(2)  The specific condition justifying the variance shall be neither so general nor recurrent in nature as to make an amendment of the code with respect to the condition reasonably practical or desirable. 
(b)  Conditions. The board of appeals may attach in writing any condition in connection with the granting of a variance that, in its judgment, is necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the people of the city in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Minimum variance. In no case shall more than the minimum variance from the code be granted than is necessary to alleviate the exceptional, practical difficulty. 
(2)  Invalidation. The breach of a condition shall automatically invalidate the variance and any permit, license and certificate granted on the basis of it. 
(Code 1976, § 5-01.06.03(C)) 
State Law reference— Specific variance, hearing, grounds and requirements, MCL 125.1515, MSA 5.2949(15).  
Sec. 18-76. - Appeal from board. 
An appeal may be taken from the construction board of appeals as is authorized by section 16 of Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1516, MSA 5.2949(16)). 
(Code 1976, § 5-01.07)  
Secs. 18-77—18-105. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 94. 
State Law reference— Moving buildings or obstructions, MCL 247.188, MSA 9.268. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-396. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building means a structure, either temporary or permanent, having a roof supported by columns or walls, intended for the shelter or enclosure of persons, animals or property of any kind, but does not include tents, awnings or vehicles or mobile homes and factory-constructed housing constructed according to federal and state codes and for transport to a permanent location. 
Building department means the city department of building and its director, inspectors and other employees. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-397. - Purpose. 
Moving of buildings within the city shall be regulated as provided in this article in order to minimize and protect against damage resulting from moving operations, to provide for orderly movement, to lessen the adverse effects of moving operations, to ensure the removal site's restoration, to establish prompt relocation, to ensure compliance with all city ordinances and codes and to promote conformity with other buildings in the area. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.01)  
Sec. 18-398. - Municipal civil infraction. 
The violation of this article shall be a municipal civil infraction, and the director of building and the director's authorized representatives, including, but not by way of limitation, all inspectors and ordinance enforcement officers in the department of building, are authorized to enforce this article and to issue and serve municipal civil infraction citations and municipal civil infraction violation notices. 
(Ord. No. 409, § 3(5-03.08), 3-5-1997)  
Secs. 18-399—18-425. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 18-426. - Required. 
No person shall move any building having a floor area greater than 50 square feet or a height greater than 15 feet into, out of, through, or within the city without first obtaining a moving permit from the building department for each building to be moved. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.03.01)  
Sec. 18-427. - Application. 
(a)  Generally. For each building to be moved, an applicant shall submit a separate written application to the building department before a moving permit may be issued. 
(b)  Content. The application shall provide the building owner's name, the description of the building to be moved, its dimensions, the purpose for the move, the locations from which and to which the building is to be moved, the proposed route and such other information the building department deems necessary. 
(c)  Photographs and construction plans. For buildings to be located in the city, the application must include photographs showing each of the building's four side elevations and must also be accompanied by a full set of construction plans for the building as it is proposed to be completed after moving. 
(d)  Submission deadline. Applications must be submitted at least seven business days before the moving day or earlier, if required by the building department in order to make necessary arrangements. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.03.02)  
Sec. 18-428. - Specific plans. 
The plans accompanying the application for a moving permit shall specifically include provisions for the following: 
(1)  The construction of a permanent foundation conforming to current building code requirements; and 
(2)  Additional site improvements as are necessary in order to comply with all applicable code requirements and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.03.03)  
Sec. 18-429. - Utility clearances and other permits. 
The applicant for a moving permit shall also provide to the building department, before the moving day, the following: 
(1)  Written clearances from the electrical, telephone, gas, cable and water utilities stating that all connections have been properly shut off and, where necessary, all obstructions along the proposed moving route will be cleared without delaying the moving operation; and 
(2)  A copy of the moving permit issued by the county or state, where such a permit is required by the county or state. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.03.04)  
Sec. 18-430. - Fee. 
The fee for a moving permit shall accompany the application for a permit and shall be in the amount as provided in section 54-346. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.03.05)  
Sec. 18-431. - Building permit required. 
For a building that is to be located on a permanent foundation within the city, an application shall be filed, the applicable fee shall be paid and a building permit for the placement and completion of the building shall be obtained at the time of obtaining a moving permit. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.03.06)  
Sec. 18-432. - Conditions for approval. 
The building department shall approve a moving permit only if all the following conditions are satisfied: 
(1)  Size. The building's size is such that it can be moved without endangering persons or property. 
(2)  Structurally safe. The building is structurally safe and fit for moving. 
(3)  Compliance with city codes. If the building is to be located in the city, the building will comply or be made to comply with all applicable city codes and ordinances. 
(4)  Other permits. The permit applicant has obtained all building, electrical, heating, plumbing and other permits required in order to comply with all applicable city codes and ordinances. 
(5)  Compatibility with buildings in area. If the building is to be located in the city and used for residential purposes, the building shall generally conform to and be compatible with the general characteristics of the buildings in the area to which the building will be moved. If the permit is denied pursuant to this subsection, the procedure shall be as follows: 
a.  Public hearing to resolve denial. A denial based on failure to satisfy this condition alone may be appealed to the city council who shall hold a public hearing and whose decision shall be final. 
b.  Notice mailed to adjacent owners and tenants. A written notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be mailed to the owners of all lots or parcels of land lying within 300 feet of the location to which the building is to be moved, and to the occupants of single-family and two-family dwellings within 300 feet. 
c.  Notice sent to addresses on roll. The notice shall be delivered personally or by regular mail addressed to the respective owners and tenants at the addresses given in the last assessment roll. If the name of a tenant is not known, the term "occupant" may be used. 
d.  Deadline. Such notice shall be served or mailed at least 15 days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.03.07)  
Sec. 18-433. - Cash deposits. 
(a)  Payment for damages and inspections. The applicant for a moving permit shall, at the time of the permit's issuance and as a condition thereof, make a cash deposit of $500.00 to guarantee payment for the following: 
(1)  Any damage to public property caused by the moving operations, including any damage to street surfaces, land, trees, bikepaths, streetlights, public buildings or any other damage to public property; and 
(2)  All inspection fees and expenses incurred by the city as a result of the moving operations in accordance with the following: 
a.  The city shall retain the cash deposit for 30 days after the moving operations are completed, during which time it shall be the building department's duty to estimate the amount of damage, if any, to public property resulting from the moving operations and to ascertain whether all materials and debris have been removed from the site from which the building was moved when the removal site is located within the city limits. The building department shall prepare a written report in regard thereto and place the report on file. 
b.  The cash deposit, less inspection fees, less the amount of damage, if any, to public property, and less the city's expense, if any, of removing material and debris shall be returned to the applicant as soon as practicable. 
c.  If damages or removing material and debris expenses exceed the amount of the deposit, the applicant shall pay the city the difference, within ten days after receiving a statement thereof from the building department. 
(b)  Payment to guarantee completion. The applicant for a moving permit shall also make a cash deposit of $2,000.00 to guarantee that the building will be completed according to the plans provided to and approved by the building department, will fully comply with all applicable code and ordinance requirements, and will be fit for occupancy within six months from the date when the moving permit is approved. 
(1)  Cash bonds exempted. Upon filing this cash deposit, the applicant shall not be required to file the cash bonds required in connection with the building permit for the building covered by a moving permit as contained in division 1 of article V of chapter 54. 
(2)  Return of deposit. The city shall return the deposit if, within six months, the building is completed according to the plans and the city has issued a final certificate of occupancy. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.04)  
Secs. 18-434—18-460. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PERFORMANCE STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 18-461. - Inspection of moving operations. 
(a)  Frequency of inspection. During a building moving operation, the building department shall, at least once each day for the length of time the building department deems advisable, inspect the moving operation and take any steps necessary to prevent damage to public or private property or any undue interference with public travel. 
(b)  Payment of costs. The city shall be paid the cost for the use of all city equipment required to be used or present during the moving operation and, in addition, an amount as set forth in section 54-347 per person per hour or fraction thereof for the services of building department personnel and other city representatives, if any, present for inspecting or guiding the moving process. Building department personnel and other city representatives, if any, shall judge the amount of time necessary for proper inspection or guidance during the moving operation. 
(c)  Notice of move. Written notice shall be provided to the building department at least seven days prior to the moving date, and no building shall be moved at a time earlier than that agreed upon by the applicant and the building department. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.05)  
Sec. 18-462. - Moving operation. 
(a)  Approved route. The person issued a moving permit shall move the building through the city only over the route approved by the building department, after consultation with other city departments. 
(b)  Minimal obstructions. The moving operation shall proceed as expeditiously as possible and in a manner to minimize obstruction to traffic. 
(c)  Building left idle on street. The building shall not be left idle on any street at any time except for an unavoidable occurrence making this necessary in the opinion of the building department. 
(d)  Barriers and lights at nighttime. The permittee shall erect a safe barrier around any part of a street occupied by the building during the nighttime and shall maintain sufficient warning lights or flares thereon during the night hours for the protection of the public. 
(e)  Suitable barriers. Suitable barriers are those that conform to the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices adopted pursuant to section 608 of Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.608, MSA 9.2308). 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.06)  
Sec. 18-463. - Restoration of removal site. 
(a)  Plugging of connections. The applicant for a moving permit shall obtain building department and department of public services approval of the plugging of sewer connections before covering the work at any building removal site located in the city. 
(b)  Filling excavations, capping well and debris removal. The applicant shall promptly fill all excavations resulting from the moving of the building, pump and fill any septic tank, cap any well in an approved manner, and remove all materials and debris from the removal site. 
(c)  Burning prohibited. The burning of materials and debris on the premises is prohibited. 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.07)  
Sec. 18-464. - Final certificate of occupancy. 
(a)  Occupancy after completion and issuance. Any building moved for the purpose of being occupied as a residence in the city shall not be occupied during the moving operation nor shall it be occupied until the building has been completed according to plans approved by the building department and a final certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(b)  Final inspection. Before a final certificate of occupancy shall be issued, the building department shall make a final inspection for the purpose of ascertaining whether the building is complete according to the plans on file with the city, whether the building is in full compliance with this Code and city ordinance requirements and whether the building is fit for human occupancy. 
(c)  Failure to obtain. If a final certificate of occupancy is not obtained within six months after the issuance of the moving permit, the cash deposit guaranteeing completion of the building required by subsection 18-433(b) may be declared forfeited to the city, and the city may initiate proceedings pursuant to article V of this chapter to have the building demolished. Any cost in connection with removal of the building and cleanup of the site may be charged against the cash deposit filed pursuant to subsection 18-433(b). 
(Code 1976, § 5-03.08)  
Secs. 18-465—18-489. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46. 
State Law reference— Dangerous buildings, MCL 125.539 et seq., MSA 5.2891(19) et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-490. - Keeping or maintaining prohibited. 
The keeping or maintaining of any building or structure or part thereof which is a dangerous building shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.01)  
Sec. 18-491. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building means a structure, either temporary or permanent, having a roof supported by columns or walls, and intended for shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels, or property of any kind. The term "building" shall specifically include a dwelling as defined and included within the application of Public Act No. 167 of 1917 (MCL 125.401 et seq., MSA 5.2771 et seq.). 
Dangerous building means a building or structure that has one or more of the following defects or is in one or more of the following conditions: 
(1)  A door, aisle, passageway, stairway or other means of exit does not conform to the city fire code. 
(2)  A portion of the building or structure is damaged by fire, wind, flood or other cause so that the structural strength or stability of the structure or building is appreciably less than it was before such catastrophe and does not meet the minimum requirements of this article or the building code for a new building or structure, purpose or location. 
(3)  A part of the building or structure is likely to fall or to become detached or dislodged or to collapse and thereby injure persons or damage property. 
(4)  A portion of the building or structure has settled to such an extent that walls or other structural portions of the building or structure have materially less resistance to winds than is required for new construction by this chapter or the building code. 
(5)  The building or structure or a part of the building or structure, because of dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, or the removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the support or for any other reason, is likely to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or underpinning of the building or structure is likely to fall or give way. 
(6)  The building or structure or a part of the building or structure is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used. 
(7)  The building or structure is damaged by fire, wind or flood or is dilapidated or deteriorated and becomes an attractive nuisance to children who might play in the building or structure to their danger, or the building or structure becomes a harbor for vagrants, criminals or immoral persons or enables persons to resort to the building or structure for committing a nuisance or an unlawful or immoral act. 
(8)  A building or structure used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, including the adjoining grounds, because of dilapidation, decay, damage, faulty construction or arrangement or otherwise, is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation, is in a condition that the health officer determines is likely to cause sickness or disease or is likely to injure the health, safety or general welfare of those people living in the dwelling. 
(9)  A building or structure is vacant, dilapidated and open at the door or window, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or accessible to entrance by trespassers. 
(10)  A building or structure remains unoccupied for a period of 180 consecutive days or longer, and is not listed as being available for sale, lease or rent with a real estate broker licensed under article 25 of the occupational code, Public Act No. 299 of 1980 (MCL 339.2501 et seq., MSA 18.425(2501) et seq.). 
For purposes of this subsection, the term "building or structure" includes but is not limited to a commercial building or structure. This subsection does not apply to either of the following: 
a.  A building or structure as to which the owner or agent does both of the following: 
1.  Notifies the local law enforcement agency that the building or structure will remain unoccupied for a period of 180 consecutive days. The notice shall be given to the local law enforcement agency by the owner or agent not more that 30 days after the building or structure becomes unoccupied. 
2.  Maintains the exterior of the building or structure and adjoining grounds in accordance with this chapter or the city building code. 
b.  A secondary dwelling of the owner that is regularly unoccupied for a period of 180 days or longer each year, if the owner notifies the local law enforcement agency that the dwelling will remain unoccupied for a period of 180 consecutive days or more each year. An owner who has given notice prescribed by this subsection shall notify the law enforcement agency not more than 30 days after the dwelling no longer qualifies for this exception. As used in this subsection, the term "secondary dwelling" means a dwelling such as a vacation home, hunting cabin, or summer home that is occupied by the owner or a member of the owner's family during part of a year. 
Structure means anything constructed or erected and designed for a permanent location on the ground. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Dangerous building defined, MCL 125.539, MSA 5.2891(19).  
Sec. 18-492. - Purpose. 
This article is adopted pursuant to and within the purview of Public Act No. 167 of 1917 (MCL 125.401 et seq., MSA 5.2771 et seq.) to provide for the regulation and demolition of dwellings and to provide a procedure for the regulation and demolition of dwellings within the provisions of Public Act No. 167. This article shall also apply to all other buildings within the city that are dangerous buildings as defined by section 18-491. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.05)  
Sec. 18-493. - Hearing officer. 
For the purposes of this article, a hearing officer shall be appointed by the mayor to serve at the mayor's pleasure. The hearing officer shall be a person who has expertise in housing matters, including but not limited to an engineer, an architect, a building contractor, a building inspector or a member of a community housing organization. An employee of the building department shall not be appointed as hearing officer. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.02(A)) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.540(4), MSA 5.2891(20), (4).  
Sec. 18-494. - Municipal civil infraction. 
It shall be a municipal civil infraction for any owner, agent, or lessee thereof to keep or maintain any dwelling, building, or structure or part thereof that is a dangerous building as defined in section 18-491. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.03; Ord. No. 409, § 6, 3-5-1997)  
Sec. 18-495. - Notice. 
(a)  Authority. Notwithstanding any other section of this article, if a building or structure is found to be a dangerous building, the building department shall issue a notice that the building or structure is a dangerous building. 
(b)  Persons served. The notice shall be served on the owner of or party in interest in the building or structure in whose name the property appears on the last local tax assessment records. 
(c)  Contents. The notice shall specify the time and place of a hearing on whether the building or structure is a dangerous building. The person to whom the notice is directed shall have the opportunity to show cause at the hearing why the hearing officer should not order the building or structure to be demolished, otherwise made safe, or properly maintained. 
(d)  Manner of service. The notice shall be in writing and shall be served at least ten days before the date of the hearing in the notice as follows: 
(1)  Upon the person to whom the notice is directed personally; or 
(2)  By certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner or party in interest at the address shown on the tax records; 
(3)  If a notice is served on a person by certified mail, a copy of the notice shall also be posted upon a conspicuous part of the building or structure; 
(4)  Additional distribution shall be as follows: 
a.  The building department shall file a copy of the notice that the building or structure is a dangerous building with the hearing officer. 
b.  In addition, the building department may file a notice with the county register of deeds to advise of the proceedings pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.01) 
State Law reference— Notice requirements, MCL 125.540, MSA 5.2891(20).  
Sec. 18-496. - Hearing before officer. 
(a)  Hearing officer. The hearing officer shall be appointed by the mayor to serve at the mayor's pleasure. 
(b)  Testimony. The hearing officer shall take testimony of the enforcing agency, the owner of the property and any interested party. 
(c)  Determination. The hearing officer shall render his decision either closing the proceedings or ordering the building or structure to be demolished or otherwise made safe. 
(d)  Historic districts. The hearing officer's decision and order concerning demolition of a structure located within a historic district established pursuant to chapter 118 shall be subject to the procedural requirements of section 118-169 of this Code. 
(e)  Compliance deadline. If it is determined by the hearing officer that the building or structure should be demolished or otherwise made safe, the hearing officer shall so order, fixing a time in the order for the owner, agent or lessee to comply therewith. 
(f)  Noncompliance with order. 
(1)  If the owner, agent or lessee fails to appear or neglects or refuses to comply with the order, the hearing officer shall: 
a.  File a report of his findings and a copy of his order with the city council; and 
b.  Request that the necessary action be taken to demolish or otherwise make safe the building or structure. 
(2)  A copy of the findings and order of the hearing officer shall be served on the owner, agent, or lessee in the manner prescribed in section 18-495(d)(1)—(3). 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.02; Ord. No. 441, § 1(5-07.04.02), 7-21-1999) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.541(1)—(3), MSA 5.2891(21), (1)—(3).  
Sec. 18-497. - City council review. 
(a)  Notice of review hearing. The city council shall fix a date, not less than 30 days after the hearing prescribed in section 18-496, for a hearing on the findings and order of the hearing officer and shall give notice to the owner, agent, or lessee in the manner prescribed in section 18-495 of the time and place of the hearing. 
(b)  Show cause. At the hearing, the owner, agent or lessee shall be given the opportunity to show cause why the order should not be enforced. 
(c)  Final determination. The city council shall either approve, disapprove or modify the order. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.03) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.541(4), MSA 5.2891(21), (4).  
Sec. 18-498. - Judicial review. 
An owner aggrieved by any final decision or order of the city council under section 18-497 may appeal the decision or order to the circuit court by filing a petition for an order of superintending control within 20 days from the date of the decision. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.04) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.542, MSA 5.2891(22).  
Sec. 18-499. - Compliance deadline. 
If the city council approves or modifies the order issued under this article, the city council shall take all necessary action to enforce the order. If the order is approved or modified, the owner, agent, or lessee shall comply with the order within 60 days after the date of the hearing under this article. For an order of demolition, if the city council determines that the building or structure has been substantially destroyed by fire, wind, flood, or other natural disaster and the cost of repair of the building or structure will be greater than the state-equalized value of the building or structure, the owner, agent or lessee shall comply with the order of demolition within 21 days after the date of the hearing under section 18-497. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.05) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.541(4), MSA 5.2891(21), (4).  
Sec. 18-500. - Corrective action by city. 
After the order issued pursuant to this article, the city may, through its agents, employees or contractors, demolish or make the building or structure safe. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.06)  
Sec. 18-501. - Compliance cost reimbursement. 
The cost of the demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure incurred by the city, to bring the property into conformance with this article, plus an administrative fee of $300.00, shall be reimbursed to the city by the owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.07) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.541(5), MSA 5.2891(21), (5).  
Sec. 18-502. - Notification of compliance costs; failure to reimburse; lien. 
Under this article, the owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears upon the last local tax assessment records shall be notified by the assessor of the amount of the cost of the demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure by first class mail at the address shown on the records. If the owner or party in interest fails to pay the cost within 30 days after mailing by the assessor of the notice of the amount of the cost, the city shall have a lien for the cost incurred by the city to bring the property into conformance with this article. The lien shall not take effect until notice of the lien has been filed or recorded as provided by law. A lien provided for in this section does not have priority over previously filed or recorded liens and encumbrances. The lien for the cost shall be collected and treated in the same manner as provided for property tax liens under the general property tax act, Public Act No. 206 of 1893 (MCL 211.1 et seq., MSA 7.1 et seq.). 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.07) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.541(6), MSA 5.2891(21), (6).  
Sec. 18-503. - Action against owner; lien on property. 
In addition to other remedies under this article, the city may bring an action against the owner of the building or structure for the full cost of the demolition, of making the building safe, or of maintaining the exterior of the building or structure or grounds adjoining the building or structure. The city shall have a lien on the property for the amount of a judgment obtained pursuant to this section. The lien provided for in this section shall not take effect until notice of the lien is filed or recorded as provided by law. The lien does not have priority over prior filed or recorded liens and encumbrances. 
(Code 1976, § 5-07.04.07) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 125.541(7), MSA 5.2891(21), (7).  
Secs. 18-504—18-530. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - RESERVED[6]

ARTICLE VII. - STREET ADDRESSES[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 94. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-565. - Purpose. 
There is hereby established a uniform system for numbering principal buildings and structures fronting on all public and private streets in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.01)  
Sec. 18-566. - Record. 
For the purpose of facilitating correct street addresses, a chart, book or other record of all public and private streets within the city, showing the assigned street address number for all buildings and structures fronting upon all public or private streets, shall be kept on file in the building department. This record shall be available for public inspection during regular business hours. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.07)  
Sec. 18-567. - Noncompliance. 
(a)  Notification. If an owner, lessee or occupant of any building or structure fails, refuses or neglects to comply with any section of this article, the building department and/or other department or enforcement officer designated by the city council to enforce this article shall serve written notification on such person, either personally or by mail, advising such person of the applicable section of this article, the manner of noncompliance, the time to remedy the noncompliance, and the penalty for violating this article. 
(b)  Failure to comply. The failure to remedy the noncompliance within ten days following service of such written notice shall constitute a violation of this article, which shall be punishable as a municipal civil infraction by a civil fine as set forth in section 66-37. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.08; Ord. No. 414, § 2(4-11.08), 4-23-1997)  
Secs. 18-568—18-595. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ASSIGNMENT 
 
Sec. 18-596. - Base lines. 
(a)  Primary streets. The base lines for assignment of numbers for primary streets shall be as follows: 
(1)  Streets running north-south. Walton Boulevard shall constitute the base line for numbering buildings or structures along streets running generally in a north or south direction. 
(2)  Streets running east-west. Rochester Road shall constitute the base line for numbering buildings or structures along streets running generally in an east or west direction. 
(b)  Others previously established. In areas where other base lines were used prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives, street address numbers shall continue to be assigned according to those base lines. 
(c)  Streets crossing base lines. Prefixes for streets crossing the base lines shall be as follows: 
(1)  Running north-south. With respect to streets running generally north-south and crossing Walton Boulevard, that portion of the street lying north of Walton Boulevard shall bear the prefix "North" (N), while that portion lying south shall bear the prefix "South" (S). 
(2)  Running east-west. With respect to streets running generally east-west and crossing Rochester Road, that portion of the street lying east of Rochester Road shall bear the prefix "East" (E), while that portion lying west shall bear the prefix "West" (W). 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.03)  
Sec. 18-597. - Responsibility for making number assignments. 
(a)  Generally. The building department shall, at the time of issuing a building permit, assign in writing a street number to each new principal building or structure requiring a means of separate identification. 
(b)  Conformance to numbering system. Such address shall to the extent possible conform to the numbering system set forth in this article. 
(c)  Nonconformance due to preexistence. Where the numbering of buildings preexisting on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives makes conformance to the numbering system specified in this article impossible or impractical, the building department shall have discretion to assign street address numbers to correspond with the existing numbering. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.01; Ord. No. 414, § 1(4-11.04.01), 4-23-1997)  
Sec. 18-598. - Applicability to preexisting buildings or structures. 
New street address numbers shall be assigned for preexisting buildings and structures only as follows: 
(1)  No previous number. No such designating number has been previously assigned; 
(2)  Previous number nonconforming. A previously assigned number neither conforms to the numbering system created by this article nor to an already existing numbering system on the block or street and the owner consents to renumbering; or 
(3)  Owner's request. The owner of the premises, upon paying the fee prescribed in section 54-376, requests a new street address and the building department determines that the new street address will conform to the numbering system set forth in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.02; Ord. No. 414, § 1(4-11.04.02), 4-23-1997)  
Sec. 18-599. - Extension from base streets. 
(a)  North-south streets. To the extent possible, street address numbers for buildings and structures located on north-south streets shall be assigned on the basis of 1,000 numbers per mile, extending north and south from Walton Boulevard, except for that portion of the city located adjacent to the City of Rochester, and buildings and structures located on Dequindre Road and some north-south streets in sections 1, 2 and 3, where numbering shall correspond as closely as possible to street addresses existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives. 
(b)  East-west streets. To the extent possible, street address numbers for buildings and structures located on east-west streets shall be assigned on the basis of 1,000 numbers per mile, extending east and west from Rochester Road, except for that portion of the city located adjacent to the City of Rochester where numbering shall correspond as closely as possible to addresses existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.03)  
Sec. 18-600. - Numbering sequence. 
Beginning with zero at the applicable base line, street address numbers shall be assigned, to the extent possible, practical and consistent with existing numbering, at the sequence of one whole number for every 5½ lineal feet of street frontage. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.04)  
Sec. 18-601. - Multiple-family residential buildings. 
(a)  Common element. A multiple-family residential building shall be designated with one street address number if all of the dwelling units are accessed through a common element. 
(b)  Separate entrances. A multiple-family residential building where any dwelling unit has a separate entrance shall be assigned a street address number for each separate entrance. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.05)  
Sec. 18-602. - Nonresidential multitenant buildings. 
(a)  Common element. A multitenant commercial, office or industrial building shall be designated with one street address number if all of the tenant spaces are accessed through a common element. 
(b)  Separate entrances. A multitenant commercial, office or industrial building where any tenant space has a separate entrance shall be assigned a street address number for each separate entrance. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.06)  
Sec. 18-603. - Interior units of multiple-family/tenant buildings. 
Within buildings having one street address number, further numbering or designation of interior units or tenant spaces may be required consistent with the purposes of this article, in the discretion of the building department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.07)  
Sec. 18-604. - Streets not intersecting base street. 
All buildings or structures fronting on streets not extending through to the base line established in this article shall be assigned the same relative number as if the street did, in fact, extend to the applicable base line. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.04.08)  
Secs. 18-605—18-630. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DISPLAY 
 
Sec. 18-631. - Duty to affix number. 
It shall be the duty of the owner, lessee and occupant of every principal building or structure situated on a parcel of property within the city fronting on a public or private street, not including garages, barns and other accessory buildings or structures which are part of the same property with a numbered house or building, to affix on every such building or structure its proper street address number in the time and manner specified in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.02)  
Sec. 18-632. - Time to display newly assigned numbers. 
(a)  New construction. The assigned street address number shall be properly displayed on any new principal building or structure prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(b)  Preexisting buildings and structures. Where a new street address number has been assigned to a preexisting building or structure, the new number shall be properly displayed within 30 days following written notification of the new number assignment from the building department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.05)  
Sec. 18-633. - Manner of display. 
Every building or structure, both new and preexisting, shall have displayed the proper street address number, whether newly assigned or previously issued, in accordance with the following criteria: 
(1)  Angling of digits. Street address number shall be expressed by digits, placed on a horizontal line or a diagonal line no more than 45 degrees from horizontal so as to read properly from left to right. For those owners, lessees or occupants who prefer to display their street address numbers vertically or diagonally at an angle greater than 45 degrees, they may do so provided there is additional placement as prescribed in subsection (4) of this section. 
(2)  Size of digits. The digits used for street address numbers shall be at least three inches in height and made of durable and clearly visible material, which shall contrast with the background. 
(3)  Conspicuousness. Digits shall be conspicuously placed so that the street address number is plainly visible from the street from which the address is derived. Generally, digits shall be placed immediately above, on or adjacent to the main entrance of each building. 
(4)  Additional placement. Whenever any one-family or two-family dwelling is situated more than 75 feet from the traveled portion of the street, or as required in subsection (1) of this section, in addition to placement of the street number on the building as required in subsections (1) through (3) of this section, the number shall also be displayed on a separate sign, post or mailbox. The additional display shall have an area of not more than two square feet and shall be placed by the driveway or main vehicular entrance to the property at least one foot above the ground so as to be plainly visible from the street and shall otherwise comply with all requirements of this Code. 
(5)  Multiple-family residential buildings. 
a.  Common element. A multiple-family residential building where all units must be accessed through a common element shall display the street address number at the entrance facing the street from which the address is derived, and every entrance shall have a directory indicating interior unit designations. 
b.  Separate entrances. A multiple-family residential building with separate entrances shall display each assigned street address number in conformance with subsections (1) through (3) of this section. 
(6)  Nonresidential multitenant buildings. 
a.  Numbers. Multitenant commercial, office or industrial buildings shall display the assigned street address number at the entrance facing the street from which the address is derived, and in addition each building that has a front and rear entrance shall display the correct street address number immediately above, on or adjacent to both the front and rear entrances. The display of street address numbers shall conform with subsections (1) through (3) of this section. 
b.  Name. In addition to the street address number, each such building shall be clearly identified in the front, and also in the rear if there is parking in or access from the rear, by displaying the name of the owner, lessee, occupant or business or the name of the building. Unless otherwise visibly displayed, the name shall be clearly printed on the main door with letters no less than one inch or not greater than three inches in height, with a total area of not more than two square feet, and shall otherwise comply with all requirements of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 4-11.06)  
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic liquor, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; license registration for builders and contractors generally, § 18-3; licensing and registration of electrical contractors, § 18-196 et seq.; cable communications, ch. 26; community development, ch. 30; emergency services, ch. 42; fees, ch. 54; franchises, ch. 62; peddling, soliciting or advertising in parks, § 74-109; peddlers, solicitors and itinerant merchants, ch. 78; commercial and residential refuse control, § 86-26 et seq.; motor carrier safety, § 98-261 et seq.; utilities, ch. 102; B-1 local business districts, § 138-476 et seq.; B-2 general business districts, § 138-521 et seq.; B-3 shopping center business districts, § 138-566 et seq.; B-4 freeway service business districts, § 138-611 et seq.; B-5 automotive service business districts, § 138-656 et seq.; CI commercial improvement districts, § 138-701 et seq.; O-1 office business districts, § 138-751 et seq.; I-1 light industrial districts, § 138-796 et seq.; I-2 heavy industrial districts, § 138-841 et seq.; R-O research-office districts, § 138-886 et seq.; SP special purpose districts, § 138-931 et seq.; ORT office, research, technology districts, § 138-976 et seq.; supplementary district regulations, § 138-1066 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 22-1—22-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MASSAGE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Massage means a method of treating external parts of the body for remedial or hygienic purposes, consisting of rubbing, stroking, kneading, adjusting or tapping with the hand or any instrument, electric, magnetic or otherwise, with or without supplementary aids. 
Massage parlor means any Turkish bath parlor, steam bath, sauna bath, magnetic healing institute or any room, place, establishment or institution where treatment of any nature for the human body is given by means of massage and where a massage, alcohol rub, fomentation, bath, physiotherapy, manipulation of the body or similar treatment is given. 
Massage school means a school which requires for admission students with a tenth grade education or its equivalent; which employs one or more competent licensed massagists as instructors; and which has minimum requirements of a continuous course of study and training and consisting of study in physiology, anatomy, massage theory, hydrotherapy, hygiene, ethics and practical massage. For the purposes of this article, a correspondence school shall not be construed to be a recognized school. 
Massagist means any person, male or female, who administers to another person, for any form of consideration, a massage, alcohol rub, fomentation, bath, electric or magnetic massage procedure, manipulation of the body or other similar procedure. 
Student means any person who, under the guidance of an instructor in a massage school, is being trained or instructed in the theory, method or practice of massage. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-27. - Purpose. 
Massage parlors, massagists, massage schools, sauna baths, and similar businesses shall be licensed and regulated as provided in this article to prevent illegal sexual acts by and between those employed by such businesses and their patrons; to provide for the issuance, renewal and revocation of licenses according to the requirements of this article; and to prevent and abate public nuisances, disturbances and burdens created in connection with massage parlors, massage schools, sauna baths and similar businesses. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.01)  
Sec. 22-28. - Applicability. 
This article shall be applicable to all persons and businesses described in this article, whether the described activities were established before or after July 4, 1986, and including any person whose application is under consideration or investigation by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.08.01)  
Sec. 22-29. - Exemptions. 
This article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Licensed professionals. Medical doctors, doctors of osteopathic medicine, doctors of chiropractic medicine, physical therapists, psychiatrists, psychologists, clinical social workers, and family counselors, who are licensed to practice their respective professions in the state or who are permitted to practice temporarily under the auspices of an associate or establishment duly licensed in the state; clergymen; and certified members of the American Massage and Therapy Association, the International Myomassethics Federation and the associated bodywork and massage professionals. 
(2)  Nurses. Nurses who are registered under the laws of this state and who administer massage in the normal course of nursing duties. 
(3)  Athletic trainers. A trainer of any duly constituted athletic team who administers a massage in the normal course of training duties. 
(4)  Barbers and beauticians. Barbers and beauticians who are duly licensed under the laws of this state and who administer massage in the normal course of their duties. 
(5)  Seminar participants. Participants in growth seminars or sensitivity sessions, provided such seminars or sessions are conducted by a member of one of the exempted professions defined in this section. 
(6)  Licensed businesses with professionals. Any office or establishment in which the persons described in this section practice their respective professions. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.09; Ord. No. 415, § 1, 5-7-1997)  
Sec. 22-30. - Inspections. 
(a)  Access for inspectors. Every establishment ostensibly being operated as a massage parlor or massage school shall be open for inspection by duly authorized representatives of any city department concerned with the licensing and supervision of such establishment during operating hours for the purpose of enforcing any of the sections of this article or other city ordinances or regulations relating to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  Refusal of entry. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse entry by city representatives, for the purpose of making lawful inspections, to premises in which a massage parlor or massage school is ostensibly being operated. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.05)  
Secs. 22-31—22-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 
 
Sec. 22-56. - Required. 
(a)  Operation of business establishment. No person shall practice, engage in, carry on or operate the business of a massagist or conduct, operate and carry on a massage parlor, massage school, or similar business within the city without first having applied for and obtained the required license and complying with all regulations and requirements of this article. 
(b)  Employment as massagist. No person shall employ as a massagist any person who does not hold a current unrevoked license as required by this division. 
(c)  Massage for compensation. No person shall practice massage for compensation without obtaining and maintaining in effect a license as a massagist as required by this division. 
(d)  Duties of owners, operators and licensees. It shall be the responsibility of an owner, operator, manager or licensee in charge of or in control of a massage parlor, massage school or similar business to ensure that each person employed or engaged by him in the business as a massagist shall have first obtained a valid massagist license pursuant to this division. Any owner, operator, manager or licensee in charge of or in control of a massage parlor, massage school or similar business who employs a person performing as a massagist not in possession of a valid massagist license or who allows such an employee to perform, operate or practice within a massage parlor shall be in violation of this article. 
(Code 1976, §§ 3-12.03.01, 3-12.03.02)  
Sec. 22-57. - Application. 
(a)  Generally. Any person desiring to obtain a license to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business or to perform massage services shall make application to the city clerk. 
(b)  Investigation fees. Investigation fees shall be submitted as follows: 
(1)  Business license. An application to obtain a license to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business shall be accompanied by an investigation fee as provided in section 54-406, no part of which shall be refundable. 
(2)  Massagist license. Each applicant for a license to allow an individual to perform massage services shall be accompanied by an investigation fee as provided in section 54-406, no part of which shall be refundable. 
(3)  Payment of fees. The application fees required in this subsection shall be payable to the city treasurer at the time the application is filed, and the application fee shall be in addition to any other license or fee required in this Code. 
(c)  Contents. Any applicant for any of the licenses required in this division shall submit the following information: 
(1)  The full name and present address of the applicant. 
(2)  The two previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant and the dates of residence. 
(3)  A description of service to be provided. 
(4)  The location and mailing address of the proposed establishment. 
(5)  If the applicant is a corporation, the names and residence addresses of each of the officers and directors of the corporation and of each stockholder owning more than ten percent of the corporation. 
(6)  If the applicant is a partnership, the names and residence addresses of each of the partners, including limited partners. 
(7)  Written proof (birth certificate or sworn affidavits) that the applicant is at least 18 years of age. 
(8)  The individual applicant's height, weight, sex, color of eyes and hair. 
(9)  One portrait photograph at least two inches by two inches and a complete set of the applicant's fingerprints, which shall be taken by the county sheriff's department. 
(10)  Business, occupation, or employment of the applicant for the three years immediately preceding the date of the application. 
(11)  A certificate from a medical or osteopathic doctor stating that the applicant has, within 30 days immediately prior thereto, been examined and found to be free of any contagious or communicable disease. 
(12)  The history of an applicant in the operation of a massage parlor, massage school or similar business or occupation, including but not limited to whether or not such person, in previously operating in this city or another municipality or another state under license, has had such license revoked or suspended and the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. 
(13)  All criminal convictions other than civil traffic infractions and the reasons therefor. 
(14)  The application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant. 
(15)  Such other identification and information necessary to discover the truth of the matters specified in this subsection as required to be set forth in the application. 
(16)  In addition, the following additional information shall be contained in an application for a license to conduct a massage parlor: the number of employees and the names and qualifications of all persons who are intended to give massages in the proposed parlor. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.03; Ord. No. 410, § 1(1-08.02.08), 3-19-1997)  
Sec. 22-58. - Processing of application. 
(a)  Application to clerk. Any applicant for a license required pursuant to this division shall present to the city clerk the application containing the information described in section 22-57. 
(b)  Investigation by sheriff and staff. The application shall be referred to the sheriff's department and city staff, who shall have a reasonable time in which to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Based on such investigation, the sheriff's department and city staff shall render a recommendation to the city clerk as to the approval or denial of the license. 
(c)  Inspection of premises. The city's building department, planning department, fire department and the county health officer shall inspect the premises proposed to be devoted to the massage parlor, massage school or similar business and shall make within a reasonable time separate recommendations to the city clerk concerning compliance with the requirements of this article and all other applicable sections of this Code. 
(d)  Past record. In reviewing an application, the following shall be considered: 
(1)  Penal history. The applicant's convictions, the reasons therefor and the demeanor of the applicant subsequent to the applicant's release. 
(2)  License history. The license history of the applicant, whether such person in previously operating in this city or state or in another municipality or state under a license has had such license revoked or suspended, the reasons therefor and the demeanor of the applicant subsequent to such action. 
(3)  Basis for denial. The sheriff's department and city staff shall recommend denial of an application for a license if the character, reputation, moral integrity, or physical or mental condition of the applicant or the applicant's employees is inimical to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.04)  
Sec. 22-59. - Establishment facilities. 
No license to conduct a massage parlor, massage school or similar business shall be issued unless an inspection by the city reveals that the establishment complies with each of the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Sign. A recognizable and readable sign shall be posted at the main entrance identifying the establishment as a massage parlor or massage school, provided that all such signs shall comply with the city sign requirements. 
(2)  Lighting. Minimum lighting shall be provided in accordance with the state construction code and, in addition, at least one artificial light of not less than 60 watts shall be provided in each enclosed room or booth where massage services are being performed on a patron. 
(3)  Sterilizing equipment. Adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing instruments used in performing the acts of massage shall be provided. 
(4)  Water. Hot and cold running water shall be provided at all times. 
(5)  Storage cabinets. Closed cabinets shall be provided, which cabinets shall be utilized for the storage of clean linen. 
(6)  Bathing, dressing, locker and toilet facilities. Adequate bathing, dressing, locker and toilet facilities shall be provided for patrons. A minimum of one tub or shower; one dressing room containing a separate locker for each patron to be served, which locker shall be capable of being locked; as well as a minimum of one toilet and one wash basin shall be provided by every massage parlor. However, if male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously at the establishment, separate bathing rooms, separate massage rooms, separate dressing rooms and separate toilet facilities shall be provided for male and female patrons. 
(7)  Cleanliness. All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms, and all other physical facilities for the establishment must be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms or steam or vapor cabinets, shower compartments and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs and/or showers shall be thoroughly cleaned after each use. 
(8)  Towels and linens. Clean and sanitary towels and linens shall be provided for each patron of the establishment or each patron receiving massage services. No common use of towels or linens shall be permitted. 
(9)  Washbasins. A minimum of one separate washbasin shall be provided in each massage parlor for the use of employees of any such establishment. The basin shall be provided with soap or detergent and hot and cold running water at all times and shall be located within or as close as practicable to the area devoted to the performing of massage services. In addition, there shall be provided at each washbasin sanitary towels placed in permanently installed dispensers. 
(10)  Privacy. No massage shall be performed in a massage parlor or a massage school in a private room that is completely closed to the view of other persons; however, reasonable measures may be used to offer privacy to patrons such as partitions, stalls, curtains and the like. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.04)  
Sec. 22-60. - Report and recommendation. 
(a)  Forwarding to council. The city clerk, upon receiving all information and making such additional investigation as deemed necessary under this division, shall forward a report and recommendation to the city council which shall approve or deny a license. 
(b)  Approval. A license shall be approved for an establishment if all requirements for a massage parlor, massage school or similar business described in this article are met. 
(c)  Denial. A license shall be denied for an establishment if the city council determines there has not been compliance with the requirements of this article and other sections of this Code or the establishment has or will have an adverse effect upon the public health, safety or welfare of the community. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.05)  
Sec. 22-61. - Annual fee. 
The city clerk shall issue a license approved by the city council to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business authorized by this article to administer massages upon paying to the city treasurer the annual fee as provided in section 54-406. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.07(A))  
Sec. 22-62. - Issuance for persons performing massages. 
If a license is granted for an establishment under this division, the city clerk shall issue a license to all persons who have applied to perform massage services therein, unless it appears that: 
(1)  Any such person has deliberately falsified the application; or 
(2)  The record of any such person reveals a conviction of a felony or a crime of moral turpitude or the person otherwise violates this article. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.06)  
Sec. 22-63. - Duration. 
The license year for any license issued under this division shall be the period from the date of license issuance to December 31 next, inclusive, unless otherwise provided. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.07(B))  
Sec. 22-64. - Expiration. 
Under this division, all licenses issued for the license year shall expire on December 31, unless suspended or revoked prior to that time. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.07(C))  
Sec. 22-65. - Transferability. 
(a)  Generally. All licenses issued under this division shall be nontransferable; provided, however, a change of location of a massage parlor or similar business may be permitted pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Change of location. A change of location of any of the premises may be approved by the city clerk and planning director, provided the requirements of the city and state law are complied with and the change of location fee, as provided in section 54-406, is paid to the city. 
(c)  Sale or transfer. Upon the sale or transfer of any interest in a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, the license shall be null and void. A new license may be obtained in accordance with the following: 
(1)  New application required. A new application shall be made by any person desiring to own or operate the massage parlor, massage school or similar business. Section 22-57 shall apply to any person applying for a massage establishment license for premises previously used as such establishment. 
(2)  Inspection and facility compliance. Any sale or transfer of any interest in an existing massage establishment or any application for an extension or expansion of the building or other place of business of the massage establishment shall require inspection and shall require compliance with section 22-59. 
(3)  Fee. A fee as provided in section 54-406 shall be payable for each application involving extension or expansion of the building or other place of business of the massage establishment. 
(Code 1976, §§ 3-12.03.08, 3-12.03.11, 3-12.03.13; Ord. No. 414, § 1(1-08.02.08), 4-23-1997)  
Sec. 22-66. - Renewal. 
(a)  Time limits. The license to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, as well as a massagist license, shall be renewed at least 15 days prior to the date of expiration. 
(b)  Sworn affidavit. The license shall be renewed by the city clerk, provided the applicant submits a sworn affidavit that the matters contained in the original application are correct and indicating any changes necessary. 
(c)  Statement from doctor. In addition to the affidavit, the applicant shall submit a signed statement from a medical or osteopathic doctor that the applicant for a massagist license has been examined within the prior 90 days and found to be free from any contagious or communicable disease that is likely to be communicated during the administration of a massage. 
(d)  Final decision by city council. If the city clerk believes, after receiving reports from the sheriff or city staff and any other investigation, that there has not been compliance with this article and this Code or there are other reasons not to renew a license, the renewal shall be submitted to the city council whose decision shall be final. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.09)  
Sec. 22-67. - Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  Hearing required for revocation. No license issued pursuant to this division shall be revoked until after a hearing shall be held before the city council to determine just cause for such revocation. 
(b)  Suspension pending hearing. The mayor may order any license suspended pending such hearing required by subsection (a) of this section, and it shall be unlawful for any person to carry on the business of a massagist or to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, depending upon the particular type of license, until it has been reinstated by the city council. 
(c)  Grounds. Any revocation or suspension of a license issued under this division shall be based upon noncompliance with the standards or requirements of this article and this Code. 
(d)  Hearing on suspension. Upon suspension, a licensee may request a hearing in writing addressed to the city clerk. A hearing shall be held within seven days in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Contents of notice. Notice of such hearing shall be given in writing and served prior to the date of the hearing thereon. The notice shall state the grounds of the complaint against the holder of such license or against the business carried on by the licensee at the establishment and shall state the time and place where such hearing shall be held. 
(2)  Service of notice. The notice shall be served upon the license holder by delivering the notice to such person or by leaving the notice at the place of business or residence of the license holder in the custody of a person of suitable age and discretion. If the license holder cannot be found and the service of such notice cannot be made in the manner provided in this subsection, a copy of the notice shall be mailed, postage fully prepaid, addressed to the license holder at his place of business or residence at least five days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.12)  
Secs. 22-68—22-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OPERATING REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 22-96. - Display of license. 
Every person to whom or for which a license shall have been granted pursuant to division 2 of this article shall display the license in a conspicuous place so that it may be readily seen by persons entering the premises where the massage, bath or treatment is given. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.03.10)  
Sec. 22-97. - Hours of operation. 
No massage parlor or massage school shall be open to the public for business between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.06.01)  
Sec. 22-98. - Employees. 
(a)  Duty to ensure licensing of massagists. It shall be the responsibility of the holder of the license for the massage parlor or the employer of any person purporting to act as a massagist to ensure that each person employed as a massagist shall first have obtained a valid license pursuant to division 2 of this article. 
(b)  Emergency employee. If the holder of a license to operate a massage parlor is required to use an emergency employee because of illness or incapacity of a regular licensed employee, the use of an emergency employee shall be permitted, provided that such emergency employee shall be required to make application for a valid license as required in this article within three days from the date of beginning work. The term "emergency employee" shall be defined to mean an individual who possesses a current unrevoked massagist license issued by another city or township in the state, who works not more than three days per year in the city and who does not possess a valid city license. 
(Code 1976, §§ 3-12.06.02, 3-12.06.03)  
Sec. 22-99. - Wearing apparel. 
Uniforms or garments covering the torso shall be worn by massagists or employees while attending patrons. Such uniforms or garments shall be made of washable material and shall be kept in a clean condition. The sleeves of the uniform or garment shall not reach below the elbow. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.06.04)  
Sec. 22-100. - Unlawful activities. 
(a)  Illegal purpose. It shall be unlawful for any person to massage any other person or give or administer any bath or give or administer any of the other things mentioned in this article for illegal purposes or to have any contact with a person's breasts, genital area or buttocks in a manner intended to arouse, appeal to or gratify a person's lust, passions or sexual desire. 
(b)  Attending opposite sex. Serving or attending in a massage parlor of patrons of the opposite sex is prohibited. However, this subsection shall not apply when such service or attending is under the supervision of any person licensed to practice medicine under article 15 of the public health code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.16101 et seq., MSA 14.15(16101) et seq.). 
(c)  Rooms open to view. No massage shall be performed in a massage parlor or a massage school in a private room that is closed to the view of other persons. 
(d)  Grounds for revocation of license. Any violation of this section shall be deemed grounds for the revocation of the license granted under division 2 of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.07.01)  
Sec. 22-101. - Patronage of business by minors. 
No person licensed as a massagist shall massage or treat any person under the age of 17 years upon the licensed premises, except upon written order by a licensed physician, osteopath or registered physical therapist, such order being dated and in the possession of the massagist giving the massage or treatment. However, if the person under the age of 17 years is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian during the massage or treatment, this section shall not apply. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.07.02) 
Cross reference— Offenses concerning underage persons, § 70-296 et seq.  
Sec. 22-102. - Name of business. 
No person licensed as provided in this article shall operate under any name or conduct his business under any designation not specified in his license. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.07.03)  
Sec. 22-103. - Advertising. 
No massage parlor, massage school or similar business or a massagist granted a license under division 2 of this article shall place, publish or distribute or cause to be placed, published or distributed any advertisement, picture or statement that is known or, through the exercise of reasonable care, should be known to be false, deceptive or misleading in order to induce any person to purchase or utilize any professional massage services. 
(Code 1976, § 3-12.07.04)  
Secs. 22-104—22-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TOBACCO PRODUCT VENDING MACHINES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Selling, giving or furnishing tobacco products to person under 18 prohibited, MCL 722.641, MSA 25.281. 
 
Sec. 22-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Tobacco product means any product made from the tobacco plant for the purpose of smoking, chewing, inhaling or other personal use, including but not limited to cigars, cigarettes, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco and snuff. 
Tobacco product vending machine means any automated, self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses any type of tobacco product. 
(Code 1976, § 3-13.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-132. - Findings and purpose. 
The city council finds the U.S. Surgeon General and other medical authorities have linked the use of tobacco products to numerous and serious health problems, and state law prohibits the sale, giving or furnishing of tobacco products to minors. Yet, despite this prohibition, the availability of tobacco products to minors continues to be a major problem, and tobacco product vending machines are often located in unattended and unmonitored areas allowing for the unlawful purchase of tobacco products by minors. Restricting tobacco product vending machines in the city to specified locations that are not generally accessible to minors will reduce the availability of tobacco products to minors and promote the public health, welfare and safety as a result. Therefore, the purpose of this article is to restrict tobacco product vending machines in the city to specified locations that are not generally accessible to minors. 
(Code 1976, § 3-13.01)  
Sec. 22-133. - Enforcement. 
Compliance with this article shall be enforced by the mayor, the city building department, the county sheriff's department, and other enforcement officers as the mayor may designate. 
(Code 1976, § 3-13.04)  
Sec. 22-134. - Restriction to specific locations. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, tenant or proprietor of any premises in the city to offer or sell tobacco products through a tobacco product vending machine except in the following specified locations: 
(1)  Access by minors to premises prohibited. A tobacco product vending machine may be placed or located wholly within premises or portions thereof to which access by minors is expressly prohibited either by law or by policy of the owner of the premises. 
(2)  Commercial and industrial buildings. A tobacco product vending machine may be placed or located wholly within a commercial building or industrial plant or a portion thereof where the general public is prohibited from entering by appropriate signs, where the tobacco product vending machine is intended strictly for the use of employees, and where minor employees are not usually admitted. 
(3)  Unattended and unmonitored areas. Notwithstanding subsections (1) and (2) of this section, no tobacco product vending machine shall be placed or located closer than 20 feet to any entrance or exit or within a restroom, coat room, outer waiting area, unmonitored hallway or any other area that is not constantly supervised or monitored during the hours the tobacco product vending machine is available for use, nor shall a tobacco product vending machine be placed or located in an area where it may be accessible to the public when the premises where it is located are closed. 
(Code 1976, § 3-13.03)  
Secs. 22-135—22-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MARIHUANA ESTABLISHMENTS 
 
Sec. 22-161. - Marihuana establishments prohibited. 
Pursuant to Section 6.1 of the Michigan Regulation and Taxation of Marihuana Act, the City of Rochester Hills completely prohibits marihuana establishments, as defined in the Act, within the city's municipal boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 608 , § 1, 12-3-2018)  
Secs. 22-162—22-185. - Reserved.  
Chapter 26. - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; franchises, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 102. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 26-1—26-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FRANCHISE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-26. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, any subsequent ordinance provisions or Code sections dealing with cable communications, any franchise agreement between the city and a cable communications company, and any application or proposal submitted, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning; words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning: 
Access cablecasting means services provided by a cable television system on its access channels. 
Access channels means channels that are dedicated to the public, educational and governmental interests. 
Applicant means a person or company submitting a proposal for the franchise of a cable communications system. 
Authority means the Intergovernmental Cable Communications Authority established by the Intergovernmental CATV Agreement of 1981, effective July 20, 1981, as may be amended from time to time. 
Basic service means all subscriber services provided by the grantee, including the delivery of broadcast signals, covered by the regular monthly charge, if any, paid by all subscribers, excluding optional services for which a separate charge is made. 
Cable communications service means the business, in whole or in part, of receiving directly or indirectly over the air and amplifying or otherwise modifying signals transmitting programs broadcast by one or more signals, sound signals, pictures, visual images, digital signals, telemetry, or any other type of closed circuit transmission by means of electrical or light impulses, whether or not directed to originating signals or receiving signals off the air, and redistributing such signals by wire, cable or other means to members of the public. 
Cable communications system, cable system, CATV and system means a system of coaxial cables or other electrical conductors or fiber optical cables and equipment used or to be used to originate or receive television or radio signals directly or indirectly off of the air and to transmit them via cable to subscribers for a fixed or variable fee, including the origination, receipt, transmission, and distribution of voices, sound signals, pictures, visual images, digital signals, telemetry, or any other type of closed circuit transmission by means of electrical impulses, whether or not directed to originating signals or receiving signals off of the air. 
Cablecast means to distribute programs, both from broadcasting sources and original programs, through the community system by means of coaxial cables or other electrical conductors or fiber optical transmitters. 
Community specific cablecasting means programming or channel allocation which selectively cablecasts to individual communities to meet their unique needs or interests.
