(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-83. - Consideration. 
In consideration of the rights, power and authority hereby granted, the grantee shall faithfully perform all responsibilities and obligations required under this article. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-84. - Conditions. 
No highway, street, alley, bridge, waterway or other public place shall be obstructed by the grantee in the performance of its business under this article. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-85. - Hold harmless. 
To the fullest extent permitted by law, the grantee shall at all times keep and save the city free and harmless from all loss, costs and expense to which it may be subjected by reason of the grantee's operations or the granting of this franchise. In case any action is commenced against the city on account of, or as a direct or indirect result of, the franchise given in this article, the grantee shall, upon notice, defend the city and save it free and harmless from all losses, costs, claims and damages, including litigation costs and actual attorney's fees, arising therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-86. - Extensions. 
The grantee may from time to time extend its services and furnish electricity to customers within the city in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-87. - Franchise not exclusive. 
The rights, power and authority in this article granted are not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-88. - Rates. 
The grantee shall be entitled to charge its customers in the city for electricity furnished at the rate and upon the terms and conditions approved by the state public service commission, which commission or its successors have authority and jurisdiction to fix and regulate electric rates and promulgate rates regulating such service in the city. Such rate shall be subject to review and change at any time upon petition made by either the city acting through the city council, or by the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-89. - Processing fee. 
The grantee shall pay to the city a fee of $5,000.00 to cover the administration and costs incurred by the city for processing the grantee's application and ensuring that the terms of this agreement are adhered to. The fee shall be paid to the city at the time of the grantee's acceptance of the franchise pursuant to section 62-93. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-90. - Revocation. 
The franchise granted by this article is subject to revocation at the will of the city council upon 60 days written notice to the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-91. - State public service commission jurisdiction. 
The grantee shall, as to all other conditions and terms of service not fixed in this article, be subject to the rules and regulations of the state public service commission applicable to the furnishing of electricity by the grantee in the city. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-92. - City jurisdiction. 
The grantee shall remain subject to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city now in effect, or which might subsequently be adopted for the regulation of land uses or for the protection of the public health, safety and general welfare; provided, however, that nothing in this article shall be construed as a waiver by the grantee of any of its existing or future rights under state or federal law or a limitation upon the existing or future powers of the city under its Charter or state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Sec. 62-93. - Effective date. 
The franchise granted in this article shall take effect on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived; provided, however, the franchise shall cease and be of no effect 30 days after its adoption unless within that period the grantee shall accept the franchise in writing filed with the city clerk. Upon the grantee's written acceptance, this article shall constitute a contract between the city and the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 439, § 1, 4-21-1999)  
Chapter 66. - MUNICIPAL CIVIL INFRACTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to designate certain violations as municipal civil infractions, MCL 117.4l, MSA 5.2083(2); municipal civil infractions, MCL 600.8701 et seq., MSA 27A.8701 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 66-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Authorized enforcement officer means all county sheriff's deputies and all city personnel designated by the mayor or authorized by this Code or city ordinance to issue municipal civil infraction citations or municipal civil infraction notices. 
Municipal civil infraction means a violation of this Code or a city ordinance for which the remedy and/or sanction is prescribed to be a civil fine or sanction other than a criminal penalty. A municipal civil infraction is not a lesser included offense of a criminal offense or of a violation of this Code or of an ordinance violation that is not a civil infraction. 
Municipal civil infraction determination means a determination that a defendant is responsible for a municipal civil infraction based on one of the following: 
(1)  An admission of responsibility for the municipal civil infraction; 
(2)  An admission of responsibility for the municipal civil infraction, with explanation; 
(3)  A preponderance of the evidence at an informal hearing or formal hearing; or 
(4)  A default judgment for failing to appear at a scheduled appearance. 
Municipal civil infraction violation notice means a written notice prepared by an authorized enforcement officer, directing a person to appear at the ordinance violations bureau established under article II of this chapter for the purpose of paying a civil fine and/or costs for a violation which is prescribed to be a municipal civil infraction. 
Violation means any act or offense which is prohibited or declared to be unlawful under this Code or a city ordinance and any omission or failure to act where the act is required by this Code or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.01), 3-5-1997) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions, MCL 600.8701, 600.8707(6), MSA 27A.8701, 27A.8707, (6).  
Sec. 66-2. - Commencement of municipal civil infraction actions. 
A municipal civil infraction action is commenced upon the issuance by an authorized enforcement officer of either of the following: 
(1)  Citation. A municipal civil infraction citation directing the alleged violator to appear in district court; or 
(2)  Violation notice. A municipal civil infraction violation notice directing the alleged violator to appear at the ordinance violations bureau. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.02.01), 3-5-1997)  
Sec. 66-3. - Citation form. 
The form and content of citations used for municipal civil infraction violations shall be in accordance with sections 8705 and 8709 of Public Act No. 12 of 1994 (MCL 600.8705, 600.8709, MSA 27A.8705, 27A.8709). 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.02.02), 3-5-1997) 
State Law reference— Citation form, MCL 600.8705, MSA 27A.8705; citation contents, MCL 600.8709, MSA 27A.8709.  
Sec. 66-4. - Issuance and service of citations. 
(a)  Basis for issuance. The basis for issuance of a municipal civil infraction citation shall be as follows: 
(1)  Witness by authorized enforcement officer. An authorized enforcement officer who witnesses a person violate a section of this Code or an ordinance, the violation of which is a municipal civil infraction, shall prepare and subscribe, as soon as possible and as completely as possible, an original and three copies of a citation unless the officer instead issues a municipal civil infraction violation notice pursuant to section 66-35. 
(2)  Based upon investigation. An authorized enforcement officer may issue a citation to a person if, based upon investigation, the officer has reasonable cause to believe that a person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(3)  Based upon investigation of complaint by witness. An authorized enforcement officer may issue a citation to a person if, based upon investigation of a complaint by someone who allegedly witnessed the person violate a section of this Code or an ordinance, the violation of which is a municipal civil infraction, the officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and if the city attorney approves in writing the issuance of the citation. 
(b)  Filing and service. Municipal civil infraction citations shall be filed with the district court, and a copy shall be served in the following manner: 
(1)  Personal service. Except as otherwise provided in subsections (b)(2) and (b)(3) of this section, the authorized enforcement officer shall personally serve a copy of the citation upon the alleged violator. 
(2)  Use or occupancy of land; posting. In a municipal civil infraction action involving the use or occupancy of land or a building or other structure, a copy of the citation need not be personally served upon the alleged violator but may be served upon an owner or occupant of the land, building or structure by posting the copy on the land or attaching the copy to the building or structure. In addition, a copy of the citation shall be sent by first class mail to the owner of the land, building or structure at the owner's last known address. 
(3)  Processing of citation. A citation served as provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section for a violation involving the use or occupancy of land or a building or other structure shall be processed in the same manner as a citation served personally upon a defendant. 
(Ord. No. 408, §§ 2(1-05.02.03), 2(1-05.02.04), 3-5-1997) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 600.8707, MSA 27A.8707.  
Sec. 66-5. - Failure to appear. 
A person served with a municipal civil infraction citation, as provided in subsection 66-4(b), who fails to appear within the time specified in the citation or at the time scheduled for a hearing or appearance is guilty of a misdemeanor. Failure to appear will also result in the entry of a default judgment on the municipal civil infraction. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 600.8723, 600.8727(9), MSA 27A.8723, 27A.8727, (9).  
Secs. 66-6—66-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS BUREAU[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Authority to establish a municipal ordinance violations bureau, MCL 600.8396, MSA 27A.8396. 
 
Sec. 66-31. - Established. 
An ordinance violations bureau is established for the purpose of accepting admissions of responsibility for municipal civil infractions in response to municipal civil infraction violation notices issued and served by authorized enforcement officers, and to collect civil fines and costs prescribed by this Code or by city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.03.01), 3-5-1997)  
Sec. 66-32. - Location. 
The ordinance violations bureau shall be located in the city's administrative offices and shall be under the supervision and control of the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.03.03), 3-5-1997)  
Sec. 66-33. - Authority. 
(a)  Acceptance of payment. The ordinance violations bureau is authorized to accept admissions of responsibility for municipal civil infractions in response to municipal civil infraction violation notices and to collect civil fines and costs in connection therewith. 
(b)  Nonacceptance of payment where responsibility denied. The ordinance violations bureau shall not accept payment of a fine or costs from any person who denies having committed the municipal civil infraction charged in a municipal civil infraction violation notice or who admits responsibility only with explanation. 
(c)  Authority to determine responsibility. The ordinance violations bureau shall not have authority or jurisdiction to determine or attempt to determine the truth or falsity of any fact or matter relating to an alleged violation. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.03.04), 3-5-1997)  
Sec. 66-34. - Disposition of payments. 
Payments made to the ordinance violations bureau shall be retained and accounted for as fines and costs, respectively, and shall be deposited in the city's budgetary fund to which the cost of enforcing the particular section of this Code or ordinance is charged. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.03.02), 3-5-1997)  
Sec. 66-35. - Municipal civil infraction violation notices. 
An authorized enforcement officer may issue and serve a municipal civil infraction violation notice, instead of a citation, under the same circumstances and in the same manner as provided for the service of citations. The violation notice shall indicate the time by which the alleged violator must appear at the ordinance violations bureau, the means by which a violator may appear, the address and telephone number of the ordinance violations bureau, the ordinance violations bureau's hours, the amount of the fine for the violation, the consequences for failure to appear or to pay the fine, together with any other information required by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.02.05), 3-5-1997) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 600.8707(6), MSA 27A.8707, (6).  
Sec. 66-36. - Disposition of violations. 
(a)  Alleged violator's options. Any person receiving a municipal civil infraction violation notice may dispose of the charge alleged in the notice by making payment of the fine and/or costs to the ordinance violations bureau. However, a person shall have the right to elect not to have the violation processed by the ordinance violations bureau and to instead have the alleged violation processed in district court. The unwillingness of any person to dispose of a violation at the bureau shall not prejudice the person or in any way diminish the person's rights, privileges and protection accorded by law. 
(b)  Procedure for processing violation at bureau. A person electing to have the alleged violation processed at the ordinance violations bureau shall appear at the bureau and pay the specified fine and/or costs within the time specified for appearance in the municipal civil infraction violation notice. Appearance may be made by mail, in person or by representation. If appearance is made by mail, the person charged in the notice shall be responsible for timely delivery of the fine and/or costs within the time specified in the municipal civil infraction violation notice. 
(c)  Procedure where responsibility not admitted or fine not paid. If a person elects not to admit responsibility or pay the specified civil fine and/or costs prescribed for the alleged violation, an authorized enforcement officer may file a municipal civil infraction citation with the district court, in which case a copy of the citation shall be served by first class mail upon the person charged with the municipal civil infraction at the person's last known address. The citation filed with the court need not comply in all particulars with section 66-3, but shall consist of a sworn complaint containing the allegations stated in the municipal ordinance violations notice and shall fairly inform the defendant how to respond to the citation. 
(Ord. No. 408, § 2(1-05.03.05), 3-5-1997) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 600.8707(6), MSA 27A.8707, (6).  
Sec. 66-37. - Schedule of civil fines. 
(a)  A schedule of civil fines payable to the ordinance violations bureau established under this article for admissions of responsibility by persons served with municipal civil infraction violation notices is listed in subsection (c) of this section. 
(b)  A copy of the adopted schedule of civil fines shall be posted at the ordinance violations bureau.

Chapter 70 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Michigan Penal Code, MCL 750.1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Hunting. 
No person shall hunt wild game or fowl or in any manner carry any gun, weapon or firearm within the city for the purpose of hunting any wild game or fowl at any time. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.16)  
Sec. 70-2. - Trapping. 
No person shall, by use of any pit, pitfall, deadfall, cage, snare, trap, net, baited hook, or any similar device or of any drug, poison, chemical or explosive, injure, capture or kill any bird, wild game or furbearing animal, nor shall any person at any time or in any manner whatsoever molest, harass, or annoy any such bird, wild game or furbearing animal within the city limits. However, a live cage may be utilized by a resident at his place of residence for purposes of removing a wild animal that is creating a nuisance to the resident or the resident's family. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.17)  
Sec. 70-3. - Trespass for hunting or trapping. 
No person shall trespass upon the lands of another to hunt or trap wild game or fowl within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.18)  
Secs. 70-4—70-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-31. - Retail fraud. 
(a)  Unlawful acts. A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity is guilty of retail fraud: 
(1)  Misrepresents the price. While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale, with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale, if the resulting difference in price is less than $200.00. 
(2)  Steals property. While a store is open to the public, steals property that is offered for sale, at a price of less than $200.00. 
(3)  Wrongful refunds and exchanges. With intent to defraud, obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and that belongs to the store, if the amount of money, or the value of the property, obtained or attempted to be obtained is less than $200.00. 
(b)  Violations; penalty. All violations of this section shall be misdemeanors and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a sentence of not more than 93 days of confinement to jail or by a fine of not more than $500.00, or both, in the court's discretion. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.20; Ord. No. 459, § 1, 2-23-2000) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 750.356d, MSA 28.588(4).  
Sec. 70-32. - Larceny under $200.00. 
(a)  Unlawful acts. If the property stolen shall be of the value of less than $200.00, it shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of larceny, by stealing, converting or wrongfully withholding the property of another, including but not limited to any of the following: 
(1)  Money, goods, chattels or services; 
(2)  Bank note, bank bill, bond, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order or certificate; 
(3)  Book of accounts for or concerning money or goods due or to become due or to be delivered; 
(4)  Deed or writing containing a conveyance of land; 
(5)  Valuable contract in force; 
(6)  Receipt, release, or defeasance; or 
(7)  Writ, process, or public record. 
(b)  Violations; penalty. All violations of this section shall be misdemeanors and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a sentence of not more than 93 days of confinement to jail or by a fine of not more than $500.00, or both, in the court's discretion. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.21; Ord. No. 459, § 1, 2-23-2000) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 750.356, MSA 28.588.  
Secs. 70-33—70-59. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TRESPASS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Recreational trespass, MCL 324.73101 et seq., MSA 13A.73101 et seq.; trespass generally, MCL 750.546 et seq., MSA 28.814 et seq. 
 
Sec. 70-60. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is so that the trespass on private property within the city shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1976, § 7-02.01)  
Sec. 70-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Owner means the titleholder, land contract purchaser, lessee, tenant, occupant, agent, employee or trustee thereof. For a public, private, or parochial school, the term "owner" includes authorized employees of the school or school district. 
Person means any individual, adult or minor, partnership, firm and corporation. 
Trespass means the unauthorized use of private property not open to the public or any public, private, or parochial school site which has been registered as provided for in this division by persons without the express written permission of the owner. The term "trespass" does not include the use of property by the owner thereof, members of his immediate family, and persons lawfully residing upon the property, nor shall it include a person accompanied by the owner, a member of his immediate family, or a person lawfully residing upon the property. The term "trespass" does not include a person in the process of or on property for the purpose of normal ingress to and egress from a residence; a commercial establishment; any public, private, or parochial school; or other occupancy of the property. 
Vehicle means any motor-driven vehicle of any type that utilizes sled-type runners, skis, wheels, or an endless belt tread or any combination thereof or other similar means of contact with the surface upon which it is operated, having a seat or saddle for the use of a rider. In addition, this term means every vehicle not entitled to be licensed for travel upon the public highways of the state that is designed primarily for recreational purposes, including but not limited to all-terrain vehicles, go-carts, trail bikes or drag bikes. 
(Code 1976, § 7-02.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-62. - Restrictions. 
(a)  Persons. No person shall trespass upon any private property not open to the public or on any public, private, or parochial school site that has been registered as provided for in this division. 
(1)  Written permission. Every person, except and in the company of the owner of the property, members of his immediate family and persons lawfully residing upon the property, shall carry with him at all times when on the property the express written permission of the owner. The written permission shall identify the property for which the permission is granted, the person to whom permission is granted, his address, the owner of the property, the duration of the permission, and the permission shall be signed by the owner. 
(2)  Display on request. The written permission shall be displayed to any law enforcement officer of the city or the county sheriff's department. 
(b)  Vehicles. No person shall operate, park, leave, stop, or stand a vehicle on private property of another without the express or implied consent or authorization from the owner. 
(Code 1976, § 7-02.03)  
Sec. 70-63. - Registration. 
To invoke the operation and enforcement of this division, an owner must register the property by appropriate description on forms provided by the city clerk to be filed with the city clerk, who shall maintain a current roster thereof. The owner shall furnish copies of the registration to the law enforcement agencies in and for the city. Registration shall be required annually. 
(Code 1976, § 7-02.04)  
Sec. 70-64. - Posted notice. 
(a)  Required. In order to invoke enforcement of this division for any particular property, notice must be posted by the owner in one or more places so as to be plainly visible to persons unfamiliar with such property for the purpose of giving notice that trespassing is prohibited. 
(b)  Form. The form of the posted notice required by subsection (a) of this section shall be substantially as follows: 
(1)  Private property not open to public. When displayed on private property not open to the public, such form shall read substantially as follows: 
This is private property. Any persons other than the owner as defined by the City Trespass Ordinance, or otherwise authorized by said Ordinance, must have on his person written permission to use the property, or said persons will be guilty of trespassing in violation of the City of Rochester Hills Trespass Ordinance. 
This property has been registered under the provisions of said Trespass Ordinance and violators will be prosecuted and unauthorized vehicles towed away or ticketed. 
(2)  School sites. When displayed on public, private, or parochial school sites, such form shall read substantially as follows: 
This is school property. No trespassing is allowed under the provisions of the City of Rochester Hills Trespass Ordinance; however, persons may utilize recreational facilities located on the property between the hours of sunrise and sunset. 
Violators will be prosecuted and unauthorized vehicles towed away or ticketed. 
(Code 1976, § 7-02.05)  
Sec. 70-65. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Right of entry. The registering of any private property pursuant to this division shall give the law enforcement agencies of the city, which includes the county sheriff's department, the right and authority to enter the property for the purpose of enforcing this division. 
(b)  Evidence of violation. In any enforcement proceeding for violation of this division, the owner as registered with the secretary of state shall be presumed to have placed or left standing any vehicle found on private property protected by this division. 
(c)  Remedies. Remedies for enforcement of this division shall be as follows: 
(1)  Towing vehicle. Any owner or law enforcement of the city may cause any vehicle that is violating this division to be towed away. 
(2)  Issuance of ticket. Any police officer or deputy sheriff may issue a ticket for violation of this division and leave it attached to any vehicle requiring the appearance of the owner thereof in court at the time and place designated therein to answer for the violation of this division. 
(Code 1976, § 7-02.06)  
Secs. 70-66—70-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-91. - Resisting, obstructing officer in discharge of duty. 
Any person who shall knowingly and willingly obstruct, resist or oppose any sheriff or other peace officer, building and zoning code enforcement officers, or any other person duly authorized, in serving or attempting to serve or execute any process, rule or order made or issued by lawful authority, or who shall obstruct, resist or oppose said officer/person by any means including verbally, physically or otherwise, in the execution of any ordinance, law, or any rule, order or resolution made, issued or passed by the City of Rochester Hills or by the State of Michigan or who shall assault, beat or wound any sheriff, other law enforcement officer, including building and zoning enforcement officers, or other person duly authorized, while serving, or attempting to serve or execute any such process, rule or order, or for having served or attempted to serve or execute the same, or who shall so obstruct, resist, oppose, assault, beat or wound any of the above-named officers, or any other person or persons authorized by law to maintain and preserve the peace, in their lawful acts, attempts and efforts to maintain, preserve and keep the peace, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500 or by a sentence of not more than 93 days of confinement in jail, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 478, § 1, 1-29-2003)  
Secs. 70-92—70-114. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DISORDERLY CONDUCT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Disorderly persons defined, MCL 750.167, MSA 28.364. 
 
Sec. 70-115. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is so that disorderly conduct shall be defined and prohibited. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.01)  
Sec. 70-116. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business parking lot means any privately owned parking area providing parking during business hours adjacent to and serving any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, office building, commercial building, industrial building or other business establishment. 
Cruising means operating or occupying any vehicle being driven in, upon, around or about essentially one place, location or premises, including but not limited to a business parking lot, for a period longer than is reasonable necessary to enter, exit, pass through, transact lawful business at, or frequent any establishment at or adjoining such place, location or premises. 
Loitering means remaining idle or lingering in essentially one location. The term "loitering" includes the concepts of spending time idly, loafing, lounging, standing or sitting around, walking about aimlessly, sitting in or on parked vehicles and also includes the colloquial expression, "hanging around." 
Public place means any structure, building, alley, street, house, hall, room, private property, or other place to which the general public has access for business, entertainment or other lawful purposes, including the front or immediate area of or parking area serving any store, shop, restaurant, tavern or other place of business, and also including public grounds, areas or parks. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-117. - Prohibited conduct. 
It shall be disorderly conduct and shall be unlawful for any person to commit or join with another person in the commission of any of the following acts: 
(1)  Prostitution. Any common prostitute. 
(2)  Molesting or assault. Any window peeper or any person who shall designedly molest, assault, or interfere with the persons or the safety, comfort, and repose of any person in any public place. 
(3)  Improper language. Any person who shall use indecent, obscene, immoral, vile, vulgar, or profane language in any public place or who shall use such language in the presence or hearing of any woman or child or who shall communicate such language to any woman or child via telephone. 
(4)  Disturbing the peace. Any person who shall make any improper, loud or tumultuous noise or disturbance which interferes with the peaceful enjoyment of the premises of others. 
(5)  Intoxication or unlawful imbibing. Any person who shall be drunk or intoxicated in any public place, and any person who shall imbibe any alcoholic liquor, including beer and wine, in any public place not licensed to sell such liquor for consumption on the premises. 
(6)  Illegal sale or dispensing of alcohol or liquor. 
a.  Any person who shall illegally sell, keep for sale, offer for sale or otherwise dispense alcoholic liquors or spirituous liquor either by the bottle or glass; 
b.  Any person who shall aid and abet in the illegal sale of alcoholic liquor or spirituous liquor; 
c.  Any person found loitering in or about a place where alcoholic liquors or spirituous liquor is illegally sold, offered for sale, or otherwise dispensed; and 
d.  Any person who shall represent his age to be 21 years or over, when such person shall be under the age of 21 years, for the purpose of illegally obtaining any alcoholic liquor or spirituous liquor. 
(7)  Loitering or cruising. Any person who shall loiter or cruise in a public place in such a manner as to: 
a.  Obstruct or interfere with the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles and pedestrians. 
b.  Create or cause a breach or disturbance of the peace or danger thereof. 
c.  Create or cause any unreasonable disturbance, annoyance or threat to the comfort, response or safety of any other person. 
d.  Obstruct or interfere with the free and uninterrupted use of private property or with any business lawfully conducted in, upon or fronting on any such public place so as to prevent the free and uninterrupted ingress to and egress from such business. 
e.  Obstruct, molest or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place by conduct including but not limited to the making of unsolicited remarks or gestures of an offensive, disgusting or insulting nature or which are calculated to annoy, disturb or threaten the person to whom or in whose presence they are made. 
(8)  Loitering in illegal place. Any person who shall knowingly loiter in and about any place where an illegal occupation or business prohibited by state law or local ordinance is being conducted, practiced, encouraged or allowed. 
(9)  Prowling. Any person who is found prowling in or about any public place, bus depot or bus stop, banking institution, motel, hotel, store, shop, public building, dwelling or private property with no valid reason for being there. 
(10)  Soliciting. Any person who stands, loiters, or strolls in any public place awaiting or seeking an opportunity to obtain money or valuable things from others by trick or fraud or to aid or assist therein. 
(11)  Breach of peace. Any person found unnecessarily shoving or jostling people in any public place, and any person who shall create any disturbance in any public place or who shall create a disturbance in any private place which shall result in any annoyance to the occupants and invitees of the immediate vicinity or who shall in any way cause a breach of the peace. 
(12)  Fights or disturbances. All persons who engage in or aid and abet in any fight, quarrel, riot or other disturbance in the city. 
(13)  Riots. Any person who shall collect, stand in crowds, or remain loitering in, on or about any street or other public place so as to hinder the free and uninterrupted passage of other persons or hinder or impede the free access to and departure from inside of any public hall, courtroom, or place of entertainment or worship, or who shall commit any act constituting a disturbance, public quarrel or riot or aid or abet in the commission of such act or any persons riotously congregated or assembled. 
(14)  Trespass on business parking lot. 
a.  Upon notification to leave. Any person remaining in any business parking lot for a period longer than reasonably necessary to transact lawful business at or frequent any establishment served by the business parking lot who, without legal right or lawful authority and upon being notified to leave by the owner, person lawfully in charge, or the servant, employee or agent of either, neglects to comply with or disregards such notification shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct. 
b.  After hours where posted. In addition to subsection (14)a. of this section, any person who enters or remains in any business parking lot at any time when entering or remaining in the lot is prohibited, as shown by a sign at the business parking lot, shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct, and it shall not be required that the person be otherwise first notified to leave. 
c.  Signs. The prohibition contained in subsection (14)b. of this section shall be effective at any business parking lot where the owner or person lawfully in charge has posted signs clearly stating the prohibition. Signs must be placed so they can be seen either at all entrances to the lot or at other prominent locations in the lot. Each sign must contain the following, or substantially similar, language: 
No parking or trespassing between _____ p.m. and _____ a.m. pursuant to section 70-117 of the City of Rochester Hills Code of Ordinances. 
(15)  Urinating in public . Any person who shall urinate or defecate in a public place other than in a toilet or a urinal. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-03.03.01, 7-03.03.03—7-03.03.05, 7-03.03.07—7-03.03.15, 7-03.03.19; Ord. No. 496, § 1, 5-4-2005)  
Secs. 70-118—70-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 70-146—70-170. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - AIRTIGHT REFRIGERATION DEVICES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Abandoned or unattended icebox or refrigerator, leaving in place accessible to children prohibited, MCL 750.493d. 
 
Sec. 70-171. - Purpose. 
Abandonment, neglect or indiscriminate location of iceboxes, refrigerators, deep freezes and other devices with airtight doors which constitute an attractive nuisance and danger to small children so that they may conceal themselves in such devices and thereby suffocate shall be controlled and regulated as provided in this division. 
(Code 1976, § 7-01.01)  
Sec. 70-172. - Abandonment or neglect. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or neglect any icebox, refrigerator, deep freeze or other device with airtight doors within the city unless all doors of the icebox, refrigerator, deep freeze or other device with airtight doors shall have been removed prior to such abandonment. 
(Code 1976, § 7-01.02.01)  
Sec. 70-173. - Possession or maintenance. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any icebox, refrigerator, deep freeze or other device with airtight doors in any place within the city unless: 
(1)  All doors of such icebox, refrigerator, deep freeze or other device with airtight doors shall have been removed. 
(2)  The icebox, refrigerator, deep freeze or other device with airtight doors shall be either kept or maintained: 
a.  In an inhabited dwelling; 
b.  Securely locked with a padlock or other locking device requiring a key, the key to which is at all times in the possession or under the control of an adult person and in such manner as to be unavailable to a minor child of less than 14 years of age; 
c.  In a structure securely locked with a padlock or other locking device, the key to which is at all times in the possession or under the control of an adult person and in such manner as to be unavailable to a minor child of less than 14 years of age; or 
d.  In a retail mercantile establishment under the control and supervision of an adult person. 
(Code 1976, § 7-01.02.02)  
Sec. 70-174. - Liability. 
For the purpose of this division, officers and/or members of the board of directors of any firm, association or corporation shall be charged with responsibility for their respective firms, associations or corporations complying with this division. 
(Code 1976, § 7-01.03)  
Secs. 70-175—70-200. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - WEAPONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Licenses required to sell, purchase, possess and carry certain firearms, MCL 28.421 et seq., MSA 28.91 et seq.; local units of government prohibited from imposing certain restrictions on pistols or firearms, MCL 123.1101 et seq., MSA 5.3415(1) et seq.; crimes relating to explosives and bombs, MCL 750.200 et seq., MSA 28.397 et seq.; crimes involving firearms and weapons, MCL 750.222 et seq., MSA 28.419 et seq. 
 
Sec. 70-201. - Discharge of firearms. 
No person shall discharge or use any firearm, gun, air rifle, air pistol, or any rifle or any handgun that propels BB's, bullets, pellets, or other similar projectiles, by means of spring, gas or air, except when: 
(1)  Lawfully acting in defense of persons or property. 
(2)  On the property of his domicile and no bullet, BB, pellet, or other similar projectile goes beyond the property. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.06) 
State Law reference— Discharge of firearms prohibited, MCL 750.234 et seq., MSA 28.431 et seq.

ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-231. - Prostitution. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Be employed in or found in any house of prostitution or ill fame or place where prostitution or lewdness is practiced, encouraged or allowed or in any house of assignation; 
(2)  Be the keeper, operator, or proprietor of such a place or the owner of property who shall knowingly permit such property to be used for such a place; 
(3)  Solicit for any such place; 
(4)  Solicit, accost, call or invite another person for any common prostitute or for any act of prostitution or lewdness; or 
(5)  Attempt to procure the commission by another or by others of any act of illicit intercourse or lewdness. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.01) 
State Law reference— Prostitution generally, MCL 750.448 et seq., MSA 28.703 et seq.  
Sec. 70-232. - Indecent exposure. 
No person shall intentionally exhibit himself in any place of entertainment or in any public place or to the public view, indecently clad or in the nude, or engage in any indecent, immoral or obscene conduct in such places, or make any indecent or open exposure of his person or of the person of another. 
(Code 1976, § 7-03.03.02) 
State Law reference— Indecent exposure, MCL 750.335a, MSA 28.567(1).  
Secs. 70-233—70-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Drug paraphernalia, MCL 333.7451 et seq., MSA 14.15(7451) et seq. 
 
Sec. 70-261. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Controlled substance means any drug, substance, or immediate precursor enumerated in schedule 1-5 of sections 7201 to 7231 of the public health code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.7201 et seq., MSA 14.15(7201) et seq.). 
Drug paraphernalia. 
(1)  Definition. The term "drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products and materials of any kind that are used, intended for use, or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance. It includes but is not limited to the following: 
a.  Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing or harvesting of any species of plant that is a controlled substance or from which a controlled substance can be derived. 
b.  Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, or preparing controlled substances. 
c.  Isomerization devices used, intended for use, or designed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant that is a controlled substance. 
d.  Testing equipment used, intended for use, or designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of controlled substances. 
e.  Scales and balances used, intended for use, or designed for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances. 
f.  Diluents and adulterants, such as quinine hydrochloride, mannitol, mannite, dextrose and lactose used, intended for use, or designed for use in mixing with, diluting, or cutting controlled substances. 
g.  Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use, or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from or in otherwise cleaning or refining marijuana. 
h.  Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons and mixing devices used, intended for use, or designed for use in compounding controlled substances. 
i.  Capsules, balloons, envelopes or other containers used, intended for use, or designed for use in packaging small quantities of controlled substances. 
j.  Containers and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances. 
k.  Hypodermic syringes, needles and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in parenterally injecting controlled substances into the human body. 
l.  Objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body, such as the following: 
1.  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls. 
2.  Water pipes. 
3.  Carburetion tubes and devices. 
4.  Smoking and carburetion masks. 
5.  Roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana cigarette, that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand. 
6.  Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials. 
7.  Chamber pipes. 
8.  Carburetor pipes. 
9.  Electric pipes. 
10.  Air driven pipes. 
11.  Chillums. 
12.  Bongs. 
13.  Ice pipes or chillers. 
(2)  Inclusions or exclusions from definition. The following are either included in or excluded from the definition, as indicated: 
a.  Paper with a colorful design or name designed or marketed for use with controlled substances are included in the definition. White paper or tobacco-oriented paper not designed or marketed for use with controlled substances and not displayed in proximity of other items within the definition are not included. 
b.  Roach clips or other pincer-type devices designed or marketed for use with controlled substances are included in the definition. Common paper clips, tie clips, hair pins and alligator clips not designed or marketed for use with controlled substances and not displayed in proximity of other items within the definition are not included. 
c.  Pipes, bongs and similar inhalators designed or marketed for use with controlled substances are included in the definition. Pipes and inhalators not designed or marketed for use with controlled substances and not displayed in proximity of other items within the definition are not included. 
d.  Common household or retail items not designed or marketed for use with controlled substances and not displayed in proximity of other items within the definition are not included. 
(3)  Additional considerations. In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, a court or other authority should consider, in addition to all other logically relevant factors, the following: 
a.  Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use. 
b.  Prior convictions, if any, of an owner or of anyone in control of the object under any local ordinance or state or federal law relating to any controlled substance. 
c.  The proximity of the object, in time and space, to a direct violation of this division. 
d.  The proximity of the object to controlled substances. 
e.  The existence of any residue of controlled substances on the object. 
f.  Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of an owner or of anyone in control of the object to deliver the object to a person whom he knows or should reasonably know intends to use the object to facilitate a violation of this division. The innocence of an owner or of anyone in control of the object as to a direct violation of this division shall not prevent a finding that the object is intended for use or designed for use as drug paraphernalia. 
g.  Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its use. 
h.  Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict its use. 
i.  National and local advertising concerning the object's use. 
j.  The manner in which the object is displayed for sale. 
k.  Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products. 
l.  Direct or circumstantial evidence of the ratio of sales of the object to the total sales of the business enterprise. 
m.  The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. 
n.  Expert testimony concerning the object's use. 
Market means the act of marketing a product. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-262. - Purpose. 
The possession, delivery, sale, marketing and advertising of items, paraphernalia, accessories or things which are designed or marketed for use with controlled substances shall be prohibited to: 
(1)  Protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(2)  Discourage the use of controlled substances. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.01)  
Sec. 70-263. - Enforcement. 
This division shall be enforced by the county sheriff's department, the state police, and/or other law enforcement officers as may be designated by the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.08)  
Sec. 70-264. - Civil forfeiture. 
Any drug paraphernalia used or possessed in violation of this division shall be seized and forfeited to the city or the seizing agency. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.06)  
Sec. 70-265. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  Misdemeanor of second degree. A person who violates any of the provisions of section 70-266 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. A misdemeanor of a second degree shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00 or by a sentence of not more than 30 days of confinement in jail, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(b)  Misdemeanor of first degree. If the offender has previously been convicted of a violation of section 70-266, any subsequent violation of the same section shall be a misdemeanor of the first degree. A misdemeanor of the first degree shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00 or by a sentence of not more than 90 days of confinement in jail, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(c)  Separate offenses. Each day that a violation of this section shall continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.07)  
Sec. 70-266. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  Delivery, sale or marketing. It is unlawful for any person to deliver, sell, market, or possess with intent to deliver, sell or market drug paraphernalia knowing or under circumstances where one reasonably should know that it will be used to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance. 
(b)  Possession. It is unlawful for any person to use or to possess with intent to use drug paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance. 
(c)  Advertisements. It is unlawful for any person to place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill, or other publication any advertisement, knowing or under circumstances where one reasonably should know that the purpose of the advertisement, in whole or in part, is to promote the sale of objects designed or intended for use as drug paraphernalia. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.03)  
Sec. 70-267. - Exceptions. 
The prohibitions contained in section 70-266 shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers, licensed medical technicians, technologists, nurses, hospitals, research teaching institutions, clinical laboratories, medical doctors, osteopathic physicians, dentists, chiropodists, veterinarians, pharmacists, or embalmers in the normal course of their respective businesses or professions; 
(2)  Common carriers or warehousers or their employees engaged in the lawful transportation of such paraphernalia; 
(3)  Public officers or employees while engaged in the performance of their official duties; or 
(4)  Persons suffering from diabetes, asthma, or any other medical condition requiring self-injection. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.05)  
Sec. 70-268. - Delivery to minors. 
Any person 18 years of age or over who violates subsection 70-266(a) by delivering drug paraphernalia to a person under 18 years of age who is at least three years his junior is guilty of a special offense which shall be punishable as a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Code 1976, § 7-12.04)  
Secs. 70-269—70-276. - Reserved.  
Sec. 70-277. - Possession/use of marijuana. 
(a)  Except as authorized by state law, it shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess marijuana. 
(b)  Any person who shall be convicted of violating this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00, or by imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 1, 4-24-2002)  
Secs. 70-278—70-295. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES CONCERNING UNDERAGE PERSONS[7] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 70-296—70-320. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic liquor, ch. 6. 
 
Sec. 70-321. - Findings and purpose. 
The city council determines that alcohol use by persons less than 21 years of age should be regulated, as unregulated use creates serious social problems, including but not limited to injury and harm to persons and property caused by vehicles operated by persons less than 21 years of age under the influence of alcohol, disturbance of the peace, and other devastating effects on not only the person less than 21 years of age involved but on the public at large. It is further determined that the regulation of the use of alcohol by persons less than 21 years of age will reduce the incidence of problems attributable to alcohol use by persons less than 21 years of age. 
(Code 1976, § 7-18.01)  
Sec. 70-322. - Enforcement. 
This division shall be enforceable by any deputy sheriff of the county sheriff's department. 
(Code 1976, § 7-18.04)  
Sec. 70-323. - Prohibited conduct and penalties. 
(a)  A minor shall not purchase or attempt to purchase alcoholic liquor, consume or attempt to consume alcoholic liquor, possess or attempt to possess alcoholic liquor, or have any bodily alcohol content, except as provided in this section. A minor who violates this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction or guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by the following fines and sanctions and is not subject to the penalties prescribed in section 909 of Public Act No. 58 of 1998 (MCL 436.1909): 
(1)  First offense. For the first violation, the minor is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and shall be fined not more than $100.00. A court may order the minor to participate in substance use disorder services as defined in section 6230 of the Public Health Code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978, MCL 333.6230, and designated by the administrator of substance abuse services, and may be ordered to perform community service and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at the minor's own expense. 
(2)  Second offense. If a violation of this subsection after one prior judgment, the minor is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 30 days if the minor has been found by the court to have violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening, or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, by a fine of not more than $200.00, or both, and may be ordered to participate in substance use disorder services as defined in section 6230 of the Public Health Code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.6230), and designated by the administrator of substance abuse services, to perform community service and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at the minor's own expense. 
(3)  Third or subsequent offense. If a violation of this subsection occurs after two or more prior judgments, the minor is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 60 days; if the minor has been found by the court to have violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening, or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, by a fine of not more than $500.00, or both, and may be ordered to participate in substance use disorder services as defined in section 6230 of the Public Health Code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978, MCL 333.6230 and designated by the administrator of substance abuse services, to perform community service, and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at the minor's own expense. 
(b)  A person who furnishes fraudulent identification to a minor, or notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a minor who uses fraudulent identification to purchase alcoholic liquor, is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $100.00, or both. 
(c)  A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a minor has consumed alcoholic liquor or has any bodily alcohol content may request that minor to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis. The results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis or other acceptable blood alcohol test are admissible in a municipal civil infraction proceeding or criminal prosecution to determine whether the minor has consumed or possessed alcoholic liquor or had any bodily alcohol content. 
(d)  A law enforcement agency, upon determining that a person less than 18 years of age and not emancipated pursuant to Public Act No. 293 of 1968, MCL 722.1 to 722.6, allegedly consumed, possessed, purchased, or attempted to consume, possess, or purchase alcoholic liquor in violation of subsection (a) of this section shall notify the parents, custodian, or guardian of the person as to the nature of the violation if the name of a parent, guardian, or custodian is reasonably ascertainable by the law enforcement agency. The notification required by this subsection shall be made not later than 48 hours after the law enforcement agency determines that the person who allegedly violated subsection (a) of this section is less than 18 years of age and not emancipated pursuant to Public Act No. 293 of 1968, MCL 722.1 to 722.6. The notification may be made by any means reasonably calculated to give prompt actual notice, including but not limited to, notice in person, by telephone, or by first class mail. If a person less than 17 years of age is incarcerated for violating subsection (a) of this section, his or her parents or legal guardian shall be notified immediately as provided in this subsection. 
(e)  This section does not prohibit a minor from possessing alcoholic liquor during regular working hours and in the course of his or her employment if employed by a person licensed by the Michigan Liquor Control Code, Public Act No. 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1101 et seq. by the Michigan Liquor Control Commission, or by an agent of the commission, if the alcoholic liquor is not possessed for his or her personal consumption. 
(f)  The following individuals are not considered to be in violation of subsection (a): 
(1)  A minor who has consumed alcoholic liquor and who voluntarily presents himself or herself to a health facility or agency for treatment or for observation including, but not limited to, medical examination and treatment for any condition arising from a violation of sections 520b to 520g of the Michigan Penal Code, 1931 PA 328, MCL 750.520b to 750.520g, committed against a minor. 
(2)  A minor who accompanies an individual who meets both of the following criteria: 
a.  Has consumed alcoholic liquor. 
b.  Voluntarily presents himself or herself to a health facility or agency for treatment or for observation including, but not limited to, medical examination and treatment for any condition arising from a violation of sections 520b to 520g of the Michigan Penal Code, 1931 PA 328, MCL 750.520b to 750.520g, committed against a minor. 
(3)  A minor who initiates contact with a peace officer or emergency medical services personnel for the purpose of obtaining medical assistance for a legitimate health care concern. 
(g)  This section shall not be construed to limit the civil or criminal liability of the vendor or the vendor's clerk, servant, agent, or employee for a violation of the Michigan Liquor Control Code, Public Act No. 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1101 et seq. 
(h)  The consumption of alcoholic liquor by a minor who is enrolled in a course offered by an accredited postsecondary educational institution in an academic building of the institution under the supervision of a faculty member is not prohibited if the purpose of the consumption is solely educational and is a requirement of the course. 
(i)  The consumption by a minor of sacramental wine in connection with religious services at a church, synagogue, or temple is not prohibited. 
(j)  Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a minor who participates in either or both of the following: 
(1)  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the person's employer and with prior approval of the local prosecutor's office as part of an employer-sponsored internal enforcement action. 
(2)  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the state police, the liquor control commission, or a local police agency as part of an enforcement action unless the initial or contemporaneous purchase or receipt of alcoholic liquor by the minor was not under the direction of the state police, the commission, or the local police agency and was not part of the undercover operation. 
(k)  In a prosecution for the violation of subsection (a) concerning a minor having any bodily alcohol content, it is an affirmative defense that the minor consumed the alcoholic liquor in a venue or location where that consumption is legal. 
(l)  As used in this section: 
(1)  "Any bodily alcohol content" means either of the following: 
a.  An alcohol content of 0.02 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine. 
b.  Any presence of alcohol within a person's body resulting from the consumption of alcoholic liquor, other than consumption of alcoholic liquor as a part of a generally recognized religious service or ceremony. 
(2)  "Minor" means an individual less than 21 years of age. 
(3)  "Prior judgment" means a conviction, juvenile adjudication finding of responsibility, or admission of responsibility for any of the following, whether under a law of this state, a local ordinance substantially corresponding to a law of this state, a law of the United States substantially corresponding to a law of this state, or a law of another state substantially corresponding to a law of this state: 
a.  This section or sections 701 or 707. 
b.  Sections 624a, 624b, or 625 of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.624a, 257.624b, and 257.625. 
c.  Sections 80176, 81134, or 82127 of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451, MCL 324.80176, 324.81134, and 324.82127. 
d.  Sections 167a or 237 of the Michigan Penal Code, 1939 PA 328, MCL 750.167a and 750.237. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-18.02, 7-18.03; Ord. No. 448, § 1, 9-29-1999; Ord. No. 493, § 1, 11-17-2004; Ord. No. 599 , § 1, 11-13-2017) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, MCL 436.1703.  
Secs. 70-324—70-350. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - HOUSE PARTIES 
 
Sec. 70-351. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Control means the authority to regulate, direct, superintend or govern or the authority to exercise restraining or dominating influence over, including a possessory right over property. With respect to a hall, a person who rents, leases, lets, hires or is otherwise responsible for arranging or obtaining use of the hall shall be considered to have control. 
Controlled substance means any drug, substance or immediate precursor designated and listed in schedules 1—5 of sections 7201 to 7231 of the public health code, Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.7201 et seq.). 
Hall means a hall, motel or hotel room, meeting room, ballroom, suite, club or other place of assembly used for a social function or gathering. 
Hall party means a social gathering at a hall. 
House party means a social gathering at a residence that includes at least one person who is not an owner, tenant or regular legal occupant of the residence. 
Residence means a house, apartment, condominium or other dwelling unit, including the curtilage and land around the dwelling unit to the extent the land is subject to the control of the same person having control of the dwelling unit. 
(Code 1976, § 7-14.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-352. - Purpose. 
The city council determines that alcohol and controlled substance use by persons less than 21 years of age should be regulated, as unregulated use creates serious social problems, including but not limited to injury and harm to persons and property caused by vehicles operated by persons less than 21 years of age under the influence of alcohol or controlled substances, disturbance of the peace, and other devastating effects on not only the person less than 21 years of age involved, but on the public at large. It is further determined that the regulation of house parties and hall parties involving alcohol and controlled substance use by persons less than 21 years of age by requiring sponsoring persons to assume responsibility for house parties and hall parties, and by prohibiting persons less than 21 years of age from attending such parties, will significantly reduce the incidence of problems attributable to alcohol and controlled substance use by persons less than 21 years of age. 
(Code 1976, § 7-14.01)  
Sec. 70-353. - Exceptions. 
This division shall not apply to legally protected religious observances and education activities. 
(Code 1976, § 7-14.04)  
Sec. 70-354. - Control and allowance of party. 
It shall be unlawful for any person 16 years of age or older having control of any residence or hall to allow a house party or a hall party to take place or to continue once it has begun at that residence or hall when the person knows or reasonably should know an alcoholic liquor or controlled substance is being or has been possessed or consumed at the house party or hall party by a person less than 21 years of age. 
(Code 1976, § 7-14.03.01)  
Sec. 70-355. - Attendance by person less than 21 years of age. 
It shall be unlawful for any person less than 21 years of age to attend a house party or hall party while having knowledge that alcohol or controlled substances are being sold, offered for sale or dispensed to or are being possessed by persons less than 21 years of age, unless the person less than 21 years of age is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(Code 1976, § 7-14.03.02)  
Secs. 70-356—70-399. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - E-CIGARETTES 
 
Sec. 70-400. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  Persons under age 18 are prohibited by law from purchasing or possessing cigarettes and other tobacco products, and retailers are prohibited from selling them to minors. However, new tobaccoless products, commonly referred to as e-cigarettes, are available which allow the user to simulate cigarette smoking and ingest nicotine. These products may be purchased by minors and are being marketed without age restrictions or health warnings and come in different flavors that appeal to young people. 
(b)  The production and distribution of e-cigarettes is not currently regulated by federal or state authorities, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has not completed testing of these products. But, initial studies by the FDA have determined that e-cigarettes can increase nicotine addiction among young people and contain chemical ingredients known to be harmful, which may expose users and the public to potential health risks. 
(c)  Therefore, the Rochester Hills City Council determines that prohibiting the sale, giving or furnishing of e-cigarettes to minors and prohibiting the purchase, possession or use of e-cigarettes by minors is in the city's best interests and will promote the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 586 , § 1, 10-6-2014)  
Sec. 70-401. - Definitions. 
(a)  E-cigarette shall mean an electronic oral device that provides a vapor of nicotine, simulates smoking through its use or through inhalation of the vapor generated by the device, is not approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration as an aid in quitting the use of tobacco or a nicotine product, and is composed of a heating element, battery or electronic circuit. 
(b)  E-cigarette cartridge shall mean a container which has openings on each end, serves as a liquid reservoir and mouthpiece, allows the passage of a liquid to an atomizer and vapor from the atomizer to the user's mouth, and contains liquid for producing vapor in an e-cigarette. 
(c)  Minor shall mean an individual younger than 18 years of age. 
(d)  Person shall mean an individual, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, wholesaler, retailer or any business. 
(Ord. No. 586 , § 1, 10-6-2014)  
Sec. 70-402. - Prohibitions; penalty. 
(a)  Sell, give or furnish to minor. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give, furnish, or offer for sale an e-cigarette or e-cigarette cartridge in the City of Rochester Hills to a minor. A person who violates this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00 for each violation. 
(b)  Purchase, use or possession by minor. It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase, possess or use an e-cigarette in the City of Rochester Hills. A person who violates this subsection is responsible for a municipal civil infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00 for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 586 , § 1, 10-6-2014)  
Sec. 70-403. - Affirmative defenses. 
(a)  It is an affirmative defense to subsection 70-402(a), above, that the defendant had in force at the time of the incident and continues to have in force a written policy to prevent the sale of e-cigarettes and e-cigarette cartridges to minors and the defendant enforced and continues to enforce the policy. 
(b)  Subsection 70-402(b), above, does not apply to the handling or transportation of e-cigarettes or e-cigarette cartridges by a minor under the terms, and in the course, of the minor's employment. 
(Ord. No. 586 , § 1, 10-6-2014)  
Sec. 70-404. - Age verification. 
Any person selling, offering for sale, giving or furnishing an e-cigarette or e-cigarette cartridge to an individual, shall first verify that the individual is not a minor by examining a government-issued photographic identification establishing that the individual is at least 18 years of age. Or, for sales over the internet or other remote sales method, the person shall perform an age verification through an independent, third-party age verification service that compares information available from a commercially available database, or aggregate of databases, that are regularly used by government agencies and businesses for the purpose of age and identity verification to the personal information entered by the individual during the ordering process that establishes the individual is 18 years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. 586 , § 1, 10-6-2014)  
Secs. 70-405—70-430. - Reserved.  
Chapter 74 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 94; vegetation, ch. 106. 
State Law reference— Authority to operate a system of public recreation, MCL 123.51 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 74-1—74-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Camping means the overnight lodging or sleeping of a person in a tent, trailer tent, trailer coach, vehicle camper, motor vehicle, or any other conveyance placed within a park. 
Motor vehicle means any power-driven vehicle, sports equipment, or motorized device, whether operated by means of wheels, tracks, runners, skis, or other means, whether or not eligible for licensing and registration under the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.). Motorized wheelchairs, carts or similar devices or equipment used for transporting persons unable to walk shall not be defined as motor vehicles. 
Park means any land owned or leased by or otherwise under the jurisdiction and control of the city, whether located within its boundaries or not, that has been designated by resolution of the city council to the use of the public for park purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.03) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 74-27. - Purpose. 
(a)  Establishment of city park system. A city park system shall be established to enrich the lives of the people of the city by granting recreational opportunities to the community. 
(b)  Establishment of rules for operation. Rules for the operation of the city parks shall be established in order to preserve the parks for the benefit of the community and to safeguard life and property. 
(c)  Establishment of conservation areas. Conservation areas may be established and maintained in city parks to secure for the people of the city the benefits of an enduring resource of natural environment. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.01)  
Sec. 74-28. - Applicability. 
This article shall apply to all property owned and/or operated as parks by the city. The city council shall designate park areas by resolution, copies of which shall be available for public inspection at the office of the city clerk during normal business hours. Such resolution shall contain a full legal description of the park property. City parks shall be posted as such by the department of parks, forestry, and facilities and their borders delineated by a fence or other means so as to inform the public that the area is a parkland. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.02)  
Sec. 74-29. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Enforcement authorities. A park shall be made secure and this article enforced by designated employees or agents of the city and as provided in section 1-14. 
(b)  Interference with duties prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or in any manner hinder any employee or agent of the city performing his official duties in the administration or policing of a park or to refuse to obey any lawful command of any such employee or agent. Nothing in this article shall prohibit or hinder duly authorized agents of the city or any peace officers from performing their official duties. 
(c)  Impersonation unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate such employee or agent. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.04)  
Sec. 74-30. - Emergency powers. 
Nothing in this article shall prohibit the mayor or the mayor's designee from establishing emergency rules designed to protect the health, welfare, and safety of park visitors, to protect park property, and to maintain order. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.05)  
Sec. 74-31. - Fees for use of park or facility. 
(a)  Established. Fees for the use of a park, on a daily or yearly basis, and/or charges for the use of any special facility made available within a park, on a yearly, seasonal, or per-use basis, shall be as set forth in article VIII of chapter 54. 
(b)  Payment mandatory. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a park or any facility for which such a charge is made without payment for such fee or charge, unless prior written waiver of such fee or charge by the mayor is received. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.06; Ord. No. 433, § 3, 7-1-1998)  
Secs. 74-32—74-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RULES AND REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 74-61. - Hours. 
The city council shall establish hours of operation for each park by resolution. No person shall enter or remain within a park at any other time, unless the hours have been extended for a special event by the mayor. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.01)  
Sec. 74-62. - Closed areas. 
The mayor may declare a park or a portion of a park closed to public use or entry. During periods when a park or portion thereof is designated as closed, no person shall enter or remain within such closed area at any time, except those persons whose presence is related to or in connection with a municipal activity or a project or an activity that has been licensed to be carried on within such park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.02)  
Sec. 74-63. - Motor-driven vehicles. 
(a)  Traffic code applicable. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate provisions of the Uniform Traffic Code as adopted by article III of chapter 98 of this Code, which traffic code is adopted in its entirety and made part and incorporated in this article by reference. 
(b)  Operation within park. It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Operate a motor-driven vehicle of any kind or nature except on designated roads and parking areas within a park. 
(2)  Operate a motor-driven vehicle on any park road at a speed exceeding 15 miles per hour or at any speed greater than that posted. 
(3)  Continuously cruise in any motor-driven vehicle within a park, for any purpose whatsoever. 
(c)  Stopping, standing or parking. Prohibitions and restrictions on stopping, standing and parking shall be as follows: 
(1)  Passenger or loading zones. It shall be unlawful for the operator of a motor-driven vehicle of any kind to stop, stand, or park the vehicle in any place marked as a passenger or loading zone, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or the unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials. 
(2)  Obstructing traffic. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to stop, stand, or park upon any roadway or in any parking area in such manner as to form an obstruction to traffic. 
(3)  Designated parking areas. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor-driven vehicle of any kind or nature any place within a park except in designated parking areas. 
(d)  Motorbikes and sport vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motorcycle, trail bike, all-terrain vehicle, or similar type of sport vehicle anywhere in a park except on the designated roads and parking areas. 
(e)  Sleds, toboggans, snowmobiles, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor-driven sled, toboggan, snowmobile, or similar type of vehicle anywhere in a park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.03) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate the speed of vehicles in public parks, MCL 257.606(1)(f), MSA 9.2306, (1)(f).  
Sec. 74-64. - Bicycles. 
(a)  Bicycles may be operated within a park, except where prohibited. 
(b)  Bicycles shall not be operated in an unsafe manner so as to endanger the operator or others. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.04) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98.  
Sec. 74-65. - Use of beach and lake. 
(a)  Swimming. No person shall swim, bathe, wade or scuba dive in a park lake, river, pond, or stream, except at such times and places as may be posted. Persons shall abide by posted swim rules.
