(b)  Food, beverages and containers. No person shall carry or consume any food or beverage of any kind, nor have in his possession any glass or metal container on any beach within a park. 
(c)  Floatation devices. No person shall use any floatation devices, inflatable or otherwise, within a park lake, river, pond, or stream, except as may be specifically posted for such use. 
(d)  Watercraft. No person shall bring into, use or navigate any watercraft of any kind, whether powered or not, including model watercraft, within a park, except as may be specifically posted for such use. This subsection shall not apply to boats made available by the city or its agent. 
(e)  Fishing. Fishing shall be prohibited in swimming areas designated by the placement of buoys and within 25 feet thereof. 
(f)  Winter sports. It shall be unlawful to skate, sled, walk or go upon any ice or to snowshoe or ski, except at such times and upon such places as may be posted within a park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.05)  
Sec. 74-66. - Roller skating or coasting. 
It shall be unlawful to roller skate or coast with skateboards, hand sleds, bobsleds, carts or other vehicles on wheels or runners, except on designated pathways. Such vehicles shall be operated in a safe manner. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.06)  
Sec. 74-67. - Camping. 
It shall be unlawful to stay or sleep overnight and to camp within the park, except in authorized areas pursuant to a written permit issued by the mayor. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.07)  
Sec. 74-68. - Fires. 
No person shall build any fire within a park, except within fireplaces, receptacles, or open spaces approved and designated for such purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.08) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 58.  
Sec. 74-69. - Exhibitions and performances. 
It shall be unlawful to exhibit any machine, show or animal or engage in any acrobatic exhibitions within a park or carry on any performance that shall cause persons to congregate so as to interfere with the proper use of a park by the community, or obstruct the passage of persons or vehicles on designated roadways within a park, except on written permit by the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.07.09)  
Secs. 74-70—74-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PROHIBITED OR RESTRICTED ACTIVITIES 
 
Sec. 74-96. - Malicious destruction. 
(a)  Property. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully destroy, deface, mark upon, cut, break, alter, change or remove any marker, structure, equipment, fence, foundation, gate, lamppost or notice of any kind whatsoever within a park. 
(b)  Trees, plants and natural surroundings. Within a park, it shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Cut, remove, or destroy any plant, including trees of whatever size, or deface or injure a plant in any way; 
(2)  Pick, uproot, remove or destroy any flower, plant or grass; or 
(3)  Remove or cause to be removed any sod, earth, humus, peat, boulder, gravel, or sand. 
(c)  Wildlife. It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt, trap, catch, wound, chase, harass, or kill or treat cruelly any bird or animal or attempt any of such activities or to molest or rob the nest, den or burrow of any such animal or bird within a park. 
(1)  Contraband. All game animals, fowl, birds, fish and other aquatic life hunted, killed, taken or destroyed, bought, sold, bartered or had in possession contrary to this article shall be and are declared to be contraband, and the animals, fowl, birds, fish and other aquatic life may be turned over to the state department of natural resources or properly disposed of by park officials. 
(2)  Weapons. Any weapon or object carried or used by any person in violation of this subsection shall be subject to seizure by the city or its agents and disposed of according to law. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.01)  
Sec. 74-97. - Burning. 
No person shall willfully set or cause to be set on fire any tree, woodland, brushland, grassland or meadow within a park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.02) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 58.  
Sec. 74-98. - Littering. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall drop, throw or otherwise scatter any material, object, or substance that is not part of the natural environment in a park. 
(b)  Inflammable materials. No person shall drop, throw, or otherwise scatter lighted matches or burning cigars, cigarettes, tobacco paper, or other inflammable material within a park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.03) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 86.  
Sec. 74-99. - Sanitation. 
(a)  Refuse. It shall be unlawful to discard or deposit refuse of any kind or nature within a park, except by placing the refuse in containers provided for such purpose. 
(b)  Pollution. It shall be unlawful to discharge or leave in a park any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which may result in the pollution of the air, water, or soil of the park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.04)  
Sec. 74-100. - Restriction of use. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a park official, to attempt to prevent any other person from entering, leaving or making full use of a park, by force, threats, unlawful fencing or any other means. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.05)  
Sec. 74-101. - Alcoholic liquors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring in, have in possession, or use alcoholic liquors within a park, except that the use of alcoholic liquors may be permitted with the permission of the city council and if the park facility and/or its operator has been issued a liquor license by the state liquor control commission. The city council reserves the right to limit areas and/or times of consumption of such alcoholic liquors in parks where alcoholic liquors are permitted. Alcoholic beverages may be permitted on museum grounds subject to rules and policies to be established by the city, provided that a licensed and insured caterer shall be used to serve alcohol, and all events shall end by 11:00 p.m. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.06; Ord. No 573, § 1, 5-6-2013 ) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic liquor, ch. 6. 
State Law reference— Authority to prohibit the possession or consumption of alcoholic liquor in public parks, MCL 436.34, MSA 18.1005.  
Sec. 74-102. - Drugs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring in, have in possession or be under the influence of intoxicants, narcotics or other mind-affecting drugs in any park, unless such possession or use is in accordance with a valid prescription. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.07)  
Sec. 74-103. - Disorderly conduct. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any violent, abusive, loud, boisterous, vulgar, lewd, wanton, obscene or otherwise disorderly conduct tending to create a breach of the peace or disturb or annoy others within a park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.08)  
Sec. 74-104. - Nudity. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to appear nude or nearly nude in a park. For the purposes of this section, the term "nude or nearly nude" shall mean when a person appears in such a manner as to expose to view any portion of the pubic area, anus, vulva, or genitals or when a female appears in such manner or attire as to expose to view the portion of the breast referred to as the "areola," "nipple," or a simulation thereof. A person has exposed to view such portions of the anatomy if such portions are naked, uncovered, or less than opaquely covered. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.09)  
Sec. 74-105. - Disturbing the peace. 
It shall be unlawful to use a loudspeaker, public address system or amplifier within a park, except as may be authorized. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.10)  
Sec. 74-106. - Gambling. 
It shall be unlawful to conduct or to participate in any form of gambling, lottery, or game of chance within a park, except as may be permitted by state law. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.11)  
Sec. 74-107. - Fireworks. 
It shall be unlawful to fire, discharge or have in possession any rocket, firecracker, sparkler, torpedo, squib or other fireworks or any substance of an explosive or dangerous nature within a park, except by special permit from the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.12) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 58.  
Sec. 74-108. - Firearms and weapons. 
It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearm, air rifle, airgun, or any other weapon that propels projectiles by any means in a park. However, this section shall not apply to any authorized peace officer while carrying out the duties of his position, nor to any individual who discharges a firearm in lawful self-defense or the lawful defense of another individual. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.13; Ord. No. 553, § 1, 5-17-2010)  
Sec. 74-109. - Peddling, soliciting or advertising. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle or solicit business of any nature whatsoever or distribute any written material of a commercial nature or post unauthorized signs within a park. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.14) 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; peddlers, solicitors and itinerant merchants, ch. 78.  
Sec. 74-110. - Animals. 
(a)  Pets. A pet shall be kept on a leash no greater than six feet in length and under the immediate control of its handler at all times within a park. Pets shall be prohibited in parks or any portion thereof posted against such use. 
(b)  Horses. It shall be unlawful to ride, lead or cause or suffer a horse to be in a park or any portion thereof posted against such use. 
(c)  Other livestock. It shall be unlawful to drive or cause to be driven any other livestock within a park or to allow any animal to run at large within a park without prior written permission of the mayor. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.15) 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 14.  
Sec. 74-111. - Balloons or parachutes. 
It shall be unlawful to ascend or descend in any balloon or parachute within a park without prior written permission of the mayor. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.16)  
Sec. 74-112. - Construction. 
No structure shall be erected, constructed, or maintained above or below ground within a park or upon the waters or ice of any lake, river, pond, stream, or designated wetland within a park by persons other than city employees or agents except on specific permit by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.08.17) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18.  
Sec. 74-113. - Smoking prohibited in Thelma G. Spencer Park. 
(a)  Prohibition. Smoking is prohibited in Thelma G. Spencer Park. 
(b)  Smoking defined. "Smoking" means the burning, inhaling, exhaling, or carrying of any lighted bidi, bong, cigar, cigarette, cigarillo, hookah, kretek, plant, pipe, weed, or other lighted tobacco product or device. For purposes of this section, "smoking" shall also include the use of an e-cigarette, as defined in city Code section 70-401. 
(Ord. No. 601 , § 1, 4-9-2018)  
Secs. 74-114—74-140. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CONSERVATION AREAS 
 
Sec. 74-141. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Conservation area means an area of undeveloped land retaining or being returned to its natural character and influence, without permanent improvements or human habitation, which is managed so as to protect its natural conditions and which: 
(1)  Generally appears to have been affected primarily by the forces of nature, with the imprint of man's work substantially unnoticeable; or 
(2)  Contains ecological, geological, or other features of scientific, educational, scenic, or historical value. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.09.01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 74-142. - Authority to establish. 
The city council may designate conservation areas within parks by resolution, copies of which shall be available for public inspection at the office of the city clerk during normal business hours. Such resolution shall have attached a drawing designating the area of parkland that is a conservation area. Conservation areas shall be posted as such by the department of parks, forestry, and facilities and their borders delineated by posting or other means so as to inform the public that the area is a conservation area. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.09.02)  
Sec. 74-143. - Maintenance. 
Conservation areas shall receive minimal maintenance and for all intents and purposes shall be left in or returned to a natural condition, subject only to the necessary removal of manmade debris and the maintenance of pathways, lands, rivers, streams, watercourses or previously existing easements as required by law or deemed necessary to the public health, safety and welfare. Nature paths, feeder stations, and similar nondisruptive uses shall be acceptable within the designated area. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.09.03)  
Sec. 74-144. - Rules and regulations. 
All conservation areas shall be subject to the park rules and regulations set forth in division 2 of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.09.04)  
Sec. 74-145. - Prohibited and restricted activities. 
(a)  Prohibited activities. There shall be no commercial enterprise, permanent road, temporary road or use of motor vehicles, motorized equipment, or any form of motorized transport within a conservation area, except as may be necessary for maintenance or in emergencies. 
(b)  Bicycles. No bicycles shall be operated within a conservation area. 
(c)  Pets. No pets shall be allowed in a conservation area. 
(d)  Disturbing the peace. It shall be unlawful to use a loudspeaker, public address system, bullhorn or amplifier within a conservation area. 
(Code 1976, § 7-10.09.04)  
Secs. 74-146—74-170. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TRAILWAYS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-171. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Motor vehicle means any power-driven vehicle, sports equipment, motorized device or remote controlled vehicle, whether propelled by means of wheels, tracks, runners, skis, or other means, whether or not eligible for licensing and registration under the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
Trailways land means land owned by the trailways commission, as described in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 74-172. - Purpose. 
The city and other municipalities have established trailways. Certain minimum rules of conduct are necessary for the best interests of the community and citizens and for the preservation of such natural assets as may be located within the trailways. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.01)  
Sec. 74-173. - Controlling provisions. 
This article shall not be deemed to repeal other provisions of the code and whichever provision is most restrictive shall control. A complaint may be brought for a violation of either or both provisions at the discretion of the enforcement officer. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.09)  
Sec. 74-174. - Applicable land. 
(a)  Land owned by trailways commission. This article shall apply to and be in effect for all lands located within the city owned by the trailways commission, which was created by an agreement between the city, the Charter Township of Avon and the Townships of Oakland and Orion dated December 23, 1981. 
(b)  Penn Central railroad right-of-way. Within the city, such lands are described as those lands formerly owned by the Penn Central Railroad and commonly known as the Penn Central Railroad right-of-way, traversing in a northwesterly-southeasterly direction through sections 3, 4, 10, 13, and 14 of the city and which lands have the appearance to persons using the trailways lands as being a trail or former railroad right-of-way because of its setting or relationship with other properties or are arranged, delineated or posted in some way as to cause a person thereon to be aware that he is on trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.03)  
Sec. 74-175. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Officers. This article shall be enforceable by any deputy sheriff of the county sheriff's department or any state police officer. 
(b)  Issuance of appearance citations. Such officers shall have the authority to issue and serve appearance citations pursuant to MCL 764.9f. 
(c)  Appointment of limited duty officer. In addition, the city council may appoint a limited duty officer who shall have authority to issue parking violation notices and complaints for vehicles illegally parked, as provided in article IV of chapter 98. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.04)  
Secs. 74-176—74-200. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RULES AND REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Ordinance regulating trailway, violation as municipal civil infraction, MCL 117.4m. 
 
Sec. 74-201. - Activities requiring permission of trailways commission. 
The following activities on trailways require written permission of the trailways commission: 
(1)  Hours. No person shall enter into or occupy any area of the trailways land when it is closed except by written permission of the trailways commission. All areas shall be deemed to be closed between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  Natural features. No person shall dig for, remove, injure or destroy any tree, flower, shrub, plant or growing thing or any wild bird or animal or any earth, rock or other material within the boundaries of the trailways land without written permission from the trailways commission. 
(3)  Sales. No person shall sell or offer for sale any article, privilege or service within the trailways land without a written permit from the trailways commission. 
(4)  Advertising. No person shall display, distribute or place any sign, advertisement, circular, notice, or statement or display any banner within the trailways land without a written permit from the trailways commission. 
(5)  Groups. No person shall promote, arrange for, or participate in any function occurring within the trailways land and involving more than 35 persons without a written permit from the trailways commission. The commission may impose such conditions upon the issuance of such permit as it deems necessary to maintain the public use of the trail, to prevent damage to the trail or any part thereof, and to protect the public safety. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-13.05.01, 7-13.05.06—7-13.05.09)  
Sec. 74-202. - Closed area. 
No person shall enter or occupy any portion of the trailways land that has been designated closed to public use or entry. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.05.02)  
Sec. 74-203. - Animals. 
(a)  Horses. No person shall ride or lead a horse within the boundaries of the trailways land except in designated areas. 
(b)  Dogs and other animals running at large. No person shall allow a dog or other animal to run at large on the trailways land. Any person with a dog or other animal on trailways land shall, at all times, maintain control of the dog or animal and keep it held securely on a leash of suitable strength and length. 
(c)  Sanitary disposal of animal waste. It shall be unlawful for any person in control of a horse, dog, or other animal within the boundaries of trailways land to fail to pick up and remove from the improved surface of the trailway such animal's feces, manure, or solid waste. However, any person in control of a horse, dog, or other animal within the boundaries of trailways land may pick up and remove from the improved surface of the trailway such animal's feces, manure, or solid waste and dispose of it in an unimproved portion of trailways land. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-13.05.04, 7-13.06.08(A)) 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 14.  
Sec. 74-204. - Littering. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall drop, throw, or otherwise scatter any material, object, or substance on the trailways land and not retrieve or pick up such material, object or substance. 
(b)  Inflammable materials. No person shall drop, throw, or otherwise scatter lighted matches, lighted cigarettes, lighted tobacco paper, other sources of fire, or combustible or inflammable material in the trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.08) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 86.  
Sec. 74-205. - Disposal of trash. 
Except in receptacles provided for the purpose of disposal, no person shall deposit or abandon in or on any lands or water areas within the trailways land any garbage, glass, trash, waste, sewage or other obnoxious or polluting material. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.05.05) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 86.  
Sec. 74-206. - Trespass to adjacent lands. 
No person shall go onto land adjacent to trailways land which is in private ownership, without the expressed permission of the owner of the land. The person going onto any such land shall be the owner or a member of the family of the owner or shall carry in his possession written permission allowing entry onto the private land, signed by the owner. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.05.10)  
Sec. 74-207. - Damage to property. 
No person shall injure, deface, disturb, befoul, change or remove any portion of any marker, structure, equipment, fence or any other property within the trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.01)  
Sec. 74-208. - Obstruction of persons. 
No person shall locate or deposit any bicycle, equipment or material upon the trailways land or loiter, sit or lie upon the trailways land so as to obstruct persons in their use of the trail. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.02)  
Sec. 74-209. - Disorderly conduct. 
No person shall engage in any drunken, loud, boisterous, or disorderly or indecent conduct, nor shall any person or group of persons engage in any activity which shall endanger or annoy other persons or disturb the peace or good order within the boundaries of the trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.03)  
Sec. 74-210. - Noise. 
No person shall operate or play any musical instrument, radio, mechanical record player or tape player or sound amplifying equipment of any kind within the boundaries of the trailways land in such a manner as to create excessive noise that disturbs or annoys others. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.04) 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46.  
Sec. 74-211. - Camping. 
No person shall camp or establish temporary lodging places within the boundaries of the trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.05)  
Sec. 74-212. - Fires. 
No person shall start or maintain a fire within the boundaries of the trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.06) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 58.  
Sec. 74-213. - Hunting and weapons. 
No person shall hunt or discharge any firearm or weapon, including but not limited to a bow or BB gun, within the trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.07)  
Sec. 74-214. - Alcoholic liquors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring in, have in possession, or use alcoholic liquors within the trailways land. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.06.09) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic liquor, ch. 6.  
Secs. 74-215—74-240. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
 
Sec. 74-241. - Operation. 
No person shall drive, propel or park a motor vehicle or motorized sports equipment of any nature upon the trailways land except motor vehicles used by authorized law enforcement or maintenance personnel and except in areas specifically designated and posted for parking. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.05.03)  
Sec. 74-242. - Illegal parking. 
(a)  Citation or impoundment. Any motor vehicle or equipment which is parked in violation of this division may be issued a citation for the violation, or may be towed away and impounded as provided in section 74-243, or both, in the discretion of the enforcement officer. 
(b)  Presumption of violation. 
(1)  Registered owner. In the prosecution for a violation of parking a motor vehicle in violation of this division, proof that the particular motor vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of this article, together with proof, by verifying ownership of the motor vehicle with the secretary of state, that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of the violation the registered owner of the vehicle shall create in evidence a presumption that the registered owner of the motor vehicle was the person who parked or placed the motor vehicle at the point where and for the time during which the violation occurred. 
(2)  Lessee. If it appears that the motor vehicle was at the time of the violation leased, proof that the defendant named in the complaint was the lessee of the motor vehicle at the time of the violation shall create in evidence a presumption that the lessee of the motor vehicle, not the registered owner, was the person who parked or placed the motor vehicle at the point for the time during which the violation occurred. 
(c)  Violations. 
(1)  Civil infractions. All violations of this division pertaining to the parking of motor vehicles are declared to be civil infractions as provided for in the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq.) and article IV of chapter 98 of this Code. 
(2)  Authority. Authority is granted for issuance of parking violation notices or appearance citations, the procedure after issuance, fines to be assessed, and all other provisions relating to violations of parking sections of this division in accordance with and pursuant to article IV of chapter 98 of this Code, which article is incorporated in this section by reference. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.07)  
Sec. 74-243. - Towing. 
(a)  Authority granted. The county sheriff's department is authorized to remove and tow away or to have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service any motor vehicle parked in violation of this division, which violation is declared to be a nuisance. 
(b)  Impounding. Motor vehicles so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored in a safe place. 
(c)  Payment of fine and charges. Motor vehicles so towed away for illegal parking shall be restored to the owner or operator of such motor vehicle upon payment of the fine as provided in article IV of chapter 98 and the reasonable towing and storage charges. 
(Code 1976, § 7-13.08)  
Chapter 78 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; peddling, soliciting or advertising in parks, § 74-109; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 94. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 78-1—78-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CHARITABLE, RELIGIOUS AND POLITICAL SOLICITATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Public safety solicitation act, MCL 14.301 et seq., MSA 3.240(31) et seq.; charitable organizations and solicitations act, MCL 400.271 et seq., MSA 3.240(1) et seq.; home solicitation sales, MCL 445.111 et seq., MSA 19.416(201) et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charitable, religious or political organization means a not-for-profit charitable, religious, political, benevolent, educational, philanthropic, humane, patriotic, eleemosynary or civic organization of persons which solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the public for charitable, religious or political purposes. 
Nonresident means a person who resides in a place other than in the city; an organization that has not established and does not maintain an office within the city. 
Person means any individual, firm, copartnership, corporation, company, association or joint stock association, church, religious sect, religious denomination, society, organization or league, political party or organization, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, agent or other similar representative thereof. 
Resident means a person residing within the city; an organization that has established and maintains an office within the city. 
Solicit, solicitation and soliciting mean the request of money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value by personal interview or otherwise on the plea or representation, other than by telephone, that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value or any part thereof will be used for a charitable, religious, political, benevolent, educational, philanthropic, humane, patriotic, eleemosynary or civic purpose. The terms also mean and include the sale or offer to sell any article, tag, ticket, emblem, publication, advertisement, subscription, or other thing, whether of value or not, on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value or any part thereof, whether received by the solicitor or purchased by the buyer, will be used for a charitable, religious, political, benevolent, educational, philanthropic, humane, patriotic, eleemosynary or civic purpose. 
Solicitor means a person who or an organization that solicits. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Charitable organization, defined, MCL 400.272, MSA 3.240(2).  
Sec. 78-27. - Purpose. 
To prevent fraud, crime, undue annoyance and harassment and to protect the privacy, safety, health and welfare of the citizens of the city, all nonresident persons and organizations soliciting for charitable, religious and political purposes shall register with the city, and all such persons and organizations, resident and nonresident, shall be subject to the regulations set forth in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.01)  
Secs. 78-28—78-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE 
 
Sec. 78-56. - Required. 
Prior to solicitation in the city, a nonresident charitable, religious or political organization or person who solicits or intends to solicit or receives or intends to receive contributions from persons in the city shall register and be issued a certificate of registration from the city clerk. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.03.01)  
Sec. 78-57. - Exemptions. 
The following are exempt from this division: 
(1)  An organization's own members. The solicitation for charitable, religious and political purposes by an organization from its members. 
(2)  On an organization's own premises. The solicitation of funds for charitable, religious and political purposes by a person or organization when such solicitation occurs on premises owned or in lawful possession of the person or organization soliciting funds or with the permission of the person or organization who owns or is in lawful possession of the premises. 
(3)  Announcements. The issuance of any announcement or advertisement that such solicitation as described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section will occur or which announces or advertises an event at which unannounced solicitation as described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section occurs. 
(4)  Telephone and mail. Telephone and mail solicitations. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.06)  
Sec. 78-58. - Information. 
Registration by a nonresident person or organization under this division shall be with the city clerk on forms to be furnished by the clerk. The registration shall contain the following information or in lieu thereof a statement of the reason why such information cannot be furnished: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number and headquarters of the person registering. 
(2)  If the registrant is not an individual, the names and addresses of the registrant and the principal officers and managers. 
(3)  The purposes for which such solicitation is to be made and the use or disposition to be made of any receipts therefrom. 
(4)  The names and addresses of the person who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitations. 
(5)  An outline of the method to be used in conducting the solicitations. 
(6)  The time when such solicitation shall be made, giving the proposed dates for the beginning and ending of such solicitations and the hours of the days thereof. 
(7)  Where and when the organization was established, the form of its organization, and its tax exempt status under the Internal Revenue Code, if any. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.03.02)  
Sec. 78-59. - Issuance; fee. 
The city clerk shall issue a certificate of registration upon the filing of the registration form as set forth in section 78-58. No fee shall be charged in connection with the registration or the certificate of registration. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.03.03)  
Sec. 78-60. - Content. 
The certificate of registration issued under this division shall bear the name and address of the person by whom the solicitation is made, the date issued, the dates within which the registrant will be soliciting, and a statement that the certificate does not constitute an endorsement by the city of the purpose of the solicitation or of the person or group conducting the solicitation. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.03.04)  
Sec. 78-61. - Transferability. 
Any certificate of registration issued under this division shall be nontransferable; provided, however, each solicitor and representative of an organization which has registered shall carry a facsimile copy of such registration while engaged in solicitation. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.03.05)  
Sec. 78-62. - Misrepresentation of endorsement by city. 
No person shall represent that the granting of a certificate of registration under this division is an endorsement by the city of the particular organization involved, and any such representation is declared to be a misrepresentation of fact and subject to the provisions for revocation of the certificate. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.03.06)  
Secs. 78-63—78-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OPERATING REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 78-91. - Registration information. 
(a)  Changes. While a certificate of registration issued pursuant to division 2 of this article is in effect, a soliciting person or organization shall, within three calendar days, report to the city clerk in writing any material change in any information previously provided on the registration form. 
(b)  False statements. No person shall knowingly file or cause to be filed a registration form containing one or more false statements. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.04.01)  
Sec. 78-92. - Proof carried and shown on demand. 
Under this article, a solicitor shall carry on his person at all times while soliciting either a certificate of registration, if a nonresident solicitor, or proof of residency within the city, if a resident of the city, and shall show the certificate or proof whenever requested to do so by a person solicited or by a city representative. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.04.02)  
Sec. 78-93. - Hours. 
Under this article, no door-to-door solicitation on private property shall be permitted between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., except by invitees. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.04.03)  
Sec. 78-94. - Time limit. 
Under this article, no solicitation by an individual or organization pursuant to this article shall exceed 30 days in any calendar year. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.04.04)  
Sec. 78-95. - Obstructing traffic. 
Under this article, a solicitor shall not block, obstruct, impede or otherwise interfere with the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic upon a public highway, street, alley or sidewalk or within public buildings and other public areas within the city by means of a barricade, object or device or with his person. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.05.01) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98.  
Sec. 78-96. - Interfering with public. 
Under this article, a solicitor shall not, without permission, accost, interfere with, or touch any member of the public in any manner. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.05.02)  
Sec. 78-97. - Noise. 
Under this article, a solicitor shall not unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of the city, and to this end solicitors shall not shout or cry out their solicitation or use any device or means of amplification to draw attention to the solicitation. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.05.03) 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46.  
Sec. 78-98. - Misrepresentation. 
Under this article, a solicitor shall not make any fraudulent or misleading representations to any person in connection with any solicitation pursuant to this article, including but not limited to any misleading representation concerning the true name and nature of the soliciting organization, the purposes for which the soliciting organization was organized, and the purposes for which contributions solicited will be used. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.05.04)  
Sec. 78-99. - Posted property. 
Under this article, no door-to-door solicitations or solicitations on private property shall be permitted at any time where a "No Solicitors," "No Trespassing" or similar notice is posted, except by invitees. A member of an organization is presumed to be an invitee of other members of that organization. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.05.05)  
Sec. 78-100. - Request to leave. 
Under this article, no solicitor shall remain on private property after having been directed to quit the premises by any person lawfully in possession of the premises. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.05.06)  
Sec. 78-101. - Request to cease. 
If any person being solicited pursuant to this article indicates in any manner a desire that the solicitation cease, the solicitor shall immediately and peacefully cease the solicitation. 
(Code 1976, § 3-11.05.07)  
Secs. 78-102—78-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ITINERANT MERCHANTS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Veterans exempt from payment of fee for peddler's license, MCL 35.441 et seq., MSA 4.1241 et seq.; licensing and regulation of transient merchants, MCL 445.371 et seq., MSA 19.691 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Itinerant merchant means any person traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or other conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck farm products or provisions, offering and exposing such for sale or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who takes or attempts to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, books or magazines, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. Any person who solicits, orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as part of an itinerant merchant scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article shall be deemed an itinerant merchant. The term "itinerant merchant" shall include the terms "peddler," "hawker," "huckster" and "canvasser." The term "peddler" shall not include agents of utility companies or firms franchised by referendum of the city electorate or agents of such firms governed by franchise ordinance enacted by the city council following an affirmative advisory vote on the question by the electorate. 
Parent organization means the person or organization that the transient or itinerant merchant is employed by or represents, the principal manufacturer and distributor of goods and the principal provider of services being sold or for which solicited. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-132. - Purpose. 
To prevent fraud, crime, undue annoyance and harassment and to protect the privacy, safety, health and welfare of the citizens of the city, all transient or itinerant merchants, commercial solicitors, peddlers and hawkers shall be licensed by the city and subject to the regulations set forth in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.01)  
Sec. 78-133. - Exempt persons. 
(a)  Subject to other sections only. The following shall be exempt from the licensing, registration and fee requirements of this article but shall be subject to the other sections of this article: 
(1)  Farmers or truck gardeners selling or offering for sale any products grown, raised or produced by them on the same parcel of land or land within the city, which are licensed under chapter 138, the sale of which is not otherwise prohibited or regulated. 
(2)  Newspaper delivery service. 
(b)  Nonprofit solicitations. Nonprofit, charitable, political and religious solicitations shall be exempt from this article. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.06)  
Secs. 78-134—78-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 78-161. - Required. 
No person shall engage in the business of an itinerant merchant in the city without first obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.01)  
Sec. 78-162. - Application. 
Before the issuance of a license required by this division, an itinerant merchant shall apply for a license upon forms prescribed and furnished by the city clerk. The application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name of the individual who will sell or solicit within the city, including resident address, telephone number, driver's license number and a physical description including height, weight, color of hair and eyes. 
(2)  The complete name, address and telephone number of the parent organization and where and when the parent organization was established or incorporated and the form of its organization. 
(3)  An outline of the method to be used in conducting the sales or solicitations (for example, door to door, street corners, sidewalks, etc.). 
(4)  The dates and times when and location where sales or solicitations will be made, giving the proposed dates for the beginning and ending of such sales or solicitations and the hours of the days thereof. 
(5)  The types of goods or services to be sold or for which solicitations will be made. 
(6)  Whether the parent organization or the itinerant merchant has ever been enjoined from soliciting. 
(7)  Whether the itinerant merchant or an officer or director of the parent organization has been convicted of a felony or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, and if so, a brief description and explanation of the reason therefor. 
(8)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. 
(9)  Such other information as the clerk may require relating to the identity and background of the applicant and the proposed solicitation or sales activity. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.02; Ord. No. 576, § 1, 6-10-2013 )  
Sec. 78-163. - Basis for issuance. 
The city clerk shall issue a license required under this division whenever the clerk shall find the following facts to exist: 
(1)  There are no facts to cause a reasonable belief that the activities of the applicant will not become an annoyance or a nuisance to the citizens of the city. Such activities shall inure to the benefit of the citizenry of the city. 
(2)  The applicant has not been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(3)  There has been compliance with this article, including payment of the applicable fee. 
(4)  There have been no violations of this article in the past, which would form a basis of a reasonable belief of further violations of this article. 
(5)  Criminal background check has been conducted through the Internet Criminal History Access Tool (ICHAT). 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.03; Ord. No. 576, § 2, 6-10-2013 )  
Sec. 78-164. - Fee; undue burden. 
The fee for a license required by this division shall be in the amount as provided in section 54-501, per individual, covered by the license. No fee for a license shall be so applied as to occasion an undue burden upon interstate commerce. In any case, where a license fee is believed by a licensee or applicant for a license to place an undue burden upon interstate commerce, he may apply to the city clerk who shall refer the application to the city council to consider making an adjustment of the fee so that it shall not be discriminatory, unreasonable, or unfair as to such commerce. Such application may be made before, at or within six months after payment of the prescribed license fee. The applicant shall, by affidavit and supporting testimony, show the method of business and gross volume or estimated gross volume of business and such other information as the clerk may deem necessary in order to determine the extent, if any, of such undue burden on such commerce. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.06)  
Sec. 78-165. - Content. 
A license issued under this division shall bear the name, address and photograph of the itinerant merchant; the date issued; the dates within which the license holder may solicit; and a statement that the license does not constitute an endorsement by the city of the purpose or products involved or of the persons or parent organization conducting the solicitation. All licenses shall be signed by the city clerk. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.05)  
Sec. 78-166. - Duration. 
A license issued under this division shall be issued for a period of 90 days. If additional time is needed, the applicant may reapply. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.07; Ord. No. 576, § 3, 6-10-2013 )  
Sec. 78-167. - Transferability. 
Any license issued under this division shall be nontransferable. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.09)  
Sec. 78-168. - Misrepresentation of endorsement by city. 
No person shall represent that the granting of a license under this division is an endorsement by the city, and any such representation is declared to be a misrepresentation of fact, a violation of this article and subject to revocation of the license. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.10)  
Sec. 78-169. - Appeal on denial. 
Whenever the city clerk shall decide not to issue a license pursuant to this division, the applicant may appeal in writing to the city council, which shall make the final determination. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.04)  
Sec. 78-170. - Revocation. 
Under this article, if any licensee or any agent or representative of the licensee is misrepresenting or making untrue statements with regard to the solicitation or has made untrue statements in the application or in any other way the solicitation is being conducted in a manner inimical to the protection of the public health, safety or welfare of the citizens of the city or in violation of any of the sections of this article or of any state statute or any other section of this Code or city ordinance or is representing in any way that any license granted under this division is an endorsement of such solicitation, the city clerk shall suspend the license or revoke the license and shall cause notice thereof to be mailed to the licensee, who shall have a right of appeal and hearing by the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.11)  
Sec. 78-171. - Ice cream vendor license. 
In addition to an itinerant merchant permit under section 78-164, ice cream vendors shall obtain an annual ice cream vendor license for each ice cream vending vehicle to be used in the city. Prior to the issuance of an annual license for ice cream vendors, the city building department and sheriff's department shall inspect each ice cream vending vehicle to determine whether it is roadworthy and complies with applicable state laws and city ordinances. An annual license decal will be affixed to the vehicle by the inspector upon successful completion of the inspection and payment of the annual license fee. The inspector will report the results of the inspection to the city clerk's office. Inspections will be performed during normal business hours by appointment. 
(Ord. No. 552, § 2, 5-3-2010)  
Secs. 78-172—78-195. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OPERATING REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 78-196. - License application information. 
(a)  Changes. While a license issued pursuant to division 2 of this article is in effect, an itinerant merchant shall, within seven calendar days, report to the city clerk in writing any material change in any information previously provided on the application form. 
(b)  False statements. It shall be a violation of this article for any person knowingly to file or to cause to be filed an application for a license containing one or more false statements. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.04.01)  
Sec. 78-197. - Inferred endorsement by city. 
A license issued under division 2 of this article shall not be used or represented in any manner as an endorsement by the city or by any department, officer or employee thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.04.02)  
Sec. 78-198. - Hours. 
Under this article, door-to-door sales or solicitations or sales or solicitations on private property shall be permitted between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. while daylight savings time is in effect and between 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. when daylight savings time is not in effect. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.04.03; Ord. No. 576, § 4, 6-10-2013 )  
Sec. 78-199. - License display. 
Every solicitor registered hereunder shall carry and display his or her city-issued license at all times while engaged in solicitation, upon a lanyard or in a manner such that the photograph and information is readily, continuously and clearly visible and unobstructed. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.03.08; Ord. No. 576, § 5, 6-10-2013 ) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 576, § 5, adopted June 10, 2013, retitled § 78-199 from "License display on request" to "License display."  
Sec. 78-200. - Obstructing traffic. 
Under this article, an itinerant merchant shall not block, obstruct, impede or otherwise interfere with the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic upon a public highway, street, alley or sidewalk or within public buildings and other public areas within the city by means of a barricade, object or device, or with his person. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.01) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98.  
Sec. 78-201. - Interfering with public. 
Under this article, an itinerant merchant shall not, without permission, accost, interfere with, or touch any member of the public in any manner. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.02)  
Sec. 78-202. - Noise. 
Under this article, an itinerant merchant shall not unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of the city, and to this end itinerant merchants shall not shout or cry out their solicitation or blow any horn or utilize any amplification system or use any device to attract the attention of the public, except there may be a ringing of a bell, unamplified, so long as it does not unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.03) 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46.  
Sec. 78-203. - Misrepresentation. 
No fraudulent or misleading representations to any person shall be made in connection with any sale or solicitation under this article, including but not limited to any misleading representation concerning the true product or service involved, the name of the transient or itinerant merchant, the trade name and the nature of the parent organization. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.04)  
Sec. 78-204. - Posted property. 
Under this article, no door-to-door sales or solicitations or sales or solicitations on private property shall be permitted at any time where a "no solicitors," "no trespassing" or similar notice is posted, except by invitees. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.05)  
Sec. 78-205. - Request to leave. 
Under this article, no itinerant merchant shall remain on private property after having been directed to quit the premises by any person lawfully in possession of the premises. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.06)  
Sec. 78-206. - Fixed stands on public property. 
Under this article, no licensee shall stop or remain in any one place upon any public right-of-way, alley or public place longer than necessary to make a sale to a customer wishing to buy. Any itinerant merchant using a vehicle, when stopped, shall stop or park his vehicle parallel to and within 12 inches of the edge of the roadway, shall utilize emergency flashing lights, and shall depart from such place as soon as he has completed sales with customers actually present. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.07)  
Sec. 78-207. - Peddling on public or commercial property. 
Under this article, no itinerant merchant shall engage in: 
(1)  Peddling on any public right-of-way, alley or public place after having been requested to desist by any sheriff's deputy because of congested or dangerous traffic conditions. 
(2)  Business on any state trunk line highway within the city. 
(3)  Business in a commercially zoned district outside of any building. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.08)  
Sec. 78-208. - Curb service. 
(a)  On or near highways. Under this article, no itinerant merchant shall operate or maintain any stand, vehicle, store or place of business on or near to any highway in such manner that the customers or traders with such person occupy or congregate within the limits of any street, lane, highway, or public place within the city. 
(b)  Public places, rights-of-way, alleys, etc. No person shall be permitted to use the public rights-of-way, alleys, lanes or public places of the city for the service of customers or for the transaction of business or to use any stands, stores or other places of business in any manner that shall require the customer, when transacting business, to stand within the limits of the public right-of-way, highway, alley or public place of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10.05.09)  
Chapter 79 - SPECIAL EVENTS 
 
Sec. 79-1. - Purpose. 
The regulations promulgated herein are in order to promote the health, safety and welfare of residents and visitors in the City of Rochester Hills by ensuring that special events held at commercially-zoned property do not create disturbances or nuisances, threaten or endanger persons or property, cause traffic problems, or burden public services. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-01), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 79-2. - Definition. 
Special event means, for purposes of this chapter, a carnival, circus, show, attraction or exhibit, or the temporary display or sale, whether for profit, non-profit or charitable, of goods, products, wares, merchandise, services or material, that is held, staged or conducted in open air or at a stand, tent or temporary structure outside of a completely enclosed building or an approved permanent outdoor sales area on non-residential property. "Special event" shall include, but not be limited to, carnivals, circuses, shows, amusement rides, arts and crafts exhibits and fairs, flea markets, rummage sales and similar temporary activities or events conducted, sponsored or authorized by the owner, tenants or occupants of the subject property. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-02), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 79-3. - Permit requirement. 
No person shall hold, stage or conduct a special event without first obtaining a permit from the City of Rochester Hills Building Department. The building official or his/her designee is authorized to approve special event permits. In addition, other permits may be required including, where applicable: 
(1)  Permit from the Oakland County Health Department shall be obtained for all temporary sanitary, water and food service facilities. However, no permit shall be required where only pre-packaged, ready-to-eat type foods are sold from a concession stand or booth. 
(2)  Street occupancy permit from Rochester Hills Engineering Department for blocked public streets, pathways or sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-03), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 79-4. - Exception. 
This article shall not apply to the display or sale by a business of merchant goods or services when placed or located directly in front of the business (but not in any parking/maneuvering/fire lane) and in accordance with local building, fire codes and zoning regulations. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-04), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 79-5. - Application. 
Any person desiring to obtain a special event permit shall complete and submit an application with the City of Rochester Hills Building Department for each event accompanied by the required fee. Permit applications must be submitted at least 14 calendar days prior to event and include all of the following information: 
(1)  Written permission from the property owner (if other than applicant). 
(2)  Three copies of a site plan (8½" x 11" preferred) describing and depicting: 
a.  Location of event activities; 
b.  Temporary structures or tents and their size; 
c.  Location and type of merchandise; 
d.  Any/type of food to be served; 
e.  Location and type of sanitary facilities; 
f.  Temporary electrical use and lighting (may require separate permit); and 
g.  Trash receptacles. 
(3)  Certificate of insurance with the city name as certificate holder for public liability insurance in the amount of $500,000.00, combined single limit coverage, for injuries to person and property and umbrella liability coverage in the amount of $1,000,000.00. No cancellation of material change in insurance may occur without 30 days written notice to the city. 
(4)  Description of activities including the following information: 
a.  Dates and hours of the event (hours are restricted to 7:00 a.m.—9:00 p.m.); 
b.  Types of activities proposed; 
c.  Anticipated number of participants; and 
d.  Any activities that may cause unusual noise, danger or safety concerns. 
(5)  If a temporary tent, canopy or other structure 200 square feet or more with sides or 400 square feet or more without sides are proposed, the following information must be provided: 
a.  Site plan (three sets) indicating the size and location and proximity between the tent/structure and all buildings, parking lots and streets (include on site plan); 
b.  Floor plan with interior layout showing seating, tables, aisles and exits with dimensions; 
c.  Fastening details; 
d.  The proposed occupant load of the structures; 
e.  Fire Resistance Certificate of Flame Spread documentation for tent/canopy fabric; 
f.  Parking lot protection for pedestrians; 
g.  Indicate if tent will have open or closed sides; 
h.  Indicate location and type of heating and electrical equipment; and 
i.  Number and location of fire extinguishers. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-05), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 79-6. - Permit issuance. 
(a)  Approval. A permit application shall be approved if the building department determines the special event will not interfere with public health, safety and welfare, create a disturbance or nuisance, threaten or endanger persons or property, create a traffic problem or violate other applicable ordinances or regulations. 
(b)  Conditions. The building department may attach reasonable conditions to the permit designed to ensure the objectives of this chapter are met. 
(c)  Duration. Permits shall be effective for up to 30 days. A person may hold up to three such events per calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-06), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 79-7. - Fees. 
Application, plan review, permit and inspection fees for tenant and building owners shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  Application fee ..... $100.00 
(2)  Plan review, permit and inspection fee ..... 50.00 
Application, plan review, permit and inspection fees for all others shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  Application fee ..... $100.00 
(2)  Plan review fee (building and fire departments) ..... 170.00 
(3)  Permit fee: 
a.  1—10 days ..... 170.00 
b.  11—20 days ..... 255.00 
c.  21—30 days ..... 340.00 
(4)  Fire department inspection fee ..... 85.00 
(5)  After-hours inspection fees will be charged for building department and fire department inspections at an overtime or double-time rate, as appropriate, with a four-hour minimum. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-07), 7-26-2010; Ord. No. 596 , § 1, 3-27-2017)  
Sec. 79-8. - Signs. 
Temporary signs when displayed during the approved times of the event shall be permitted without additional fees or permits. Temporary signs shall be limited to one per road frontage, 25 square feet in area and not be located in any public right-of-way. Ground signs are limited to seven feet in overall height; wall signs are limited to 20 feet in overall height. No roof-mounted displays, balloons or signs are permitted. Signs may not be located in any parking, fire lane or area interfering with public activity outside the event area. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-08), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 79-9. - Permit revocation. 
A violation of or failure to comply with any provision of this chapter or any permit condition, or the making of any false, inaccurate or misleading statement in the permit application is grounds for the immediate revocation of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 556, § 1(79-09), 7-26-2010)  
Chapter 82 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes:

Editor's note— Ord. No. 517, § 1, adopted Jan. 10, 2007, amended ch. 82 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 82, §§ 82-26—82-130, pertained to similar matter. See the Code Comparative Table for full derivation. 
Cross reference— Regulations pertaining to personnel saved from repeal, § 1-7(a)(13); administration, ch. 2; ethics, ch. 50. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 82-1—82-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EMPLOYEE APPEAL PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 82-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Day means a week day—Monday through Friday—except holidays. 
Employee means all persons who are regular, full-time employees, except those specifically excluded in section 82-29 or otherwise indicated by the context of the use of the word. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-27. - Purpose. 
An employee appeal procedure is available to all regular, full-time employees to provide recourse to them if their city employment is adversely affected as described in this article. The purpose of this procedure is to assist the city in attracting and maintaining employees of ability and character, and thus increase the efficiency of city government by granting to these employees the right to obtain a hearing and present their position to a personnel board, as defined in this article, which is authorized to make a final decision regarding their city employment. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-28. - Right to repeal or amend. 
The City of Rochester Hills specifically reserves the right to amend this article in whole or in part, at one or more times hereafter, or to repeal this article; provided, however, that the rights of an employee who has initiated an appeal in accordance with the provisions below shall not be abrogated by such amendment or repeal. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-29. - Employees excluded. 
The following employees are specifically excluded from this article: 
(1)  Elected officials . The mayor, members of the city council and other elected officials. 
(2)  Appointed officials . The city clerk, deputy city clerk, city treasurer, deputy city treasurer, assistant to the mayor, city administrator, city attorney, city planning consultant, city auditor, city assessor, and members of boards and commissions. 
(3)  Members of collective bargaining units . Employees who are members of any organization that has been certified or legally recognized as a collective bargaining agent for any group of employees, and that negotiates wages, hours and conditions of employment with the city pursuant to Public Act No. 336 of 1947 (MCL 423.201 et seq.). 
(4)  Temporary and part-time employees . Employees who are hired to work a limited length of time (temporary employees) and employees who are regularly scheduled to work fewer than 40 hours per week (part-time employees). 
(5)  Paid-on-call firefighters . Individuals employed by the city to provide emergency service on an intermittent, as-needed basis, under the direction of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-30. - Personnel board. 
(a)  Composition . The personnel board shall consist of three members, appointed as follows: 
(1)  Employees' appointment . The regular, full-time employees of the city shall appoint one member of the personnel board to serve a term ending December 31 of the second year following the appointment; provided, however, should a majority of these employees be unable to agree on an appointee, a secret ballot election shall be held under the control of the city clerk, who shall be solely responsible for the conduct and certification of such election. If the employees' appointee is employed in the same city department as the employee appealing under this article, an alternate must be chosen by the employees to hear the matter. No employee assigned to the city's human resources department may be a member of the personnel board. 
(2)  City council appointment . The city council shall appoint one member of the personnel board to serve a term ending as of December 31 of the second year following the appointment. 
(3)  Third member appointment . 
a.  By two board members. The two members so appointed shall mutually appoint a third member of the personnel board when there is a matter to be heard as is provided for by this article. Upon mutual agreement by the two members, the same third member may be appointed to hear more than one matter. 
b.  By American Arbitration Association. If the two members are unable to agree upon the selection of a third member within five days of an appeal from an employee, a third member shall be selected according to the rules for expedited hearing promulgated by the American Arbitration Association. 
c.  Compensation. The third member shall be compensated a reasonable fee, and such cost may be assessed against the city and/or the employee, in the discretion of the personnel board. 
(b)  Vacancy appointment . Any appointment to the personnel board to fill a vacancy due to a member's death, discharge, resignation or retirement shall be made only for the remainder of the unexpired term for which the former member had been appointed. 
(c)  Authority of employees' appointee . The personnel board member appointed by the employees shall sit on the board and hear matters presented pursuant to this article. Such member shall not have any authority to represent the employees, other than is specifically provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-31. - Employee coverage status. 
All regular, full-time employees employed by the city shall be excluded from the coverage and sections of this article until these employees have successfully completed a probationary period of six consecutive months of employment in a covered position, or such longer probationary period as extended by the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-32. - Dismissal, suspension or demotion. 
(a)  Actions affecting employment. An employee covered by this article may be dismissed, suspended, or demoted by the city for good and sufficient cause. 
(b)  Appeal to personnel board. Such employee may, within ten days after presentation to him of written confirmation of such action affecting his employment, appeal the action to the personnel board. 
(c)  Hearing by personnel board. The board shall, within two weeks from the date of filing such appeal, commence hearings thereon and shall thereupon hear and determine the matter and either affirm, modify or revoke the action affecting the employee's employment. The employee shall be entitled to appear personally, produce evidence, have counsel and have a public hearing, if the employee so desires. The findings and decisions of the personnel board shall be final and shall be promptly delivered to the employee and to the city. 
(d)  Benefits continued. Benefits such as health, dental, life insurance and disability benefits shall be continued for the employee by the city during an appeal from a suspension or dismissal until such time as a decision is rendered by the personnel board. 
(e)  Compensation. If a dismissed employee is reinstated or a suspension without pay is reversed or reduced, the personnel board shall decide, in its discretion, whether the employee shall receive full, partial or no compensation for such time as the suspension or dismissal was in effect. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-33. - Suspensions. 
(a)  Without pay. An employee covered by this article may be suspended without pay for reasons relating to the employee's performance of job duties. An employee suspended without pay may request a hearing before the personnel board if the suspension is for more than ten working days or, if indefinite, after the tenth working day of the suspension. 
(b)  With pay. An employee may be suspended with pay indefinitely immediately upon the occurrence of an event for the purpose of investigation or when the best interests of the city require. An employee who is suspended with pay may appeal any such suspension after the 30th calendar day of the suspension. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-34. - Nondiscrimination. 
A person entitled to the benefits of a hearing by the personnel board under this article shall not be in any way favored or discriminated against because of race, sex, age, religion, or other reasons proscribed by law or because of political opinions or affiliations. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Secs. 82-35—82-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EMPLOYEE PENSION PLAN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Investment of assets of public employee retirement systems, MCL 38.1132 et seq; municipal employees retirement act of 1984 MCL 38.1502a et seq. 
 
Sec. 82-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Full-time employee means an employee subject to completion of a probationary period of at least six months, or as may be extended by the city, who is regularly employed for 40 hours or more per week, or as otherwise designated in the plan document and who receives city-recognized fringe benefits available to full-time employees. 
(ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-62. - Purpose. 
A pension plan for the mayor, city council, and eligible employees of the city, as originally adopted and established by Ordinance No. 65, effective November 1, 1974, shall be continued. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-63. - Continuation. 
(a)  Plan continued. The city continues its pension plan for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits for its mayor, city council, and eligible employees. 
(b)  Contracts authorized. The city also authorizes the mayor and the city clerk to undertake all steps necessary for the continuation of the pension plan, including the following: 
(1)  Enter contracts. Entering into a contract, in the name of the city and/or the pension plan, with the approval of the city council, with any company or persons authorized to transact such business within the state; or 
(2)  Establish trust fund. Establishing an independent trust fund to be administered by an investment fiduciary, as defined by Public Act No. 314 of 1965 (MCL 38.1132 et seq.), who may be either an employee of the city or an independent contractor. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-64. - Coverage, vesting and contributions. 
(a)  Plan controls. The requirements set forth in the pension plan documents shall control the coverage, vesting, contributions and other aspects of the pension plan. 
(b)  Plan amendment. The pension plan may, from time to time, be modified or changed by a resolution duly adopted by the city council or by collective bargaining agreement approved by city council. Any changes to the pension plan must comply with the conditions of Public Act 728 of 2001, as amended. Unless otherwise specifically provided, any amendment of the pension plan will apply to individuals employed by the city on and after the effective date of the amendment. The pension rights of an individual whose city employment terminated before the effective date of the amendment will be governed by the provisions of the pension plan in effect on the date the individual last terminated employment. 
(c)  Trustee administration. The pension plan is intended and has been administered to be a qualified pension plan under subsection 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. The trustee of the pension plan may adopt such additional provisions of the pension plan as are necessary to fulfill this intent. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-65. - Ratification of existing plan. 
The city ratifies and confirms the validity of any pension plan in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives and ratifies and confirms all official actions previously taken in connection with such plans. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Secs. 82-66—82-95. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - EMPLOYEE GROUP INSURANCE PLANS 
 
Sec. 82-96. - Purpose. 
Group insurance plans covering life, health, hospitalization, medical and surgical service and expense and disability insurance for certain classes of city officers and employees and their dependents shall be created and established as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-97. - Established. 
(a)  Plans created. The city creates and establishes group insurance plans covering life, health, hospitalization, medical and surgical service and expense, and disability insurance for its officers and employees enumerated in this article and their dependents. 
(b)  Contracts authorized. For the purposes described in subsection (a) of this section, the city also authorizes the mayor and the city clerk to contract, in the name of the city subject to approval of the city council, with any company authorized to transact such business within the state for such group insurance policies. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-98. - Coverage. 
(a)  Health, hospitalization, and medical. The group insurance plan or plans for health and hospitalization, and medical services shall cover persons within the following classes of officers and employees and shall also cover the dependents of such persons, as the policies of insurance allow and provide: 
(1)  Mayor, city clerk and city treasurer. 
(2)  All city employees who are employed 30 hours or more per week on a regular basis. 
(3)  Retired city employees who qualify under city policies and/or collective bargaining agreements. 
(4)  As otherwise determined by the city. 
(b)  Life insurance. The group life insurance plan created, established and contracted for under this article shall cover each person within the following classes of officers and employees: 
(1)  Mayor, city clerk and city treasurer. 
(2)  All city employees who are employed for more than 30 hours per week on a regular basis. 
(3)  As otherwise determined by the city. 
(c)  Disability insurance. The group disability insurance plan created, established and contracted for under this article shall cover each person within the following classes of officers and employees: 
(1)  Mayor, city clerk and city treasurer. 
(2)  All city employees who are employed for more than 30 hours per week on a regular basis. 
(3)  As otherwise determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-99. - Premium contributions. 
The city shall annually contribute and pay premiums or charges arising under the insurance plans provided for in this article for each person within the classes of persons enumerated in section 82-98 as required by city policies and/or collective bargaining agreements. Such city contribution shall be secured from the appropriate fund (in proportion to the percent of salary earned from the fund), as the case may be, of the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-100. - Ratification of existing insurance plans. 
The city ratifies and confirms the validity of any life, health, hospitalization, medical and surgical, and disability insurance or any one or more of such forms of insurance in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives and ratifies and confirms all official actions previously taken in connection with such plans and/or policies. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Secs. 82-101—82-125. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - EMPLOYEE DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN AND TRUST 
 
Sec. 82-126. - Purpose. 
A deferred compensation plan and trust for the benefit of employees of the city shall be continued for the purpose of attracting and retaining competent employees and assisting them to provide for their retirement security. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-127. - Deferred compensation plan. 
(a)  Plan continued. The city hereby continues its deferred compensation plan for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits for its eligible employees. 
(b)  Authorization of contracts. The city authorizes the mayor and city clerk, subject to city council approval, to enter a contract or contracts to provide deferred compensation benefits for eligible city employees. Contracts shall only be entered with a company licensed and/or authorized to provide deferred compensation plans in the State of Michigan. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-128. - Coverage. 
(a)  Eligibility. All full-time and part-time city employees shall be eligible to participate in the plan established by this article upon their commencement of employment with the city. 
(b)  Participants. City employees may elect to participate in the plan by entering into an individual agreement conforming to the plan. Any employee so electing shall be designated as a participant. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)  
Sec. 82-129. - Loan program implementation. 
The city may offer a loan program as part of any deferred compensation plan it offers to its eligible employees. If a loan plan is offered, it shall be governed by the conditions and requirements set forth in the plan documents. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 1-10-2007)
