Pipeline means all parts of those physical facilities through which oil, gas, other hydrocarbons, hazardous liquids, fresh water, salt water, or chemicals are transported, including but not limited to, pipe, valves, other appurtenance attached to pipe, and ancillary equipment such as pigging stations and compressors, whether or not laid in public or private easement or public or private right-of-way in the city, and also including but not limited to, flow lines, gathering lines, production lines and transmission lines. This definition does not include pipelines associated with franchise utilities. 
Pipeline construction means the initiation of any excavation or other disturbance of property for the purpose of installation, construction, maintenance, repair, replacement, modification or removal of a pipeline. 
Pipeline emergency means a pipeline incident that is required to be reported to the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality, or any other federal, state or local regulatory agency, and/or which may endanger the health, safety or welfare of persons or property. 
Pipeline operator means any person owning, operating or responsible for operating a pipeline. 
Residential area means any area in the city zoned or used for single or multi-family residential use. 
Well site means the physical location where an oil or gas well is drilled. 
Wellhead means the assemblage of equipment attached to the opening of an oil or gas well. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-201. - City regulated pipelines—Permit required. 
(a)  City regulated pipelines shall adhere to all standards outlined in section 94-202. Federal and state statutory or regulatory requirements shall apply to pipelines between the well and/or wellhead and the point of custody transfer. Prior to the transport of gas, oil, liquids or hydrocarbons, the pipeline operator shall provide to the city certification from a registered professional engineer that the design and installation of the pipelines meet all state and federal requirements. 
(b)  Prior to pipeline construction and the issuance of notice required in subsection 94-202(d) of this article, a pipeline operator shall obtain a pipeline permit from the city engineer for all city regulated pipelines. An exception to this permitting is construction necessary to respond to a pipeline emergency. 
(c)  At the same time the pipeline operator submits an oil or gas well drilling permit application to the state pursuant to Part 615 of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, MCL 324.61501 et seq., and the administrative rules promulgated thereunder, the pipeline operator shall submit to the city a proposed pipeline route from the well bore, wellhead and/or well site to the transmission line, for all city regulated pipelines. 
(d)  The pipeline operator shall be required to submit an application for a pipeline permit to the city and obtain a pipeline permit prior to making any offer or initiating any negotiation or action to acquire any easement or other property right to construct, install, maintain, repair, replace, modify, remove or operate a pipeline in residential areas. Prior to commencing pipeline construction, the pipeline operator shall provide to the city a copy of any easements obtained. A condition of the permit is that the pipeline operator shall relocate the pipeline at its sole cost as directed and in the sole discretion of the city. 
(e)  Review and approval by the city council for all proposed pipelines through residential areas shall be required prior to the issuance of a permit for the commencement of pipeline construction. 
(f)  A pipeline permit application shall be required as follows: 
(1)  Applications for a city regulated pipeline or other activities regulated by this subsection shall be submitted to the city in a form prescribed by the city. 
(2)  Plans submitted with each application for a pipeline permit shall be in a format approved by the city showing the dimensions and locations of the pipeline and related items or facilities, as well as all proposed lift stations, pumps or other service structures related to such pipeline and the location, type and size of all existing utilities, drainage, right-of-way and roadway improvements. The plans must additionally show the elevation and location of all known public utilities within 15 feet of the centerline of the proposed pipeline. Any application that fails to meet these requirements will be returned unfiled to the applicant. 
(3)  The following information shall be provided in the application: 
a.  The name, business addresses and telephone numbers of the pipeline operator; 
b.  The names, titles and telephone numbers of the following: 
1.  The person signing the application on behalf of the pipeline operator; 
2.  The person designated as the principal contact for the submittal; and 
3.  The person(s), located within Oakland County, Michigan, designated as the 24-hour emergency contact. 
c.  The origin point and the destination of the proposed subject pipeline; 
d.  A text description of the general location of the proposed subject pipeline; 
e.  A description of the substance to be transported through the proposed subject pipeline; 
f.  A copy of the GHS (globally harmonized system) safety data sheet; 
g.  Engineering plans, drawings and/or maps with summarized specifications showing the horizontal location, covering depths and location of shutoff valves of the proposed subject pipeline. To the extent that information can be obtained, drawings shall show the location of other pipelines and utilities that will be crossed or paralleled within 15 feet of the proposed subject pipeline right-of-way; 
h.  A description of the consideration given to matters of public safety and the avoidance, as far as practicable, of existing habitable structures and private residential areas; 
i.  Detailed cross section drawings for all public street right-of-way and easement crossings; 
j.  The proposed method or methods to be used for the installation of the pipeline; 
k.  Methods to be used to prevent both internal and external corrosion; 
l.  A binder or certificates of all bonds and insurance; and 
m.  A proposed alignment strip map showing name and address of all affected and adjacent property owners. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-202. - General regulations. 
(a)  As determined in the sole, but reasonable, discretion of the city, pipelines shall not interfere with or damage existing utilities, including but not limited to: water, sewer or gas lines, storm drains, electric lines, telecommunications, public lighting, traffic control devices or equipment, or the facilities of any public utilities located in public rights-of-way, utility easements or other city-owned property or in residential areas. 
(b)  The pipeline operator shall backfill all trenches and compact such trenches to 95 percent standard density proctor in eight-inch lifts and construct the pipeline so as to maintain a minimum depth of ten feet below the finished grade except in public rights-of-way, where minimum cover to the top of the pipe shall be at the discretion of the city based on existing or planned utilities. During the backfill of any pipeline excavations in open cut sections, the pipeline operator shall bury a magnetic buried pipeline warning tape one foot above any such pipeline to warn future excavators of the presence of a buried pipeline. The city may also require that a proposed or existing pipeline be relocated at the sole cost of the pipeline operator should it conflict with the proposed alignment and depth of a gravity dependent utility. 
(c)  The pipeline operator shall equip all city regulated pipelines with an automated pressure monitoring system that detects leaks and shuts off any line or any section of line that develops a leak. 
(d)  The pipeline operator shall be responsible to grade, level and restore the property affected by pipeline construction to the same surface condition, as nearly practicable, as existed before operations were first commenced. 
(e)  The pipeline operator shall construct, repair and/or maintain all pipelines so as to meet or exceed the applicable minimum criteria established by the statutory or regulatory requirements of the state and federal governments for such pipeline. 
(f)  At least 20 days prior to the commencement of any pipeline construction, the pipeline operator shall give written notification to all persons to whom real property is assessed within 300 feet of the proposed pipeline and to the occupants of all structures within 300 feet of the proposed pipeline. 
(g)  The pipeline operator shall provide the city the following information, including GPS (global positioning system) information sufficient to locate the pipelines in the future, including the beginning and end points of the pipeline and sufficient points in between the pipeline route and the depth of cover information. This information shall be submitted to the city in a format compatible with the city's own GIS (geographic information system) system. 
(1)  As-built or record drawings of the pipelines. Accuracy of the record drawings shall meet a survey level of one foot to 50,000 feet. The scale of the record drawings shall be a minimum of one inch to 40 feet. The drawings shall also be supplied in a DFF (digital file format) with the location tied to at least one nearby GPS city monument. If the new pipeline length exceeds 1,000 feet within the city, the pipeline shall be tied to at least two GPS city monuments; 
(2)  The origin point and the destination of the pipeline; 
(3)  The substance to be transported; 
(4)  A copy of the GHS safety data sheet; 
(5)  Engineering plans, drawings and/or maps with summarized specifications showing the horizontal location, covering depths, and location of shutoff valves of the subject pipeline. Drawings shall show the location of other pipelines and utilities that are crossed or paralleled within 15 feet of the pipeline right-of-way; 
(6)  Detailed cross-section drawings for all public rights-of-way and easement crossings on city property as permitted by the city; and 
(7)  A list of the names and mailing addresses of all the property owners, residents and tenants adjacent to the pipeline construction. 
(h)  A pipeline operator that transports gas, oil, liquids or hydrocarbons through a pipeline located in the city shall be a member in good standing with the Miss Dig System or other approved excavation monitoring system as required by state law. The pipeline operator that transports gas, oil, liquids or hydrocarbons through a pipeline shall contract for service with the selected underground utility coordinating system for a minimum of five years unless there is an agreement to change to an alternate system between the city and the pipeline operator. The pipeline operator shall maintain such services without interruption for the life of the pipeline permit and as required under this section. 
(i)  At the time of permitting and each year thereafter that the pipeline remains active, each pipeline operator shall provide to the mayor, city engineer, fire chief and Oakland County Sheriff the names, mailing and email addresses and telephone numbers of at least two primary persons, officers or contacts who will be available on a 24-hour basis and at least two alternative persons, officers or contacts to be reached in the event that the primary contacts are unavailable who: 
(1)  Can initiate appropriate actions to respond to an emergency; 
(2)  Have access to information on the location of the closest shutoff valve to any specific point in the city; and 
(3)  Can furnish the common name of the material then being carried by the pipeline. 
Any change in the above information must be provided to the city by contacting the gas inspector prior to such change. 
(j)  Each pipeline operator shall file a copy of all initial or follow-up reports provided to state or federal agencies about unsafe pipeline conditions, pipeline emergencies, pipeline releases, pipeline safety violations or pipeline incidents in the city concurrently with the city. 
(k)  A city regulated pipeline shall not be located closer than 1,000 feet from a residential dwelling, place of worship, school, child care center or public park. A city regulated pipeline for purposes of this subsection does not include those pipes which are part of the well and regulated by the State of Michigan. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-203. - City engineer review. 
After the filing of an administratively complete application, the city engineer shall review all applications. If deemed necessary by the city, a third-party technical consultant may be engaged by the city. The costs associated with the consultant shall be borne by the pipeline operator. Any decision by the city engineer is final. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-204. - Abandoned pipelines. 
(a)  All pipelines shall be maintained in an active condition unless abandoned according to applicable state and federal regulations. The pipeline operator shall notify the city of abandonment of any pipeline. 
(b)  Reactivation of abandoned pipelines shall require notification to the city and a new permit pursuant to the standards and requirements of this article at the time of the new permit application. Reactivation shall require pressure testing for integrity and compliance with state and federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-205. - Emergency response plans and emergency incident reporting. 
(a)  Each pipeline operator shall maintain written procedures to minimize the hazards resulting from an emergency. The pipeline operator must provide a copy of the written procedures to the city prior to commencement of pipeline construction. These procedures shall at a minimum provide for the following: 
(1)  Prompt and effective response to emergencies including, but not limited to the following: 
a.  Leaks or releases that can impact public health, safety or welfare; 
b.  Fire or explosions at or in the vicinity of a pipeline or pipeline easement; 
c.  Natural disaster; 
d.  Effective procedures and protocols to notify and communicate required and pertinent information to local fire, police, public officials and affected residents during an emergency; 
e.  The availability of personnel, equipment, tools and materials as necessary at the scene of an emergency; 
f.  Measures to be taken to reduce public exposure to injury and probability of accidental death or dismemberment; 
g.  Emergency shut down and pressure reduction of a pipeline; 
h.  The safe restoration of service following an emergency or incident; and 
i.  A follow-up incident investigation to determine the cause of the incident and require the implementation of corrective measures. 
(b)  Upon discovery of a pipeline emergency or incident, any affected pipeline operator shall immediately communicate to the 911 system the following information: 
(1)  A general description of the emergency or incident; 
(2)  The location of the emergency or incident; 
(3)  The name and telephone number of the person reporting the emergency or incident; 
(4)  The name of the pipeline operator; 
(5)  Whether or not any hazardous material is involved and identification of the hazardous material so involved; and 
(6)  Any other information as requested by the emergency dispatcher or other such official at the time of reporting the emergency or incident. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-206. - Protection and painting of structures. 
A pipeline operator shall keep protected and painted all pipeline risers and all appurtenances related to pipeline construction and operations which are composed of materials which are generally protected or painted. Such operator shall repaint all such items at sufficiently frequent intervals to maintain same in good condition. It shall be a violation of this article for any pipeline operator to permit any pipeline riser and/or appurtenances related to pipeline construction and operations to be in a state of disrepair or to have chipped, peeling or unpainted portions. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-207. - Markers. 
It is the joint and several responsibility of the owner and the pipeline operator of any and all pipeline to maintain markers in accordance with this article. The location of all new or replacement pipe and pipelines shall be marked by the owner(s) thereof or by the person installing or operating such pipelines as follows: 
(1)  Marker signs shall be placed at all locations where pipe or pipelines cross property boundary lines and at each side of a public street or road right-of-way which the pipe or pipeline crosses; 
(2)  The top of all marker signs shall be a minimum of four feet above ground level, and the support post must be sufficient to support the marker sign and shall be painted yellow or such other color as may be approved by the city engineer or his designee; 
(3)  All marker signs shall be a minimum of 12 inches square and shall be marked as "Gas Pipe Line;" 
(4)  All marker signs shall contain the name of the owner and operator of the pipeline and a 24-hour local contact number; 
(5)  Pipelines shall be marked along their entire length with a buried magnetic metal wire and metallic flag tape; 
(6)  All signs shall also contain a "Call Before You Dig" statement; and 
(7)  The pipeline operator shall annually replace signage that has been lost, damaged or removed. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-208. - Performance guarantee. 
Prior to issuance of a pipeline permit, the pipeline operator shall provide to the city, and thereafter keep in force, a cash or surety bond or irrevocable bank letter of credit acceptable to the city as a performance guarantee that the pipeline operator will comply with the provisions of this article. The city shall be authorized to draw upon the cash or surety bond or irrevocable bank letter of credit to recover the cost of correcting or remedying any default or violation by the pipeline operator of any provision of this article, including but not limited to, the cost of repair and replacement of any property damaged or destroyed as a result of the construction of the pipeline or a pipeline emergency. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-209. - No implied grant of use of public rights-of-way, utility easements or other city owned property. 
Nothing in this section grants permission for the use of any street, public rights-of-way, utility easements, or city owned property. In the event a pipeline operator wishes to undertake any pipeline construction on, over, under, along, or across any public rights-of-way, utility easements or other city owned property, the pipeline operator shall apply for and execute a written agreement with the city governing the terms and conditions for such use; obtain all required permits; and comply with any other applicable provisions of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-210. - Expiration of pipeline permit. 
If construction of a pipeline has not commenced within one year of the date of issuance of the pipeline permit, or if the pipeline has not been completed and the surface restored within two years, the pipeline permit shall expire; provided, however, that the city engineer may grant an extension of time not to exceed an additional one year if the city engineer determines weather or other unforeseen conditions justify such an extension. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 94-211. - No assumption of responsibility by city; hold harmless. 
Nothing in this section shall be construed as an assumption by the city of any responsibility of a pipeline operator of a pipeline not owned by the city. Further, by accepting a permit under this article, the pipeline operator agrees to hold harmless the city from any claims or causes of action which arise out of the construction or operation of the pipeline. 
(Ord. No. 589 , § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Secs. 94-212—94-235. - Reserved.  
Chapter 98 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations, including through streets, speed limits, one-way traffic, limitations on load of vehicles or loading zones saved from repeal, § 1-7(a)(10); authorized emergency vehicles and equipment, § 58-90; driving over fire hoses, § 58-92; offenses, ch. 70; motor-driven vehicles in parks, § 74-63; bicycles in parks, § 74-64; motor vehicles on trailways, § 74-241 et seq.; obstructing traffic by charitable solicitors, § 78-95; obstructing traffic by itinerant merchants, § 78-200; refuse transporting unit license, § 86-56 et seq.; operating requirements for licensed refuse transporters, § 86-91 et seq.; operating requirements for licensed waste haulers, § 86-226 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 94; nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths and sidewalks, § 94-76 et seq.; traffic interference by signs, § 134-110; B-5 automotive service business districts, § 138-656 et seq.; parking and storage of commercial and recreational vehicles and equipment and junked vehicles, § 138-1141 et seq.; off-street parking and loading, § 138-1266 et seq. 
State Law reference— Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.; regulation by local authorities, MCL 257.605, 257.606, 257.610, MSA 9.2305, 9.2306, 9.2310. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 98-1—98-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC AND SAFETY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Mayor to approve administrative rules and regulations of all boards and commission, § 8.3.10. 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-141 et seq. 
 
Sec. 98-26. - Purpose. 
A traffic and safety board shall be established for the city to study and recommend traffic and safety measures and programs to enhance traffic safety within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.01)  
Sec. 98-27. - Established. 
The traffic and safety board for the city is established, pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.02)  
Sec. 98-28. - Scope of authority. 
The traffic and safety board shall be a nonadministrative board serving solely in an advisory capacity. The board may make recommendations to the city council but may not assume any legislative nor administrative authority of the city council, the mayor or any city department. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.03)  
Sec. 98-29. - Composition and tenure. 
(a)  Generally. The traffic and safety board shall consist of seven voting members and two nonvoting ex officio members. The voting members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by the city council. 
(b)  Voting members. All board members shall be electors of the city. Four of the voting members shall reside in and be appointed to represent each of the four voting districts under the Charter. The other three members may represent the interests of the two school districts situated within the city and of the business community. 
(c)  Terms of office. The voting members shall be appointed to three-year terms expiring on June 30 of the year of expiration. 
(d)  Ex officio members. The two ex officio members shall be the city traffic engineer and a member of the city council appointed by the city council. 
(e)  Vacancies. Any vacancies shall be filled as provided in this section for appointments for the expiration of the term of office for which the appointment is made. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.04) 
Charter reference— Appointment to boards and commissions not established by state law shall be in accordance with the ordinance or resolution of the council providing for such appointments, § 8.7.5.  
Sec. 98-30. - Officers. 
(a)  Chairperson and vice-chairperson. The traffic and safety board shall, from its appointed members, elect a chairperson who shall be the presiding officer of the board and a vice-chairperson who shall serve as presiding officer of the board in the absence of the chairperson. 
(b)  Secretary. A secretary, who shall keep and maintain the proceedings of the board, shall be appointed by the board. The secretary need not be a member of the board. 
(c)  Terms of office. The terms of office for such officers shall be one year and until their successors have been elected. 
(d)  Ex officio members excluded. An ex officio member of the board shall not act as the chairperson or vice-chairperson but may serve as secretary. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.05)  
Sec. 98-31. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular. The traffic and safety board shall hold at least one regular meeting each month at such time and place as may be established by the board. 
(b)  Special. Special meetings may be called by the secretary at the written request of the chairperson or any three members of the board on at least two days' notice. 
(c)  Quorum. A quorum for the transaction of business at the regular and special meetings shall be four appointed members and at least one ex officio member. 
(d)  Open to public. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.06)  
Sec. 98-32. - Compensation. 
Voting members of the traffic and safety board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.07) 
Charter reference— Compensation for members of boards and commissions, § 8.8.  
Sec. 98-33. - Objectives. 
(a)  Resolving traffic problems. The traffic and safety board shall review and evaluate traffic problems that exist, anticipate those that may occur and recommend to the city council corrective measures or programs to resolve the problems. 
(b)  Endeavoring to decrease accidents. In addition, the board shall endeavor to serve the city by planning, conducting, promoting and assisting activities designed to decrease the number, severity and cost of accidents in the community. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.08)  
Sec. 98-34. - Duties. 
In carrying out its objectives, the traffic and safety board may: 
(1)  Safe traffic and safety promotion. Receive and review questions having to do with traffic and safety matters and make recommendations to the city council where action is deemed necessary to promote safe and efficient movement of traffic. 
(2)  Traffic condition improvement. Recommend to the city council ways and means for improving traffic conditions. 
(3)  Effective street usage. Recommend and monitor programs that will encourage and help to create the most effective use of existing streets. 
(4)  Street and intersection improvement. Review methods to improve streets and intersections. 
(5)  Sign or signal effectiveness improvement. Review the adequacy or effectiveness of existing or requested traffic signs, markings and signals. 
(6)  Accident cause review and prevention. Review causes of accidents and recommend how they can be prevented. 
(7)  Safety education. Conduct and promote safety education of the public by all available means for the purpose of obtaining remedial and preventative action. 
(8)  Volunteer coordination. Provide a means for voluntary coordination of planning and executing projects by the many groups interested in traffic and safety problems. 
(9)  Agency jurisdiction coordination. Establish communication and encourage coordination between governmental agencies having jurisdiction over streets in the city. 
(10)  Council or planning commission support. Pass upon all matters referred to it by the city council or planning commission and give the city council or planning commission the benefit of its judgment with relation to such matters so referred. 
(Code 1976, § 2-08.09)  
Secs. 98-35—98-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MICHIGAN VEHICLE CODE 
 
Sec. 98-61. - Adoption by reference. 
The Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 through 257.923, as amended and as may be amended in the future, is adopted by reference. Section 625(1)(c) of the Michigan Vehicle Code, being MCL 257.625(1)(c), is specifically adopted by reference in accordance with 2012 PA 7. 
(Ord. No. 458, § 1, 2-23-2000; Ord. No. 492, § 1, 8-4-2004; Ord. No. 495, § 1, 5-4-2005; Ord. No. 567, § 1, 4-2-2012)  
Sec. 98-62. - Reference to local authorities. 
References in the Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authorities" shall mean the city. 
(Ord. No. 458, § 1, 2-23-2000; Ord. No. 567, § 1, 4-2-2012)  
Sec. 98-63. - Publication of notice. 
The city clerk shall publish this article in the manner required by law and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the Michigan Vehicle Code and the fact that a complete copy of the code is available to the public at the clerk's office for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 458, § 1, 2-23-2000; Ord. No. 567, § 1, 4-2-2012)  
Sec. 98-64. - Penalties. 
The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are adopted by reference; provided, however, that the city may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment exceeds 93 days. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a violation of Section 625(1)(c) of the Michigan Vehicle Code is punishable by one or more of the following: 
(1)  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
(2)  Imprisonment for not more than 180 days. 
(3)  A fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $700.00. 
(Ord. No. 458, § 1, 2-23-2000; Ord. No. 567, § 1, 4-2-2012)  
Secs. 98-65—98-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate standing or parking of vehicles, MCL 257.606(1)(a), MSA 9.2306, (1)(a). 
 
Sec. 98-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Parking violation means a notice, other than an appearance citation, directing a person to appear at the city parking violations bureau and to pay the fine and costs, if any, prescribed by the Michigan Vehicle Code or this Code for parking, stopping, or standing of a motor vehicle in violation of the Michigan Vehicle Code or this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 7-11.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 98-102. - Parking violations bureau. 
(a)  Established. A parking violations bureau, authorized by section 8395 of Public Act No. 236 of 1961 (MCL 600.8395, MSA 27A.8395), is established. 
(b)  Designated office. The office of the city treasurer shall be the parking violations bureau, which office shall be authorized to accept civil infraction admissions in parking violations cases and to collect and retain civil fines and costs as prescribed by this article. 
(c)  Operating expense. The expense of operating the parking violations bureau shall be borne by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-11.03) 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Authority to establish parking violations bureaus, MCL 600.9395, MSA 27A.9395.  
Sec. 98-103. - Parking violations. 
(a)  Civil infractions. All parking violations provided for in the Michigan Vehicle Code as adopted by the city, with modifications, and in any chapter of this Code shall be civil infractions as defined and provided for in sections 6a and 907 of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.6a, 257.907, MSA 9.1806(1), 9.2607). A violation of a parking regulation of the city shall be processed in the same manner as a civil infraction under the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.). 
(b)  Persons authorized to issue. Persons authorized to issue parking violations shall be the following: 
(1)  A deputy sheriff of the county sheriff's department, a state police officer and a limited duty officer, authorized by the mayor, shall have authority to and may issue a parking violation notice. 
(2)  The mayor may appoint a limited duty officer to issue parking violation notices and otherwise comply with the requirements of this article. 
(c)  Service of notice and presumption. In a civil infraction action involving the parking, stopping, or standing of a motor vehicle, a copy of the notice of parking violation need not be served personally upon the defendant, but may be served upon the registered owner by attaching a copy to the vehicle. 
(d)  Payment of fine. If the parking violation fine is paid to the parking violations bureau, the city treasurer shall accept the fine and deposit the monies to the city's general fund or fire fund as the city council may determine. 
(Code 1976, § 7-11.04)  
Sec. 98-104. - Uniform traffic citation or complaint. 
(a)  Failure to pay fine. If the parking violation fine is not paid by the date indicated on the parking violation notice, the parking violations bureau shall return the notice to the officer who issued the violation, requesting the officer to: 
(1)  Verify the vehicle's ownership with the secretary of state; 
(2)  Obtain the registered owner's name and address from the secretary of state; 
(3)  File with the district court a uniform traffic citation, properly filled out, or a sworn complaint which contains the allegations stated in the parking violation notice and fairly informs the defendant how to respond. 
A copy of the citation or complaint, whichever is utilized, shall be mailed to the registered owner of the vehicle at his last known address. 
(b)  Persons authorized to issue. A uniform traffic citation may be issued by a deputy sheriff, state police officer or any other person authorized by this article, in lieu of a parking violation notice. 
(c)  Processing. Whenever a uniform traffic citation or a sworn complaint, as provided for in subsection (a)(3) of this section, is filed with the district court, the violation shall be processed in the same manner as a citation issued personally to the defendant, pursuant to subsections (1) and (2) of section 742 of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.742, MSA 9.2442). 
(Code 1976, § 7-11.05)  
Sec. 98-105. - Parking fines. 
(a)  Schedule. The schedule of fines payable to the parking violations bureau for parking violations shall be as follows: 
(1)  Parking within 500 feet of fire apparatus ..... $ 40.00 
(2)  Parking in front of fire hydrant ..... 40.00 
(3)  Parking in front of fire stations ..... 40.00 
(4)  Parking in posted fire lane ..... 40.00 
(5)  Blocking fire department connection ..... 40.00 
(6)  Blocking crosswalk, sidewalk, alley, drive or traffic ..... 40.00 
(7)  Double parking ..... 40.00 
(8)  Improper parking ..... 40.00 
(9)  Parking over 24 hours ..... 40.00 
(10)  Prohibited parking ..... 40.00 
(11)  Prohibited parking, handicapped ..... 100.00 
(12)  Parking in violation of winter weather emergency ..... 40.00 
(13)  Other violation ..... 40.00 
(b)  Other fines under Michigan Vehicle Code or this Code. All parking violations that are paid to or settled with the city parking violations bureau shall be as provided in this section, unless another fine is specifically provided for in the Michigan Vehicle Code or another section of this Code, which other provisions shall prevail over what is set forth in this section. 
(c)  Unpaid or unsettled parking violations under Michigan Vehicle Code. If the parking violation is not settled or paid to the city parking violations bureau as provided in this article before it is reported to the district court, the fine and costs for the civil infraction shall be as is provided in section 907 of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.907, MSA 9.2607). 
(d)  Other procedures. All other procedures provided by the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code shall apply. 
(Code 1976, § 7-11.06; Ord. No. 428, § 1, 12-3-1997)  
Sec. 98-106. - Handicapped parking spaces. 
In accordance with section 942a of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.942a, MSA 9.2642(1)), the owner and the lessee, in the case of a leasehold, of all public and private property having parking facilities available to the public shall set aside sufficient number of parking spaces according to the requirements and specifications for handicapped parking spaces as contained in section 315.3 of the state construction code and shall comply with the signage requirements for the handicapped parking spaces, as required by state laws. 
(Code 1976, § 7-11.07)  
Sec. 98-107. - Parking on private property. 
(a)  No person shall park any motor vehicle on any private property in the city without the expressed or implied consent, authorization or ratification of the owner, holder, occupant, leasee, agent or trustee of such property. 
(b)  No person shall park any motor vehicle on any private property, with or without consent of the owner, within 100 feet of a street right-of-way for the principal purpose of displaying the vehicle for sale, displaying, advertising, or selling merchandise from such vehicle, except within the defined limits of a duly established new or used automobile dealership or sales lot, which shall not include bike paths adjacent to any automobile dealership or sales lot, or when so authorized or licensed under the ordinance code provisions of the city. 
(Ord. No. 467, § 1, 12-5-2001)  
Sec. 98-108. - Winter weather emergencies. 
(a)  While a winter weather emergency is in effect, no person shall park or leave any vehicle on any city street or portion thereof to which the parking prohibition applies. 
(b)  As used in this section, "street" means the portion of any city street, highway or roadway that is improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, including the shoulder, if any. 
(c)  Whenever the mayor finds, on the basis of snow, sleet or freezing rain accumulation, or on the basis of a forecast by the United States Weather Bureau or other weather service of snow, sleet or freezing rain that weather conditions will make it necessary that motor vehicle traffic be expedited and that parking on city streets be prohibited for snow plowing, de-icing and other purposes, the mayor shall declare a winter weather emergency and put into effect a parking prohibition on all or any portion of city streets as the mayor determines necessary by declaring such emergency as provided in this subsection. 
(d)  Once in effect, a prohibition under this section shall remain in effect until terminated by announcement of the mayor in accordance with this subsection, except that any street which has become substantially clear of snow and ice from curb to curb, or to the edge of the shoulder for streets without curbs, for the length of the entire block shall be automatically excluded therefrom. 
(e)  Whenever a vehicle becomes stalled or disabled for any reason, whether or not in violation of this subsection, on any portion of a city street to which the parking prohibition applies, the person operating the vehicle shall take immediate action to have the vehicle towed or pushed off the street. No person shall abandon or leave their vehicle in a city street (regardless of whether the person indicates, by raising the hood or otherwise, that the vehicle is stalled), except for the purpose of securing assistance during the actual time necessary to go to a nearby telephone or to a nearby garage, automobile service station or other place of assistance and return without delay. 
(f)  (1)  Declaration. The mayor shall cause each declaration of a winter weather emergency made pursuant to this section to be publicly announced, between 6:00 A.M. and 8:00 P.M., by means of broadcasts or telecasts from stations with a normal operating range covering the city, and the mayor may cause such declaration to be further announced in newspapers of general circulation when feasible. Each announcement shall describe the action taken by the mayor, including the time it became or will become effective, and shall specify the streets affected. 
(2)  Time of effect. The parking prohibition resulting from the mayor's winter weather emergency declaration shall go into effect two hours after it has been first announced. 
(3)  Record. The mayor shall make a record of each time and date when any winter weather emergency declaration is announced to the public pursuant to this section. 
(g)  Whenever the mayor shall find that some or all of the conditions which give rise to a winter weather emergency declaration no longer exist, the mayor may declare the winter weather emergency and parking prohibition terminated, in whole or in part, effective immediately upon announcement. 
(h)  Any provision of this section which becomes effective by declaration of the mayor or upon the occurrence of certain weather conditions shall, while temporarily in effect, take precedence over other conflicting city ordinance code provisions normally in effect, except that it shall not take precedence over city ordinance code provisions relating to traffic accidents, emergency travel or authorized emergency vehicles, or emergency traffic directions by a police officer. 
(i)  (1)  Enforcement authority. This section 98-108 shall only be enforceable by the county sheriff's department, who shall have the authority to issue and serve parking violation notices or appearance tickets for violations of this section 98-108. 
(2)  Civil infraction. Any person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(3)  Presumption of responsibility for parking or leaving vehicle. There shall be a rebuttable presumption that the registered owner was the person who parked or left the vehicle in violation of this section. 
(4)  Service of appearance ticket. An appearance ticket for a violation of this section need not be served personally upon the violator, but may be served by attaching a copy to the subject vehicle. 
(5)  Impounding of vehicle. Any vehicle parked or left on any city street in violation of this section may be towed and impounded, and no person may recover any impounded vehicle without first paying the cost of removal and storage, notwithstanding, and apart from, any fine which may also be imposed for violation of this section. The impoundment fee may be waived at the mayor's sole discretion if the person in violation of this section can demonstrate that he or she was taking responsible steps to remove the vehicle from the street. 
(Ord. No. 467, § 1, 12-5-2001)  
Secs. 98-109—98-135. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLES ON SCHOOL PROPERTY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Operation of motor vehicles on school district property, MCL 257.961, MSA 9.2660. 
 
Sec. 98-136. - Purpose. 
The operation, parking, and speed of vehicles on school property shall be regulated as provided in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-05.01)  
Sec. 98-137. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Standing or parking violations. All violations of this article pertaining to standing or parking of vehicles are declared to be civil infractions as provided for in the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.), and article IV of this chapter. The procedure for issuing parking violation notices or appearance citations, the procedure after their issuance, fines to be assessed and all other provisions relating to violations of standing or parking sections of this article shall be in accordance with and pursuant to article IV of this chapter, which article is incorporated in this section by reference. 
(b)  Other violations. For violations other than parking, standing and stopping, this article shall be enforced only by any deputy sheriff of the county sheriff's department or any state police officer. 
(Code 1976, § 7-05.04)  
Sec. 98-138. - Towing. 
(a)  Authority granted. The city police and the county sheriff's department are authorized to remove and tow away or to have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service any car or other vehicle parked in violation of this article where such parked vehicle: 
(1)  Creates or constitutes a traffic hazard. 
(2)  Blocks the use of a fire hydrant. 
(3)  Obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle. 
(b)  Impounding. Cars so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored in a safe place. 
(c)  Payment of fine and charges. Cars so towed away for illegal parking shall be restored to the owner or operator of such car upon payment of the fine as provided in subsection 98-137(a) and the reasonable towing and storage charges. 
(Code 1976, § 7-05.05)  
Sec. 98-139. - Speed limit. 
(a)  Reasonable and proper operation. Any person operating a motor vehicle on property of a board of education in the city shall operate the vehicle at a careful, prudent speed not greater than nor less than is reasonable and proper, having due regard to the traffic, the surface and width of the traffic lane in which the vehicle is traveling and of any other conditions then existing. 
(b)  Ability to stop. In no event shall any such person operate a motor vehicle on such properties at a speed greater than that which will permit him to bring the vehicle to a stop within an assured clear distance ahead. 
(c)  Maximum unposted speed. In no event shall the speed of any vehicle operated on such properties exceed 15 miles per hour, unless otherwise posted. 
(Code 1976, § 7-05.02)  
Sec. 98-140. - Parking. 
(a)  Marking of spaces. The boards of education having jurisdiction in the city shall cause lines or marks to be painted on the surface of the parking areas located on their respective properties within the city to designate the spaces to be used for vehicular parking thereon. 
(b)  Parking across lines. On the property that is so marked, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle across any such lines or marks or to park any vehicle in such a way that the vehicle shall not be within the area so designated by such lines or markings unless such vehicle is too large to be confined in one such space. 
(c)  Prohibited areas. No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle where official signs prohibit parking, standing or stopping, except as follows: 
(1)  As directed by officer. In compliance with the directions of a city police officer or the county sheriff or his deputy at any place upon the property of a board of education. 
(2)  Designated areas. When parking is not adequate for a specific event such as a football game or a baseball game, there may be parking in areas designated by school authorities for additional parking, so long as the additional areas are clearly marked for parking and/or school personnel direct cars to the additional parking areas. 
(d)  Time limit. It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any property of a board of education in the city for a period longer than one hour between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, unless otherwise provided by signs erected and maintained by a board of education giving notice of such exception. However, this prohibition shall not apply to any vehicle which has displayed on its windshield a sticker or emblem issued by the board of education upon whose property the vehicle is parked, giving permission to the operator of the vehicle to park such vehicle for longer periods of time. 
(Code 1976, § 7-05.03)  
Secs. 98-141—98-165. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SHOPPING CENTER PARKING LOTS[5]

Sec. 98-166. - Purpose. 
Traffic in shopping center parking areas shall be regulated as provided in this article, an authorized representative of each of the shopping centers specified in this article having requested in writing this regulation at each of the named shopping centers. 
(Code 1976, § 7-06.01)  
Sec. 98-167. - Traffic control devices and signs. 
(a)  Posting to notify or clarify prohibitions. The chief of police or any other person authorized by the mayor shall cause signs or other traffic control devices required in a parking area to be posted along those areas in front of the buildings or at other specified locations in order to notify the public of the prohibitions as set forth in this article. Signs may be posted in other areas if it appears necessary in order to clarify the prohibitions to the public. 
(b)  Conformance to requirements. A sign or other traffic control device required in a parking area shall conform to the requirements of the state Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(Code 1976, § 7-06.04)  
Sec. 98-168. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Civil infractions. All violations of this article pertaining to standing or parking of vehicles or traffic control are declared to be civil infractions as provided for in the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.), and articles III and IV of this chapter. 
(b)  Procedures relating to violations. The procedure for issuing parking violation notices or appearance citations, the procedure after their issuance, fines to be assessed and all other provisions relating to violations of the standing or parking or traffic control sections of this article shall be in accordance with and pursuant to articles III and IV of this chapter, which articles are incorporated in this section by reference. 
(Code 1976, § 7-06.05)  
Sec. 98-169. - Towing. 
(a)  Authority granted. The city police and the county sheriff's department are authorized to remove and tow away or to have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service any car or other vehicle parked or abandoned in violation of this article where such vehicle: 
(1)  Creates or constitutes a traffic hazard. 
(2)  Blocks the use of a fire hydrant. 
(3)  Obstructs traffic or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle. 
(b)  Impounding. Cars and other vehicles so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored in a safe place. 
(c)  Payment of fines and charges. Cars or other vehicles so towed away for illegal parking shall be released to the owner or operator of such car or other vehicle upon payment of the fine as provided for in section 98-168 and the reasonable towing and storage charges. 
(Code 1976, § 7-06.06)  
Sec. 98-170. - Unlawful standing or parking. 
(a)  Areas designated. At any time, it shall be unlawful for any vehicle to stand or to park in any of the following areas: 
(1)  North Hill Shopping Center. Any marked entrance and/or exit lanes and marked driving aisles in the parking lot of the shopping center commonly known as the North Hill Shopping Center, which is located in the southwest quadrant of the intersection of Rochester Road and Tienken Road. This area shall specifically include the entire area 30 feet from the curb in front of the entire length of the buildings comprising the stores and shops of the North Hill Shopping Center.

The marked entrance and exit lanes and the marked aisles in the parking lot of the shopping center which is commonly known as the Rochester Hills Plaza, which is located north of Walton Boulevard, west of the centerline of Livernois Road approximately 731 feet. This area shall specifically include the area adjoining the buildings in the Rochester Hills Plaza, extending from the curbs in front of the buildings to the area marked for parking spaces. 
(3)  Hampton Plaza Shopping Center. The marked entrance and exit lanes and the marked aisles in the parking lot of the shopping center which is commonly known as the Hampton Plaza, which is located in the southeast quadrant of the intersections of Rochester Road and Hamlin Road. This area shall specifically include the area adjoining the buildings in the Hampton Plaza Shopping Center, extending from the curbs in front of the buildings to the area marked for parking spaces. 
(4)  Campus Corners Shopping Center. The marked entrance and exit lanes and the marked aisles in the parking lot of the shopping center which is commonly known as Campus Corners, which is located in the southeast quadrant of the intersections of Walton Boulevard and Livernois Road. This area shall specifically include the area adjoining the buildings in the Campus Corners Shopping Center, extending from the curbs in front of the buildings to the area marked for parking spaces. 
(5)  Winchester Mall. The marked entrance and exit lanes and the marked aisles in the parking lot of the shopping center which is commonly known as Winchester Mall, which is located in the southwest quadrant of the intersection of Rochester Road and Avon Road. This area shall specifically, but not by way of limitation, include the area adjoining the buildings in the Winchester Mall, extending from the curbs in front of the buildings to the area marked for parking spaces, as well as the area extending from the western edge of the mall parking lot to the area marked for parking spaces, as follows: 
 
Winchester Mall 
(6)  University Square. The marked entrance and exit lanes and the marked aisles in the parking lot of the shopping center which is commonly known as University Square, which is located in the northwest quadrant of the intersection of Walton Boulevard and Adams Road. This area shall specifically, but not by way of limitation, include the area adjoining the building in University Square, extending from the curbs in front of the building to the area marked for parking spaces. 
(7)  Kmart Shopping Center. This area shall specifically include the area adjoining the buildings in the Kmart Shopping Center, extending from the curbs in front of the buildings to the area marked for parking spaces. 
 
K-Mart Center 
(b)  Designated fire lanes. The areas so described in subsection (a) of this section are declared to be fire lanes. 
(c)  Exceptions. Exceptions to this section shall be when necessary in order to avoid conflict with other traffic or to comply with the directions of a peace officer. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-06.02, 7-06.0A, 7-06.0B)  
Sec. 98-171. - Traffic control. 
A person who violates the directions of any of the following traffic control devices is responsible for a violation of this article: 
(1)  Winchester Mall. Any and all stop signs, yield signs, or other traffic control devices erected at entrance and exit locations and intersections in the Winchester Mall parking area, as set forth in section 98-170. 
(2)  University Square. Any and all stop signs or other traffic control devices erected at entrance and exit locations in the University Square parking area. 
(3)  Kmart Shopping Center. Any and all stop signs or other traffic control devices erected at entrance and exit locations in the Kmart Shopping Center, as shown in section 98-170. 
(Code 1976, § 7-06.03)

ARTICLE VII. - MOTORCYCLES AND CERTAIN RECREATIONAL VEHICLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Operation of motorcycles, MCL 257.656 et seq., MSA 9.2356 et seq. 
 
Sec. 98-201. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Michigan Vehicle Code. All definitions that appear in the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.), shall be applicable to such terms when used in this article. 
Motorcycle means: 
(1)  Every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground; and 
(2)  Every vehicle not entitled to be licensed for travel upon the public highways of the state that is designed primarily for recreational purposes, including but not limited to all-terrain vehicles, go-carts, trail bikes or drag bikes. 
The term does not include tractors, motor-powered lawn mowers, special mobile equipment as defined in the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.), or similar vehicles. 
(Code 1976, § 7-08.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Motorcycle, defined, MCL 257.31, MSA 9.1831.  
Sec. 98-202. - Purpose. 
By the adoption of this article, the city council finds and determines the uncontrolled operation of motorcycles, as defined in section 98-201, has become a public nuisance within the city due to loud and raucous noises, noxious odors and excessive dust. They are dangerous to the health and safety of persons within the city, and damage is being caused to property within the city because of the uncontrolled use of such vehicles on private property without the consent of the owners thereof and on public property without the consent of the public bodies having jurisdiction. The city council further finds that this article controlling the use of such vehicles is necessary to prevent nuisance conditions detrimental to the safety, health, and general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1976, § 7-08.01)  
Sec. 98-203. - Operating restrictions. 
(a)  Motor vehicle travel areas. No motorcycle shall be operated upon the city streets and highways or other areas open to public motor vehicle travel except in accordance with the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.). 
(b)  Parking facilities. No motorcycle shall be operated in any area open to the public for the parking of motor vehicles except for the sole purpose of normal ingress and egress into such parking facilities. 
(c)  Public or school property. No motorcycle shall be operated upon property owned by the city or by a public school district, other than areas designated for the parking of motor vehicles, except in accordance with the rules and regulations established for such property by the public body having jurisdiction. 
(d)  Private property. The following shall apply to the use of motorcycles on private property: 
(1)  Trespassing. No motorcycle shall be operated upon any private property in violation of division 2 of article II of chapter 70 pertaining to trespassing. 
(2)  Zoning. No motorcycle shall be operated upon any private property within the city unless such operation is in accordance with a principal use permitted on such property by chapter 138 or is an accessory use normally incidental to a permitted principal use then in existence upon the property. 
(e)  Subdivision streets. No person shall operate a motorcycle on the streets of any subdivision except for the purpose of gaining ingress to or egress from premises located within the subdivision or for through traffic through the subdivision. It is the intention of this subsection to regulate, restrict and minimize the use of subdivision streets for the recreational use of motorcycles. 
(Code 1976, § 7-08.03)  
Sec. 98-204. - Operator restrictions. 
No person shall operate a motorcycle on public or private property: 
(1)  While under the influence of alcoholic liquor or narcotic drugs, barbital or any derivative of barbital; 
(2)  When, due to consumption of alcoholic liquor, narcotic drugs, barbital or any derivative of barbital, he has visibly impaired his ability to operate the vehicle; 
(3)  In willful or wanton disregard for the safety of persons, including himself, or property; 
(4)  In a careless or negligent manner likely to endanger any person or property; 
(5)  In a speed or acceleration contest or for the purpose of making a speed record, whether from a standing start or otherwise over a measured or unmeasured distance; or 
(6)  In a drag race as defined in section 626a of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.626a, MSA 9.2326(1)). 
(Code 1976, § 7-08.04)  
Sec. 98-205. - Excessive, unusual or unnecessary noise. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person shall operate a motorcycle in the city in such a manner as to create excessive, unusual or unnecessary noise. 
(b)  Mandatory equipment. Every motorcycle so operated shall be equipped with an efficient muffler which will ensure noise levels comparable to that of a private passenger automobile. 
(c)  Causes. Causes of excessive, unusual or unnecessary noise shall be as follows: 
(1)  Racing engines. Racing motorcycle engines or repeated acceleration and deceleration of motorcycle engines, except in the course of maintenance of such engines, is deemed to be excessive, unusual and unnecessary noise. 
(2)  Abrupt or violent acceleration. Abrupt or violent acceleration of a motorcycle, including acceleration which causes the front wheel of the motorcycle to lose contact with the ground, shall be deemed to create excessive, unusual, or unnecessary noise. 
(Code 1976, § 7-08.05)  
Secs. 98-206—98-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - OFF-ROAD VEHICLES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Off-road recreation vehicles, MCL 324.81101 et seq., MSA 13A.81101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 98-231. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Off-road vehicle or ORV means a motor-driven off-road recreation vehicle capable of cross-country travel without benefit of a road or trail, on or immediately over land, snow, ice, marsh, swampland or other natural terrain. The term includes but is not limited to a multitrack or multiwheel drive or low pressure tire vehicle, a motorcycle or related two-wheel, three-wheel or four-wheel vehicle, an amphibious machine, a ground-effect or air cushion vehicle, or any other means of transportation deriving motive power from a source other than muscle or wind. The term does not include a registered snowmobile; a farm vehicle being used for farming; a vehicle used for military, fire, emergency, or law enforcement purposes; a vehicle owned and operated by a utility company or an oil or gas company when performing maintenance on its facilities or on property over which it has an easement; a construction or logging vehicle used in performance of its common function; a registered aircraft or motorboat; or a self-propelled lawn mower, snow blower, garden or lawn tractor or golfcart while being used exclusively for their designed purpose. 
(Code 1976, § 7-15.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Off-road vehicle, defined, MCL 324.81101, MSA 13A.81101.  
Sec. 98-232. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city council finds and determines off-road vehicles (ORVs) have become a public nuisance within the city due to loud and raucous noises, reckless and careless operation, noxious odors, excessive dust and other adverse effects upon the natural terrain and environment. 
(b)  They are dangerous to the health, safety and welfare of persons within the city, and damage is being caused to property within the city due to the use of such vehicles on private property without the consent of the property owners and on public property without the consent of the public bodies having jurisdiction. 
(c)  The city council further determines this article restricting the use, operation, setting into motion, transportation, movement, maneuvering or standing of such vehicles is necessary to prevent and eliminate nuisance conditions that are detrimental to the health, safety and general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1976, § 7-15.01)  
Sec. 98-233. - Prohibitions. 
Except as permitted in section 98-234, it shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate, set in motion, transport, move, maneuver or leave standing an off-road vehicle within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 7-15.03)  
Sec. 98-234. - Exceptions. 
The prohibition expressed in section 98-233 shall not apply to the use, operation, setting in motion, transportation, movement, maneuvering or standing of an off-road vehicle: 
(1)  On the frozen surface of public waters or on land owned by or under the control of the state; 
(2)  Which is a vehicle registered under the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.), or part 811 of the natural resources and environmental protection act, Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.81101 et seq., MSA 13A.81101 et seq.), unless the vehicle is operated as an off-road vehicle off highways, roadways or streets; 
(3)  Occurring exclusively during the course of a special event of limited duration which is conducted according to a prearranged schedule under a permit from the city council; 
(4)  Upon private property owned or leased by or under the control of the off-road vehicle owner, provided the activity is in accordance with a principal or accessory use permitted on the land by chapter 138 pertaining to zoning; 
(5)  Upon the private property of another, in the presence of or with the written consent of the owner, lessee or agent thereof; 
(6)  Left or kept at an off-road vehicle dealership or repair facility; 
(7)  Operated across a public highway, other than a limited access highway, at right angles to the highway for the purpose of getting to a permitted area when the operation can be done in safety and another vehicle is not crossing the highway at the same time in the same general area. An operator shall bring his off-road vehicle to a complete stop before proceeding across the public highway and shall yield the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic; or 
(8)  In the process of being transported in a trailer upon the city highways, roadways, or streets. 
(Code 1976, § 7-15.04)  
Sec. 98-235. - Impoundment for violation. 
(a)  Authority of sheriff's department. The county sheriff's department is authorized to remove, tow and impound any off-road vehicle used, operated, set in motion, transported, moved, maneuvered or left standing in violation of this article. 
(b)  Minimum duration. An impounded off-road vehicle shall be held for at least 24 hours. 
(c)  Release. The off-road vehicle shall be released in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Application by owner. After the time stated in subsection (b) of this section, an impounded off-road vehicle shall be released upon application of the off-road vehicle owner and payment of any removal, towing and storage charges. 
(2)  Owner under 18. If the owner is less than 18 years old, the owner must also be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
(Code 1976, § 7-15.05)  
Secs. 98-236—98-260. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Motor carrier safety act of 1963, MCL 480.11 et seq., MSA 9.1666(1) et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 98-261. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business district means the territory contiguous to a highway when 50 percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of 300 feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business. 
Drive-away/tow-away operation means an operation in which one or more motor vehicles, new or used, constitute the commodity being transported when one or more sets of wheels of any such motor vehicle are on the roadway during the course of transportation, regardless of whether the motor vehicle being transported furnishes the motive power. 
Driver means a person who drives or operates a motor vehicle. 
Enforcement officer includes both sheriff's deputies and other persons designated by the mayor to enforce this article. 
Gross weight means the combined weight of a motor vehicle or combination of vehicles and any load thereon. 
Hazardous materials means all solids, liquids, and gases listed in the provisions of 49 CFR 171 et seq. 
Lightweight vehicle means either of the following: 
(1)  A motor vehicle that has a gross vehicle weight of 10,000 pounds or less, if a single vehicle, or a gross combination weight of 10,000 pounds or less, if a combination of vehicles. 
(2)  A motor vehicle that has a gross weight, including its load and the gross weight of any vehicle being towed by the motor vehicle, of 10,000 pounds or less. 
The term "lightweight vehicle" shall not include a vehicle that is being used to transport hazardous materials of a type or quantity that requires the vehicle to be marked or placarded pursuant to the provisions of 49 CFR 171 et seq. 
Motor carrier means a carrier of property by motor vehicle and includes a motor carrier and the agents, officers, representatives, and employees of a motor carrier who are responsible for the hiring, supervising, training, assigning, or dispatching of drivers. 
Motor vehicle means a vehicle that is self-propelled or a vehicle that is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails. 
Pole trailer means a vehicle without motive power, possibly of variable wheelbase, designed to be drawn by another vehicle and attached to the towing vehicle by means of a reach or pole, or by being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle, and ordinarily used for transporting long or irregularly shaped loads, such as poles, pipes, or structural members capable generally of sustaining themselves as beams between the supporting connections. 
Residential district means the territory contiguous to a highway not comprising a business district when the frontage on such highway for a distance of 300 feet or more is mainly occupied by dwellings. 
Semitrailer means a vehicle with or without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
Trailer means a vehicle with or without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying property or persons and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle. A semitrailer equipped with an auxiliary front axle, known as a dolly, shall be deemed to be a trailer. 
Truck means a motor vehicle designed, used, or maintained primarily for the transportation of property. 
Truck tractor means a motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
Vehicle means any conveyance of any type whatsoever operated upon the highways. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-16.02, 7-16.03.02(c)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions, MCL 480.11a, MSA 9.1666(1a).  
Sec. 98-262. - Purpose. 
The city council finds and determines that it is necessary to regulate the operation of motor trucks, truck tractors, and trailers within the city to promote the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.01)  
Sec. 98-263. - Enforcement officers. 
(a)  Designated. It shall be the duty of the sheriff's department and the deputy sheriffs of the department and other enforcement officers designated by the mayor to enforce this article. 
(b)  Authority to stop and inspect vehicles. The enforcement officers, upon reasonable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is being operated in violation of this article, may stop the motor vehicle and inspect the motor vehicle. 
(c)  Issuance of appearance notice. If a violation is found, the enforcement officer may issue a notice to appear for that violation. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.03.02)  
Sec. 98-264. - Responsibility for violation. 
Any driver or operator who violates this article or any motor carrier or any owner or user of any truck, truck tractor, or trailer or any officer or agent of any individual, partnership, corporation, or association or their lessees or receivers appointed by any court which is the owner or user of any vehicle, who requires or permits the driver or operator to operate or drive any truck, truck tractor, or trailer in violation of this article, is guilty of a misdemeanor for each violation. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.03.01)  
Secs. 98-265—98-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DRIVING OF MOTOR VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 98-291. - Medical certificate. 
(a)  Required. A person who drives a motor vehicle as, for, or on behalf of a motor carrier shall have on his person the original or a copy of a certificate, issued from a physician licensed to practice medicine or osteopathy in the state, stating that the person is physically qualified to drive a motor vehicle, unless that person is otherwise lawfully exempted from having the certificate on his person. 
(b)  Form. The certificate shall be in accordance with the following form prescribed by the motor carrier safety act and rules as promulgated by the department of state police and authorized by MCL 480.14, MSA 9.1666(4): 
I certify that I have examined ___________ in accordance with Motor Carrier Safety Rules R 460.16215—R 460.16218, and with knowledge of his or her duties, I find him or her qualified under the regulations. 
_____ Qualified only when wearing corrective lenses. 
A completed examination form for this person is on file in my office at (address) _____
_____ . 
_____
(Date of exam) 	_____
(Examining Doctor) 
	_____
(Driver) 
	_____
(Driver's Address) 
 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.04.01) 
State Law reference— Medical examiner's certificate, MCL 480.12i, MSA 9.1666(2i); persons required to be medically examined and certified in accordance with 49 CFR 391.43, MCL 480.12j, MSA 9.1666(2j).  
Sec. 98-292. - Operation by impaired driver. 
(a)  Restriction. Under this article, a driver shall not operate a motor vehicle and a motor carrier shall not require or permit a driver to operate a motor vehicle while the driver's ability or alertness is so impaired or so likely to become impaired, through fatigue, illness, or any other cause, as to make it unsafe for him to begin or continue to operate the motor vehicle. 
(b)  Grave emergency exception. However, in case of grave emergency, where the hazard to occupants of the vehicle or other users of the highway would be increased by compliance with this section, the driver may continue to operate the motor vehicle to the nearest place at which that hazard is removed. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.04.02)  
Sec. 98-293. - Narcotics, amphetamines and like substances. 
(a)  Definition. As used in this section, the term "possession" does not include possession of a substance which is manifested and transported as part of a shipment. 
(b)  Operation of motor vehicle. Under this article, a person shall not operate or be in physical control of a motor vehicle if he possessed, is under the influence of, or is using any of the following substances: 
(1)  A narcotic drug or any derivative thereof. 
(2)  An amphetamine or any formulation thereof, including but not limited to pep pills and bennies. 
(3)  Any other substances, to a degree which renders him incapable of safely operating a motor vehicle. 
(c)  Motor carrier responsibility. A motor carrier shall not knowingly require or permit a driver to violate subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Permissive use. Subsection (b) of this section does not apply to the possession or use of a substance administered to a driver by or under the instructions of a physician who has advised the driver that the substance will not affect his ability to operate a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.04.03)  
Sec. 98-294. - Alcoholic liquor. 
(a)  Prohibitions. Under this article, a person shall not: 
(1)  Consume an alcoholic liquor, regardless of its alcoholic content, or be under the influence of an alcoholic liquor within four hours before going on duty or operating or having physical control of a motor vehicle. 
(2)  Consume an alcoholic liquor, regardless of its alcoholic content, or be under the influence of an alcoholic liquor while on duty or while operating or being in physical control of a motor vehicle. 
(3)  Be on duty or operate a motor vehicle while he possesses an alcoholic liquor, regardless of its alcoholic content. However, this subsection does not apply to possession of an alcoholic liquor which is manifested and transported as part of a shipment. 
(b)  Motor carrier responsibility. A motor carrier shall not require or permit a driver to: 
(1)  Violate subsection (a) of this section. 
(2)  Be on duty or operate a motor vehicle if, by his general appearance, conduct or other substantiating evidence, he appears to have consumed an alcoholic liquor within the preceding four hours. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.04.04)  
Sec. 98-295. - Schedules to conform with speed limits. 
A motor carrier shall not schedule a run or shall not permit or shall not require the operation of a motor vehicle between different locations in such a period of time as would necessitate the vehicle being operated at speeds greater than those prescribed. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.04.05)  
Sec. 98-296. - Parts and accessories. 
(a)  Proper operating condition. Under this article, a motor vehicle shall not be driven unless the driver thereof is satisfied that the vehicle is in proper operating condition. Parts and accessories that shall be checked by the driver include but are not limited to all of the following: 
(1)  Service brakes, including trailer brake connections. 
(2)  Parking brake or hand brake. 
(3)  Steering mechanism. 
(4)  Lighting devices and reflectors. 
(5)  Tires. 
(6)  Horn. 
(7)  Windshield wipers. 
(8)  Rear-vision mirrors. 
(9)  Coupling devices. 
(10)  Windshield washers. 
(11)  Windshield defrosters. 
(b)  Use of parts and accessories. A driver of a motor vehicle shall not fail to use or make use of the parts and accessories listed in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.04.06)  
Sec. 98-297. - Emergency equipment inspection and use. 
Under this article, a motor vehicle shall not be driven unless the driver thereof has been satisfied that the emergency equipment required by section 98-398 is in place and ready for use, and a driver shall not fail to use or make use of such equipment when and as needed. 
(Code 1976, § 7-16.04.07)  
Sec. 98-298. - Safe loading. 
(a)  Requirements. A person shall not drive a motor vehicle and a motor carrier shall not require or permit a person to drive a motor vehicle pursuant to this article, unless there is compliance with all of the following: 
(1)  The vehicle's cargo is properly distributed and adequately secured as specified in sections 98-399 to 98-401. 
(2)  The vehicle's tailgate, doors, sideboards, tarpaulins, spare tire, other equipment used in its operation and the means of fastening the vehicle's cargo are secured. 
(3)  The vehicle's cargo or any other object shall not do any of the following: 
a.  Obscure the driver's view ahead or to the right or left sides. 
b.  Interfere with the free movement of the driver's arms or legs. 
c.  Prevent the driver from having free and ready access to any accessories required for emergencies. 
d.  Prevent the free and ready exit of any person from the vehicle's cab or driver's compartment. 
(b)  Examination of vehicle and load. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the driver of a truck or truck tractor shall do all of the following: 
(1)  Assure himself that all the provisions of subsection (a) of this section have been complied with before he drives the vehicle. 
(2)  Examine the vehicle's cargo and its load-securing devices within the first 25 miles after beginning a trip and cause any adjustments to be made to the cargo or load-securing devices, other than steel strapping, as may be necessary to maintain the security of the vehicle's load.
