(7)  Any other factor related to the development and proper design of the proposed subdivision. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.09.02)  
Sec. 122-234. - Preliminary approval. 
(a)  Planning commission recommendation. If the planning commission is satisfied that the proposed open space plan meets the letter and spirit of the zoning ordinance and sections of this article and should be approved, it shall recommend such approval to the city council with the conditions upon which such approval should be based. If the commission recommends denial, it shall state its reasons and forward its reasons to the proprietor and the city council. 
(b)  City council action. Thereafter, the council shall take action upon such application in accordance with subdivisions II and III of division 3 of this article and upon being satisfied the open space plan meets the requirements of and is consistent with the standards of this division. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.09.03)  
Sec. 122-235. - Engineering plans and specifications. 
At the time engineering plans and specifications for other improvements in the subdivision are presented and approved by the city engineer in accordance with section 122-302, the proprietor shall present engineering plans and specifications for and obtain approval from the city engineer for improvements, grading, and retention and detention basins and related facilities. The engineering plans and specifications shall be substantially in conformity with the open space plan approved by the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.09.04)  
Sec. 122-236. - Open space agreement. 
The proprietor shall provide the city with a written open space agreement setting forth the conditions upon which such approval is based, which agreement, after approval thereof by the council, shall be entered into between the city and the proprietor prior to the approval of any subdivision final plat. The open space agreement shall contain at least the following: 
(1)  Incorporation of homeowners' association. The incorporation of a nonprofit corporation to serve as a homeowners' association for purposes of holding title to, controlling and being responsible for the open space. 
(2)  Timely conveyance of title. A provision requiring the conveyance of title of the open space to the association before the sale of a lot in the subdivision or within 90 days of the recording of the plat, whichever occurs first. 
(3)  Regulation of the open space. Provisions for the regulation of the open space. 
(4)  Timely and guaranteed completion. A provision that all improvements within the open space shall be completed within two years of the recording of the plat and that security shall be filed as required in this division to guarantee the completion of the improvements. 
(5)  Interim responsible party. A provision placing responsibility upon a named individual or entity other than the association for maintaining the open space from the date of recording of the plat until effective control if the association is turned over to the homeowners. 
(6)  Satisfactory completion guarantee. Provisions for guaranteeing that, at the time of turning over the control of the association to the homeowners, all of the improvements are completed in a satisfactory condition including the dredging or cleaning of any detention or retention basins and related facilities so that their grades are according to grades established in the engineering plans and specifications. 
(7)  Assessments for maintenance. Provisions for assessments for maintenance of the open space and detention and retention basins and related facilities with the assessments to commence within the first year of recording of the plat. All lots in the subdivision shall be assessed regardless of who may own them. 
(8)  Evidence of compliance. A provision to require the proprietor to provide the city, evidence within 90 days of recording of the plat, that the association has been established as a nonprofit corporation and that the association has been conveyed title to the open space. 
(9)  Turn over of control. Provisions that the proprietor shall turn over control of the association to the homeowners upon 65 percent of the lots being sold to homeowners, other than builders and developers, or four years from the date of recording of the plat, whichever occurs first. No bylaws or other devices shall prevent the effective turn over of control at the time stated herein. 
(10)  Filing of a maintenance bond. A provision to require the proprietor to file a maintenance bond in an amount determined to be reasonable and necessary by the city engineer, to guarantee maintenance of the open space for a two-year period from the time that it is accepted by the city engineer as being completed. Maintenance shall include removal of soils from any detention or retention basin and reworking of drainage facilities so that they are in compliance with the engineering plans and specifications. 
(11)  Second or later phase deed provisions. Provisions, if the agreement pertains to the second or later phase of a multiphase subdivision, requiring a fully executed deed conveying the open space in the new plat to the association to be filed with the city, to be held by the city until the improvements in the open space have been completed and the open space is ready to be turned over to the association. 
a.  Filing of deed of conveyance with city. This section shall apply, except that the deed of conveyance required by subsection (b) of this section shall be filed with the city as required in this subsection. 
b.  Release of deed by city. When the open space is ready to be turned over to the association which was formed in connection with platting of the first phase of the subdivision, the city shall release the deed to the association. 
c.  Proprietor responsibility in interim. Until that time, the proprietor shall have the responsibility for improvement and maintenance of the open space and shall assess the lots in the phase covered by the agreement, as provided in this section. 
(12)  Other factors. Any other factor related to the legal or practical problems of ownership, use, and maintenance of this open space. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.09.05)  
Sec. 122-237. - Final approval. 
The granting of final plat approval for the subdivision shall constitute final approval of the open space plan. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.09.06)  
Sec. 122-238. - Performance guarantee. 
At the time of application for final plat approval, the proprietor shall deposit cash, a certified check, an irrevocable bank letter of credit or a corporate surety bond in the amount of the estimated cost of the proposed improvements to the open space guaranteeing the completion of such improvements within a time agreed upon between the council and the proprietor. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.09.07) 
State Law reference— Agreement to construct improvements, MCL 560.188, MSA 26.430(188).  
Secs. 122-239—122-265. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 122-266. - Scope. 
The subdivision design standards set forth in this division are development guides for the assistance of the developer. All final construction plans shall be reviewed and approved by the city engineer and department of public service. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08; Ord. No. 444, § 1, 9-1-1999)  
Sec. 122-267. - Streets. 
(a)  Conformance to requirements. Subdivision streets shall conform to all minimum requirements, general specifications, typical cross sections and other requirements of the road commission for the county and this article and any other requirements of the city engineer. 
(b)  Location and arrangement. 
(1)  The proposed subdivision shall conform to the various elements of the city master plan and shall be considered in relation to existing and planned major thoroughfares and collector streets, and such streets shall be platted in the location and the width indicated on such plan. 
(2)  The street layout shall provide for continuation of streets in the adjoining subdivisions and of the proper projections of streets when adjoining property is not subdivided. 
(3)  The street layout shall include local streets so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(4)  If a proposed subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed major thoroughfare, the planning commission may require marginal access streets, reverse lot frontage with an approved screen planting contained in a dedicated nonaccess reservation along the rear property line having a minimum width of 15 feet, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation and reduction of traffic hazards. Where mature trees are present in the reservation strip they shall be preserved. 
(5)  If a proposed subdivision borders on or contains a railroad, expressway or other limited access highway right-of-way, the planning commission may require the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the development of an appropriate use of the intervening land such as for parks in residential districts. Such distances shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for approach grades to future grade separation. 
(6)  Half streets shall be prohibited, except where absolutely essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision and in conformity with the other requirements of this article. Wherever a dedicated or platted and recorded half street exists adjacent to the tract to be subdivided, the other half shall be dedicated in the plat. 
(7)  Streets shall be arranged in proper relation to topography so as to result in desirable and usable lots and safe streets with reasonable gradients. 
(8)  Except where justified by extreme conditions, alleys and private streets will not be permitted in areas of detached single- or two-family residences. 
(c)  Right-of-way widths. Street right-of-way widths shall conform to the requirements of the road commission for the county or at least the following requirements, whichever is greater: 
(1)  Major thoroughfares. In conformance with the traffic study and comprehensive transportation plan including the master right-of-way plan adopted by the planning commission. 
(2)  Collector streets: 86 feet. 
(3)  Industrial-service streets: 70 feet. 
(4)  Local and marginal access streets (single-family or multiple-family residential where platted): 60-foot curbs and gutter. 
(5)  Boulevard streets: 80 feet or more. 
(6)  Turnaround (loop or U) streets: 120 feet. 
(7)  Alleys: 20 feet. 
(8)  Cul-de-sac streets; turnarounds. 
a.  Industrial: 70 feet terminating with a 70-foot radius. 
b.  Residential and others: 60 feet or 70 feet (see subsection (c)(4) of this section) terminating with a 60-foot radius. 
(9)  Maximum length for cul-de-sac streets shall generally be 600 feet; this may be exceeded subject to the approval of the commission. 
(d)  Geometrics. Standards for maximum and minimum street grades, vertical and horizontal street curves and sight distances shall be established by resolution of the council and shall not be less restrictive than the standards of the county road commissioners. 
(e)  Intersections. Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible to 90 degrees. Curved streets intersecting with major thoroughfares and collector thoroughfares shall do so with a tangent section of centerline 50 feet in length, measured from the right-of-way line of the major or collector thoroughfare. 
(f)  Layouts. All streets and roads shall conform to the right-of-way width designated in the approved traffic study and comprehensive transportation plan for the city including the master right-of-way plan. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08.01)  
Sec. 122-268. - Blocks. 
(a)  Size. The size of subdivision blocks shall be as follows: 
(1)  Length. Maximum length for blocks shall not exceed 1,300 feet, except where, in the opinion of the city council with the advice of the planning commission, city planner and the city engineer, conditions may justify a greater distance. 
(2)  Width. Widths of blocks shall be determined by the conditions of the layout and shall be suited to the intended design of the subdivision. 
(b)  Paths and sidewalks. Paths and sidewalks shall be in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Requirement established. 
a.  Single-family residential sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be required on both sides of streets in all plats for the development of single-family residential subdivisions. 
b.  Option of planning commission. Except as otherwise provided, nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths and sidewalks may be required by the planning commission where an improved street is not available for pedestrian use, to obtain satisfactory pedestrian circulation within the subdivision and on the periphery to public or private facilities. 
(2)  Nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths. Eight-foot asphalt nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths shall be provided in all rights-of-way abutting the subject property which are either existing or planned rights-of-way of 120 feet in width or greater, as designated on the master right-of-way plan for the city as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(3)  Sidewalks. Five-foot concrete sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of the improved roadway in all rights-of-way abutting the subject property which are located in plats for single-family residential subdivisions or existing or planned rights-of-way less than 120 feet in width, as designated on the master right-of-way plan as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
a.  Location. In single-family residential subdivisions, sidewalks shall be constructed adjacent to retention basins, outlets, and open spaces when abutting an improved street within the subdivision, and along those sections of streets that do not abut lots within the subdivision. 
b.  Uninterrupted. All sidewalks within subdivisions shall be laid out and installed so as to be uninterrupted and continuous. 
(4)  School access easements. Where sidewalks are not required, easements for walkways shall be provided for school access routes. The walkways shall conform to the requirements for nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths. 
(6)  Time of construction. 
a.  Single-family residential subdivision sidewalks. Required sidewalks adjacent to residential lots in single-family residential subdivisions shall be installed prior to the issuance of a final certificate of occupancy, except as may be allowed by this article and article III of chapter 94 pertaining to the standards for construction, protection, and maintenance of nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths and sidewalks. 
1.  A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued for a residence prior to the installation of a sidewalk adjacent to such residential lot upon the deposit by the proprietor of a cash bond in an amount equal to 150 percent of the projected completion cost of such sidewalk. 
2.  Sidewalks along open spaces, outlots, retention basins, and all other areas adjacent to a local street, but not adjacent to a residential lot, shall be constructed before issuance of any building permit for a building within a subdivision, except for building permits issued pursuant to section 122-64. 
b.  Other paths, sidewalks and walkways. Required nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths, sidewalks and walkways, except sidewalks as shown on local streets in plats for single-family residential subdivisions, shall be constructed before issuance of any building permit for a building within a subdivision, except for building permits issued pursuant to section 122-64. If a required path, sidewalk or walkway must be crossed in order to construct a building on a lot in a subdivision, the building department may allow a delay in construction of the path, sidewalk or walkway adjacent to the lot until completion of the building or the expiration of two years from the date of recording of the plat, whichever occurs first. 
(c)  Easements. Easements shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  Location of utility line easements shall be provided along the rear, front or side lot lines as necessary for utilities. Every lot, park or public grounds shall have access to an easement. 
(2)  Recommendations on the proposed layout for telephone, gas and electric utility easements shall be obtained from the utility companies serving the city. It shall be the responsibility of the proprietor to submit copies of the preliminary plans to all appropriate public utility agencies. 
(3)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a storm easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse and such further width or construction or both as will be adequate for the purpose. Such easements shall meet the approval of the city engineer and the drain or road commission for the county. 
(4)  The city may request an easement for emergency vehicle access through properties adjacent to bodies of water. 
(5)  The city may require scenic easements to provide buffers at the edge of subdivisions to screen from major thoroughfares, nonresidential areas and other areas not part of the subdivisions. (See subsection 122-267(b)(4).) 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08.02; Ord. No. 444, § 1, 9-1-1999)  
Sec. 122-269. - Lots. 
Lots within subdivisions shall conform to the city zoning ordinance and the following standards: 
(1)  Sizes and shapes. Sizes and shapes shall be as follows: 
a.  The lot size, width, depth and shape in any subdivision proposed for residential uses shall be appropriate for the location and the type of development contemplated. 
b.  Side lot lines shall be essentially at right angles to straight streets and radial to curved streets and must exhibit satisfactory rear and side yard relationships to provide for privacy and drainage. 
c.  Excessive lot depth in relation to width shall be avoided. A depth-to-width ratio of not more than 3:1 shall be desirable. 
d.  Corner lots in residential subdivisions shall be platted at least 20 feet wider than the minimum width permitted by the city zoning ordinance. 
e.  Lots intended for purposes other than single-family residential use shall be specifically designed for such purposes and shall have adequate provision for off-street parking, setbacks and other requirements in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Orientation. Orientation of lots shall be as follows: 
a.  Every lot shall front or abut on a public street except when involving a planned development for multiple dwellings, business centers or industrial tracts where such requirements would not serve the best interests of the city. 
b.  Residential lots abutting major thoroughfares where marginal access streets are not desirable or possible to attain shall be platted with reverse frontage lots or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic streets. In certain instances, such lots may be platted with extra depth to permit generous distances between buildings and such trafficway, upon approval of the planning commission. 
(3)  Buildable. All lots shall be buildable. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08.03)  
Sec. 122-270. - Natural features. 
For the purposes of this article, the natural features and character of land must be preserved wherever possible. Due regard must be shown for all natural features such as large trees, natural groves, watercourses and similar community assets that will add attractiveness and value to the property if preserved. The preservation of drainage and natural stream channels must be considered by the proprietor and the dedication and provision of adequate barriers (dams, bulkheads, retaining walls, etc.), where appropriate, shall be required. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08.04)  
Sec. 122-271. - Planting strips. 
Planting strips in a subdivision may be required to be placed next to incompatible features such as highways, railroads, commercial or industrial uses to screen the view from residential properties. Such screens or greenbelts shall be a minimum of 15 feet wide and shall not be a part of the normal roadway right-of-way or utility easement, nor counted as open space meeting the requirements of division 4 of this article. Where mature trees are present in the planting strip, they shall be preserved. In all other instances the proprietor shall furnish a satisfactory landscape plan to the planning commission. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08.05)  
Sec. 122-272. - Floodplains. 
Any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which lie either wholly or in part within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek, or lake or any other areas which are subject to flooding or inundation by stormwater shall require specific compliance with the city's wetland protection ordinance in article IV of chapter 126 of this Code; the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq., MSA 26.430(101) et seq.); and its review by the county drain commission and the water resources commission of the department of natural resources. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08.06)  
Sec. 122-273. - Topsoil. 
Removal of topsoil from areas to be subdivided shall be prohibited except in those areas to be occupied by buildings, roads, or parking areas. A plan for storage or stockpiling of topsoil shall be submitted by the proprietor with the final plat. Such plan shall meet the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.08.07)  
Secs. 122-274—122-300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 122-301. - Minimum acceptable standards. 
The improvements set forth under this division are to be considered as the minimum acceptable standard. All those improvements for which standards are not specifically provided shall comply with all other standards set by ordinance or by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.10.01)  
Sec. 122-302. - Compliance standards. 
(a)  Approvals. Engineering plans and specifications for all improvements in a subdivision shall be approved by the city engineer and/or the department of public service prior to the installation of any subdivision or project improvements within the city. 
(b)  Compliance. All subdivision or project improvements within the city installed in public streets, public alleys, rights-of-way, or public easements and/or under the ultimate jurisdiction of the county or city shall comply with all of the provisions and requirements of this article and all other related sections of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.10.02)  
Sec. 122-303. - Subdivision utility standards. 
(a)  Minimum water and storm sewer systems. When a subdivision is developed in stages and the complete water and storm sewer systems are not included in the phase being developed, a sufficient amount of the water system shall be constructed, made operable, and approved so that there will be a looped water system, and a sufficient amount of the storm sewer system shall be constructed and approved so that it is a functional storm system, even if this requires construction of a part of the water or storm sewer system off of the property or in a later phase of the development. 
(b)  Looped water system. A looped water system shall mean the looping of the water mains in such a way, either to two supply points or within the subdivision (all phases), so that the system in the phase of the subdivision being platted has two sources of supply. This shall not require connection to two supply points if both are off of the property being subdivided. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.10.03)  
Sec. 122-304. - Utility improvement standards. 
Three sets of engineering plans shall be prepared by a professional engineer showing all utility improvements in a subdivision and shall be submitted to the city clerk. The plans shall show and conform to the design standards that follow: 
(1)  Streets. All streets and utilities within street or road rights-of-way will be in compliance with current standards of the county road commission. Curb and gutter will be required whenever an adequate storm drainage outlet is available. 
(2)  Storm drainage. All storm drainage plans shall conform to the city master storm drainage plan. When portions of the drainage plan are contained within the subdivision, that portion of the plan will be installed by the developer. 
(3)  Storm sewers. All storm sewers will be designed for rainfall intensity as follows: 
i = 154 / t+22 
Where: 
i = Intensity 
t = Time 
Provisions shall be made to accommodate off-site drainage which naturally flows to the subdivision on the basis of existing zoning. Minimum velocity in storm sewers shall be 2.5 feet per second. Rear yard catchbasins will be provided whenever rear yards are drained to the rear. Sump pump connections shall be provided to a storm sewer available to each lot. Retention facilities shall be required unless adequate off-site drainage is available. Materials, catchbasins, manholes and appurtenances are shown on the city's standard sewer specifications. 
(4)  Water mains. Where municipal water is available, water mains shall be installed in each subdivision in the city and conveyed to the city upon completion. The size shall comply with the city master water plan. In areas where municipal water is not available, the plat shall indicate the water supply source for the lots. Private wells shall be approved by the county health department. The installation of private wells shall not be required during the development of the subdivision. Water mains and appurtenances shall conform to the city's water main standards and specifications. 
(5)  Sanitary sewers. Sanitary sewers shall be installed in subdivisions in the city whenever the summation of the capital charges for all lots within the subdivision is equal to or greater than the cost of bringing sanitary sewers to the site. If sanitary sewers cannot be constructed on this basis, other on-site sanitary sewage disposal will be allowed if approved by the appropriate county agency and the state department of health. Sanitary sewers and appurtenances shall conform to city's sanitary sewer standards and specifications. 
(6)  Overall grading plan. Each subdivision shall have an overall grading plan showing grades for rear yards, sidewalks, and rear yard catchbasins. Storm sewers, house grades and direction of surface drainage flow shall be shown. 
(7)  Trees. 
a.  The proprietor shall take the necessary action to preserve the trees within a proposed subdivision. The proprietor shall inventory the trees, file specifications for the protection of the trees during development, file specifications for grading and drainage for preservation of those trees to be retained, and comply with such other requirements relating to trees as are included in the zoning ordinance, this Code and the applicable standards and specifications. 
b.  Street trees shall be planted by the city, with at least one per lot at the lot line, but within the street right-of-way, after the construction and grading of the subdivision has been completed. Prior to the release of the final plat by the city clerk, the proprietor shall pay to the clerk, in cash or by certified check payable to the city, $200.00 per lot for subdivisions located in the R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-4 residential zoning districts to purchase and plant the street trees. The city shall deposit any amount paid pursuant to this subsection in an interest-bearing account and shall credit interest earned to such account. The city shall determine the kind and size of trees for each street. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.10.04; Ord. No. 435, § 1, 12-2-1998)  
Sec. 122-305. - Surface drainage. 
(a)  Limitation. It shall be unlawful for any person to impede, block, change or alter the flow of surface drainage in any manner or to maintain any such impediment or blockage in any manner, in any subdivision, without the prior written express approval of the city engineer. 
(b)  Land improvement permit. No building permit shall be issued in any subdivision in the city unless a grading plan is filed for the lot and a land improvement permit is obtained from the city engineer pursuant to article II of chapter 114 pertaining to drainage. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.10.05)  
Sec. 122-306. - Sidewalk standards. 
The city engineer shall keep on file in his office standard specifications for the construction of sidewalks in subdivisions. All sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with such specifications. 
(Code 1976, § 4-01.10.06)  
Secs. 122-307—122-335. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - ONE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DETACHED CONDOMINIUMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 469, § 1, adopted Mar. 6, 2002, amended Art. IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. IV, §§ 122-336—122-401, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1976, §§ 4-16.01—4-16.04, 4-16.05.01—4-16.05.03, and 4-16.06—4-16.12. 
State Law reference— Condominium Act, MCL 559.101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 122-336. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Buildable means having sufficient land area outside of wetlands and any required setback and floodplains to construct a structure which meets minimum structure setback, floor area, parking, sewage disposal, and accessory use requirements or, where a permit is obtained, allowing construction of the structure in the wetland, required natural feature setback, or floodplains. 
Building envelope means the condominium unit, consisting of the land area and airspace to be occupied within a building site by the principal structure and any accessory structure. 
Building site means the building envelope and the associated land area or contiguous limited common element underlying and surrounding the building envelope. 
Common elements means the portions of the one-family residential detached condominium development other than building sites; common elements include sidewalks. 
Floodplain means as defined in article III of chapter 114 of this Code. 
Limited common element means the contiguous land area underlying and surrounding the building envelope which is limited to the exclusive use of the condominium unit owner. 
One-family residential detached condominium development means the development of land to create separate and detached one-family residential buildings and building sites under the condominium act, Public Act No. 59 of 1978 (MCL 559.101 et seq.). 
Subdivisions ordinance means article III of this chapter pertaining to subdivisions. 
Wetland means as defined in article IV of chapter 126 of this Code. 
Zoning ordinance means zoning Ordinance No. 200, as amended, as printed in chapter 138 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, §1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions, MCL 559.102 et seq.  
Sec. 122-337. - Purpose. 
(a)  Alternative method of development. The city council recognizes that state law authorizes a method of developing land to create separate and detached one-family residential buildings and building sites, under the condominium act, Public Act No. 59 of 1978 (MCL 559.101 et seq.), as an alternative to the more traditional method of development under the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(b)  Compatibility with other developments. The purpose of this article is to provide regulations, standards and review procedures for one-family residential detached condominium developments to promote consistency and compatibility with developments in the city which have been or are being developed under the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-338. - Applicability of article. 
This article shall apply to all one-family residential detached condominium developments in the city, except for those receiving site plan approval on or before October 3, 1994, provided such site plan remains in effect and in good standing. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-339. - Relational intent for acts and ordinances. 
(a)  Generally. The terms and provisions of this article are defined and used both in the context of the condominium act, Public Act No. 59 of 1978 (MCL 559.101 et seq.), and in a manner intended to make comparison possible among the terms used in this article and those used in the zoning ordinance, subdivisions ordinance, and other applicable sections of this Code. 
(b)  Compliance with city ordinances. Compliance shall be as follows: 
(1)  Schedule of regulations. One-family residential detached condominium developments shall comply with all applicable sections of this Code, specifically including but without limitation the zoning ordinance's schedule of regulations. 
(2)  Synonymous terms. For purposes of this article, certain terms used in the zoning ordinance, subdivisions ordinance, and other application sections of this Code shall be considered synonymous with terms defined and used in this article. Specifically, in other sections of this Code, reference to the term: 
a.  "Lot" shall be synonymous with the term "building site"; 
b.  "Building" or "structure" shall be synonymous with the term "building envelope"; 
c.  "Preliminary plat" or "plat" shall be synonymous with the term "one-family residential detached condominium plan"; 
d.  "Subdivision" or "single-family residential subdivision" shall be shall be synonymous with the term "one-family residential detached condominium plan"; and 
e.  "Proprietor" shall be synonymous with the term "developer." 
(c)  Plan review objective and intent . With respect to the review of one-family residential detached condominium plans under this article, the city council recognizes that it may not always be practical or feasible to precisely apply traditional definitions and measures applicable to developments regulated under the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and the subdivisions ordinance. Nevertheless, one-family residential detached condominium plan review under this article shall be accomplished, aside from procedural differences, with the objective and intent of achieving the same results as if the development were being developed under the land division act, Public Act No. 288 of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and the subdivisions ordinance, except that nothing in this article shall be construed as requiring a one-family residential detached condominium development to obtain plat approval. 
(d)  Lot size variations. The provisions for average lot sizes and subdivision open space plan option contained in division 4 of article III of this chapter pertaining to subdivision control and section 138-1112 of the zoning ordinance shall also apply to one-family residential detached condominium developments, provided that the condominium plan is laid out to make it reasonably possible to compute lot size and open space. 
(e)  Buildable sites All building sites in a one-family residential detached condominium development shall be buildable. 
(f)  Variances. The city council may authorize variances and sidewalk waivers in the manner and to the extent described in section 122-91 through 122-95 of the subdivisions ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-340. - Fees. 
Review fees, charges, and insurance under this article shall be in accordance with division 4 of article III of chapter 110. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Secs. 122-341—122-365. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PLAN REVIEW 
 
Sec. 122-366. - Required. 
Review and approval of a one-family residential detached condominium plan under this division is prerequisite to construction or expansion of a one-family residential detached condominium development in the city. Review and approval shall occur in two stages: preliminary plan approval and final plan approval. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-367. - Preliminary plan. 
(a)  Contents. The preliminary plan for one-family residential detached condominiums shall include the plans, survey, sketches, drawings, statements and additional information and documentation containing all the information required in the subdivisions ordinance for tentative approval of a preliminary subdivision plat. The preliminary plan shall assign a number to each building envelope and shall describe the nature, location, and size of common elements. 
(b)  Review and approval. The preliminary plan shall conform to and be governed by the preparation, filing, technical review, and planning commission and city council initial review and approval requirements and procedures applicable to tentative approval of a preliminary subdivision plat under sections 122-152 through 122-156 of the subdivisions ordinance. 
(c)  Rights conferred with approval . Preliminary plan approval by the city council shall confer upon the developer, for one year, the right to submit a final plan. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-368. - Final plan. 
(a)  Contents. The final plan for one-family residential detached condominiums shall include all the information required in the approved preliminary plan and shall also include the following: 
(1)  Any additional information required in the subdivisions ordinance for final approval of a preliminary subdivision plat; and 
(2)  Evidence that all necessary state and county agency approvals have been obtained with respect to any aspect of the proposed one-family residential detached condominium development, including, without limitation, utilities, water supply, sewage disposal, drainage, wetlands, and roads. 
(b)  Master deed. The developer shall also submit, for review and approval by the city staff and city attorney, five copies of a proposed master deed, bylaws and restrictive covenants, if any, containing provisions governing the maintenance and control of common areas and stormwater retention and detention facilities and conforming with all applicable sections of this Code. 
(c)  Review and approval. The final plan shall conform to and be governed by the preparation, filing and final technical review requirements and procedures applicable to final approval of a preliminary subdivision plat under sections 122-157 through 122-159 of the subdivisions ordinance. Following final technical review and recommendations by city staff for either approval or disapproval of the final plat, the final plan shall be submitted to the planning commission for review and recommendation to the city council, which shall thereafter review the final plan and shall: 
(1)  Approve. Approve the final plan if it conforms with the approved preliminary plan and all requirements of this article and other applicable sections of this Code; 
(2)  Disapprove. Disapprove the final plan if it fails to conform with the approved preliminary plan and all requirements of this article or other applicable sections of this Code; or 
(3)  Approve with conditions. As an alternative to disapproval of the final plan, the city council may approve the final plan with conditions intended to correct any deficiencies in the final plan. 
(d)  Notice of wetland/floodplain designation. Upon approval of a final plan by the city council but before a final plan is stamped "approved," the developer shall present to the city a fully executed notice of wetland or floodplain designation, in a recordable form satisfactory to the city, for every building envelope, building site, and common element which includes any area designated as wetland or floodplain. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Secs. 122-369—122-395. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 122-396. - Commencement of construction. 
Construction of utilities, street, sidewalks, and other improvements may commence only after final approval of the one-family residential detached condominium plan by the city council and approval of engineering plans by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-397. - Monuments. 
(a)  Placement required. All one-family residential detached developments shall be marked with monuments acceptable to the city and located at all one-family residential detached condominium development boundary angles; street intersection line; intersections of street and alley lines with one-family residential detached condominium development boundaries; points of curvature, compound curvature, reverse curvature, tangency and angles in street and alley lines; and at all angles of an intermediate traverse line and at the intersection of limited common elements and common elements. 
(b)  Waiver. The city council may, in the manner prescribed in section 122-196 of the subdivisions ordinance, waive the requirements of subsection (a) of this section for up to one year after final plan approval; however, the city shall not issue building permits for buildings or structures being constructed on building sites until all required monuments and markers are in place. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-398. - Design and improvement standards. 
One-family residential detached condominium developments shall conform to the subdivision design standards and subdivision and project improvements standards set forth in divisions 5 and 6 of article III, respectively, of the subdivisions ordinance in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-399. - Building permits. 
(a)  Requirements. Except for building permits for up to four sales models, which shall be subject to the requirements of subsection 122-64(b)(1) of the subdivisions ordinance, the city shall not issue any building permits for buildings or structures being constructed on building sites for one-family residential detached condominiums until: 
(1)  Installation of required improvements. All utilities, streets, nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths, sidewalks and other required improvements have been installed and completed; 
(2)  Warranty deeds and easements. The city has received warranty deeds and easement documents, in recordable form, for all rights-of-way and easements being dedicated to the public; 
(3)  Maintenance agreement. The city has received and approved an agreement providing for adequate maintenance of any stormwater retention or detention facility, and further providing that if the facility is not adequately maintained, the city may perform the maintenance and charge the cost thereof to the condominium association; and 
(4)  Maintenance bond. The city has received a maintenance bond in an amount determined to be reasonable and necessary by the city engineer, to guarantee maintenance of the common elements for a two-year period after completion. Maintenance shall include removal of soils from any detention or retention basin and rework of drainage facilities so that they are in compliance with the approved engineering plans and specifications. 
(b)  Before completion of improvements. Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the city may issue building permits for building sites before installation and completion of all utilities, streets, nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths, sidewalks, and other required improvements upon the developer's deposit with the city of an amount, in the form of cash, certified check, irrevocable bank letter of credit or corporate surety bond acceptable to the city, sufficient to guarantee installation and completion of utilities, streets, nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths, sidewalks, and other required improvements. As work progresses, the city shall refund or release amounts to the developer in proportion to the work completed. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-400. - Improvements prior to occupancy. 
(a)  Required. No building or structure constructed on a building site for one-family residential detached condominiums shall be occupied other than as a model nor shall the city issue a final certificate of occupancy until all utilities, streets, nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths, sidewalks, and other required improvements are installed and completed in accordance with city standards. 
(b)  Issuance of temporary certificates . The city may issue temporary certificates of occupancy, provided utilities, streets, nonmotorized vehicle-pedestrian paths, sidewalks, and other required utilities are substantially installed and completed and sufficient financial guarantees for completion of improvements before expiration of the temporary certificate of occupancy have been provided to the city. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002)  
Sec. 122-401. - Construction limitations. 
The construction limitations set forth in section 122-165 of the subdivisions ordinance shall apply to one-family residential detached condominium developments. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 3-6-2002) 
State Law reference— Condominium Act, MCL 559.101 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 126-1—126-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SOIL EXCAVATION AND LANDFILL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Soil erosion and sedimentation control, MCL 324.9101 et seq., MSA 13A.9101 et seq.; ordinances, contents, applicability, enforcement, MCL 324.9106, MSA 13A.9106; soil conservation districts, MCL 324.9301 et seq., MSA 13A.9301 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 126-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ashes means the residue from burning of wood, coal, coke, or other combustible materials. 
Board of appeals means the city zoning board of appeals. 
Bulky wastes means large items of refuse, including but not limited to appliances, vehicles, furniture, large auto parts, tires, trees and branches, stumps and flotage. 
Cell means compacted refuse completely enveloped by cover material. 
Facility means any solid waste disposal site, system or process, the operation thereof including but not limited to personnel, equipment and buildings. 
Garbage means any putrescible solid and semisolid animal or vegetable wastes resulting from the production, handling, preparation, cooling, serving or consumption of food or food materials. 
Groundwater means any water found under the surface of the earth. 
Hazardous waste means any material including but not limited to explosives, pathological wastes, pesticides and chemicals, including empty containers previously used for such material, which, when discharged on land, into the air, or into or upon surface waters or groundwaters, presents an imminent and substantial danger to public health or welfare or to elements of the human environment, including but not limited to aquatic organisms, fish, shellfish, terrestrial life, birds and other wildlife. 
Impermeable means a hydraulic conductivity of no greater than 1 × (10)-7 centimeters per second as determined by field and/or laboratory tests made according to standard test methods. A medium has a hydraulic conductivity of unit length per unit time if it will transmit in unit time a unit volume of groundwater at the prevailing viscosity through a cross section of unit area, measured at right angles to the direction of flow, under a hydraulic gradient of unit change in head through unit length of flow. 
Industrial solid waste means any waste substance or a combination thereof resulting from the operation of or from any process of industry, manufacturing, trade or business or from the development of any agricultural or natural resources. 
Inert solid wastes means wastes, including but not limited to glass, crockery, brick, plastics, rubber or other materials, which are shown through analytical testing to have minimum potential for environmental degradation and leachate production. 
Landfill means any disposal area or tract of land, building, unit or appurtenance or combination thereof that is used to collect, store, handle, dispose of, bury, cover over, or otherwise accept or retain refuse as defined in this section. 
Leachate means fluid that has percolated through solid waste and which contains contaminants consisting of dissolved or suspended materials, chemicals and microbial waste products from the solid waste. 
Lift means a layer of refuse cells which raises the ground elevation to an approximately common level. 
Other wastes means garbage, refuse, decayed wood, sawdust, shavings, bark, lime cinders, offal, oil, tar, dye stuffs, acids, chemicals and all discarded materials other than sewage or industrial wastes. 
Refuse means any putrescible or nonputrescible solid waste, except human excreta, but including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, offal and solid agricultural, commercial, industrial, hazardous and institutional wastes and construction wastes resulting from the operation of a contractor. 
Roads on site means roads designated on approved plans and such other areas used by vehicles and/or equipment for travel on a regular basis, other than for travel on an infrequent basis, necessitated by the operation of the landfill such as trucks and/or equipment going to and from a regular course of travel to the area which is currently being filled. 
Rubbish means any nonputrescible solid waste, excluding ashes, such as cardboard, paper, plastic, metal or glass food containers, rags, waste metal, yard clippings, small pieces of wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, crockery, and other similar materials. 
Sewage means water-carried human or animal wastes from septic tanks; water closets; residences; building, industrial and municipal establishments; or other places, together with such groundwater infiltration, subsurface water, mixtures of industrial wastes or other wastes as may be present. 
Site means a parcel or unit of land. 
Sludge means a semiliquid sediment resulting from industrial or municipal establishments, or other places, together with such groundwater infiltration, subsurface water, mixtures of industrial wastes or other wastes as may be present. 
Soil excavation means the excavation or removal of any kind or nature from a site of gravel, clay, sand, soil or other similar materials. 
Solid waste means any garbage, refuse, rubbish, special solid waste, other waste, or any combination thereof with insufficient liquid content to be free flowing. 
Special solid waste means hazardous wastes, radioactive wastes, agricultural wastes, industrial wastes or sludges, and sewage residues. 
Surface water means water occurring generally on the surface of the earth. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 126-27. - Purpose. 
The removal of topsoil, subsoil, sand, gravel and other materials and the filling of land with refuse result in the emission of noise, dirt, dust, and odors, and such operations effect permanent changes in the topographical and geological characteristics of land; further, because of such changes, the operations create dangers and hazards by virtue of shifting earth, standing water, filtration into the underground water systems and other like considerations. In recognition of the fact that the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare of the residents of the city and the preservation of the city resources and the prevention of nuisances and hazards require reasonable control of these operations, it is deemed necessary that the operations be regulated and that standards be established wherein procedures permitting the operations are established, operating requirements are set forth, the administration of such standards are provided for, and penalties are provided. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.01)  
Sec. 126-28. - Administration. 
The zoning board of appeals is granted authority under this article as a city board to entertain applications, hold public hearings, grant permits and do all other acts authorized in this article and in the city zoning ordinance in chapter 138 of this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.03)  
Sec. 126-29. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Generally. This article shall be enforced by the building department and any ordinance enforcement officer appointed by the city council. 
(b)  Inspections. By accepting a permit issued under this article, and/or the zoning ordinance in chapter 138, the owner and/or operator of any operation shall be presumed to have consented to regular and routine inspections of the property. The consent shall be authority to go on to any property under permit for purposes of any inspection. 
(c)  Authority to issue appearance tickets. The building inspector and enforcement officers shall have the authority to issue appearance tickets for a violation of this article pursuant to sections 9a through 9g of Public Act No. 147 of 1968 (MCL 764.9a et seq., MSA 28.868(1) et seq.). 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.04)  
Sec. 126-30. - Effective date for existing landfills. 
All of the sections of this article, as amended, shall apply to new and existing landfills on June 5, 1976, the effective date of amendment, except the added requirements for bonds as contained in subsection 126-71(b)(1) and the requirements and/or standards added to subdivision III of division 3 of this article by the amendment which became effective on June 5, 1976, which require a revision of approved plans, shall not apply to existing landfills for a period of six months after the effective date. After the six-month period, all requirements and/or standards shall be effective as to existing landfills, except requirements and/or standards requiring a revision of approved plans shall not apply to those areas of existing landfills which are actually being physically prepared for or being filled at the end of the six-month period. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.12)  
Sec. 126-31. - Exclusions. 
Under this article, no permit shall be required for the following: 
(1)  Building construction excavations. Excavations for the construction of buildings and structures for which a building permit has been issued. 
(2)  Landscaping. The moving, grading or leveling of earth or rock materials by a property owner solely upon his property and not remove to other noncontiguous property. 
(3)  Filling of low land. The filling of land for purposes of construction where the land is low and in need of fill so long as the fill does not contain any refuse, it is not a commercial operation, and not more than five acres are involved on any given site. 
(4)  Minimal soil removal. The removal of soil, etc., when no more than 20 cubic yards are removed in any calendar year. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.03)  
Secs. 126-32—126-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 126-61. - Required. 
From and after May 29, 1975, no person shall operate a soil excavation site or a landfill in the city except in accordance with a permit issued by the zoning board of appeals, pursuant to the authority of this article and the city zoning ordinance in chapter 138. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.01)  
Sec. 126-62. - Application. 
An applicant for a permit required by this division shall submit to the board of appeals an application containing the following information: 
(1)  Full names and addresses of all parties of interest in the premises, setting forth their legal interest. Proof of the legal interest shall be provided. 
(2)  A detailed and full legal description of the premises wherein the operations are proposed shall be provided. 
(3)  Topographical survey map at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet, showing existing and proposed grades on a two-foot contour interval. The grades shall be prepared and sealed by a civil engineer or land surveyor, registered as such by the state. 
(4)  A statement by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor as to the cubic yards of the material to be removed and/or the fill, and a detailed statement as to how the filling and/or materials removal is to be accomplished. 
(5)  A detailed statement as to all types of materials to be removed and/or filled, an indication of specific places on the property where each of the materials or fill are to be removed or placed, a detailed statement as to the methods of operation, the type of machinery or equipment to be used, and the estimated period of time that such operations shall cover. 
(6)  Details of similar operations carried on by the applicant. 
(7)  The type and daily number of vehicles to be used in the proposed operations. 
(8)  Identification of access roads, on-site roads, grades for proper drainage and any special draining devices if necessary, fencing, any structures on site existing or proposed, existing and proposed utilities, and any explanation of any on-site testing or other reliable survey data, including soil surveys, water tables and subsurface characteristics. 
(9)  Presentation of an environmental impact statement and a statement concerning trees and/or other vegetation as required by section 138-142 of the city zoning ordinance. 
(10)  A statement which specifies in detail the proposed use of the land after the excavation or filling. The final grades presented shall be consistent with the purposes for the property after completion of operations. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.02(A))  
Sec. 126-63. - Application attachments. 
Applications for a permit to operate a solid waste processing or disposal facility or areas shall contain or be accompanied by the following information: 
(1)  Design plans. Design plans prepared by and bearing the signature and seal of a professional engineer registered in the state. 
(2)  Background data. Background data, including the following: 
a.  Present and estimated future contributory populations of the life of the system. 
b.  Estimated per capita daily domestic waste quantities in weight and volume. 
c.  Anticipated weight and volume of other wastes, including but not limited to industrial, agricultural and demolition wastes and street cleanings. 
d.  Ratio of the maximum daily volume anticipated to the average daily volume anticipated. 
(3)  Maps. Maps, in the number prescribed by the city, drawn to the scale of 100 feet equals one inch or larger and with two-foot contour intervals. Maps shall include as a minimum the following information: 
a.  Property boundaries and boundaries of areas to be filled. 
b.  Access road location. 
c.  Proposed traffic patterns. 
d.  Location of fencing. 
e.  Location of weighing facilities, if applicable. 
f.  Location of existing and proposed utilities. 
g.  Indication of use of adjoining land. 
h.  Borrow and soil storage areas. 
i.  Location of public and private water supplies, wells, springs, streams, swamps or other bodies of water within one-fourth of a mile of the proposed landfill site property lines. 
j.  Location of gas and oil wells. 
k.  Location of high-tension power line rights-of-way. 
l.  Location of fuel transmission pipeline rights-of-way. 
m.  Location of mining operations within one-fourth of one mile of property lines of the proposed landfill. 
(4)  Plan of operation. 
a.  A plan of operation shall be written and submitted which is specific as to areas to be filled, schedule of filling, site preparations, source and types of materials to be used as cover. 
b.  The plan should include details relative to the following: 
1.  Compaction of solid wastes. 
2.  Application of daily cover material. 
3.  Elevation and grade of final cover. 
4.  Liner construction. 
5.  Leachate collection treatment and recirculation or disposal. 
6.  Management of groundwater. 
7.  Management of surface water. 
8.  Erosion control. 
9.  Revegetation procedures to be used. 
10.  Typical cross sections of lifts, dimensions and elevations of the base lifts. 
11.  Grades required for proper drainage of lifts. 
12.  Decomposition gas control measures. 
(5)  Hydrogeologic investigation and report. A soils, geologic and groundwater report of the characteristics of the proposed site, prepared by a competent hydrogeologist, shall be based on a geological investigation showing a sufficient number of boring and wells drilled to a depth necessary to determine the soil, geology and seasonal groundwater flow conditions. These may be supplemented by excavations where appropriate. 
a.  Borings and wells shall be drilled five feet into the groundwater or 20 feet below the base of the proposed landfill, whichever is deeper. 
b.  One well shall be drilled near the point of highest ground surface elevation, ten feet into the groundwater. 
c.  A minimum of one groundwater elevation and quality monitoring well shall be drilled in each dominant direction of groundwater movement, down-gradient of refuse placement. One monitoring well shall be installed up-gradient of refuse placement. Groundwater monitoring well screens shall be set so that the top of the screen is five feet below the yearly low groundwater table elevation in unconfined aquifers. 
d.  All useable aquifers underlying the proposed landfill site and within one-quarter mile of the site shall be delineated. 
(6)  Other information. Such other information and material as the board shall require. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.02(B))  
Sec. 126-64. - Fees and/or costs. 
An applicant for a permit required by this division shall deposit such fees and/or costs as provided in section 110-256. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.02(C))  
Sec. 126-65. - Hearing/referral to planning commission. 
Before granting a permit for any property or additional area of property not previously under a permit issued under this division, the board of appeals shall hold a public hearing and shall, either before or after the public hearing, refer the application to the city planning commission for findings and recommendations as to whether the granting of the permit, as proposed, would: 
(1)  Permanently impair the intended land use potential of the property in question; 
(2)  Detrimentally affect the adjoining properties; and 
(3)  Be consistent with the planning and zoning of the area where the proposed operation is to be located. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.02(D))  
Sec. 126-66. - Basis for issuance. 
The board of appeals shall authorize the issuance of a permit under this division only if it finds that the granting of the permit: 
(1)  Will not be injurious to the public health, safety and welfare of the city and its residents; 
(2)  There has been compliance with all the requirements and standards of this article, and the other applicable sections, standards and regulations of this Code; 
(3)  The proposed operation will not create an unreasonable hazard, annoyance or inconvenience to the owners or occupants of nearby property; 
(4)  Will not significantly change the character of the neighborhood or unreasonably reduce the value of nearby property; and 
(5)  Will not create any significant obstacle to the implementation of the zoning plan as evidenced by this article and the master plan of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.02(E))  
Sec. 126-67. - Duration, expiration and renewal. 
After referral to the planning commission, either before or after the public hearing, and after considering all the available facts and details, the board of appeals may issue a permit pursuant to this division for a period of up to one year, expiring on May 15 of each year, and renewable annually for a year or less by the board of appeals without further public hearing. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.02(F))  
Sec. 126-68. - Conditions. 
(a)  Necessity. The board of appeals may attach such conditions to the granting of the permit under this division that it may find necessary to ensure that the intent and purpose of this article is in all respects observed. 
(b)  Violation. Any violation of a condition included in the permit shall be construed as a violation of this article and shall give rise to the penalties provided in this article and shall be grounds for revoking the permit. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.02(G))  
Sec. 126-69. - Revocation. 
(a)  Notice of violation. The board of appeals may, in its discretion, notify the owner and/or operator of any violation of the permit issued under this division and/or this article. 
(b)  Failure to abate violation. Upon failure of the owner and/or operator to abate the violation within five days after mailing or delivery of the notice, the operation site may be summarily closed, and the permit therefor suspended or revoked and resort had to the bond for restoration. 
(c)  Hearing request. Any owner and/or operator aggrieved of any notice sent pursuant to this section may request a hearing before the board of appeals, if the request is in writing and delivered to the city. The request should set forth why the operation site should not be summarily closed, the permit suspended or revoked, and resort had to the bond. 
(d)  Action pending hearing. In any case, if the board of appeals determines the operation of the landfill would be detrimental to the health and/or safety of persons and/or property, the board may summarily, and without five days' notice, suspend or revoke the permit, but shall grant a hearing upon request as provided in this section. 
(e)  Hearing. If a request for a hearing is received, the board of appeals shall hold a hearing within seven days and may, after the hearing, continue the suspension or revocation of the permit or take such other action as appears appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.04)  
Sec. 126-70. - Changes. 
The person issued a permit under this division shall submit a written request to the board of appeals for approval of changes to the original plans, specifications, reports and methods of operation submitted with a permit application. No such change shall be initiated until the written approval of the board of appeals has been obtained. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.05.05)  
Sec. 126-71. - Surety bond. 
(a)  Required. The applicant for a permit required under this division shall post a surety bond or some other equitable security satisfactory to the board of appeals naming the city as the beneficiary thereof in an amount determined by the board of appeals to be reasonably necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(b)  Conditions. Conditions of the bond shall be as follows: 
(1)  Guarantee of compliance. Bonds shall guarantee compliance with this article, the permit requirements and conditions, and that the operation will be carried out according to the approved plans and specifications. 
(2)  Guarantee of landfill work performance. For a landfill, it shall further guarantee the performance of whatever work or rework that needs to be done to avoid harmful movement of gases or contamination to the groundwater or surface water and/or environment during operations and for five years after the completion of the landfill. 
(3)  Forfeiture of bond. Upon the lack of timely compliance with the requirements for which the bond guarantees, the city may use the bond proceeds to the extent necessary. 
(c)  Noncompliance enforcement. By filing an application, every applicant shall be deemed to have granted a license to the city and its agents and contractors to go onto a property under permit to use the bond proceeds for the purposes allowed by the bond, for which there has been noncompliance. 
(d)  Establishing amount. The amount of the bond shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Considerations. In fixing the amount of the bond, the board of appeals shall take into account the following: 
a.  The size and scope of the proposed operation. 
b.  Current prevailing cost of rehabilitating the premises upon default of the operator. 
c.  Other such conditions and factors as might be relevant in determining the sum reasonable in light of all facts and circumstances surrounding each application. 
(2)  Minimum amount. In no case will the sum of the surety bond be less than $500.00 for each acre or fraction thereof of land to be covered by the permit. 
(e)  Notice of lapse. The applicant shall notify the bonding company and provide proof thereof that the city be notified of any lapse in the effectiveness of the bond. 
(f)  Reduction of bond. For each acre restored and reclaimed in accordance with this article or otherwise, the bond may be reduced pro rata as determined by the board of appeals. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.06)  
Secs. 126-72—126-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PERFORMANCE STANDARDS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46. 
 
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 126-101. - Hours of operation. 
Under this article, hours of operation shall be 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. unless otherwise specified by the board of appeals. No operation shall be permitted on Sundays and legal holidays. In emergency situations this time period may be modified by the building department, provided such emergency order shall not be effective for more than 72 hours. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.08)  
Sec. 126-102. - Compliance required. 
With a permit or without a permit, if one is not required, the carrying on of any alterations, modifications or changes in geographical or geological structures, which shall include all soil excavation for removal and filling of land or the creation or alteration of waterways, canals, etc., for either immediate use or for filling or removal to other places, the performance standards for sound, vibration, etc., shall be complied with as provided in this subdivision. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07)  
Sec. 126-103. - Atmospheric discharge. 
Under this article, it shall be unlawful to discharge into the atmosphere from any single source of emission whatsoever any air contaminator for a period aggregating more than four minutes in any one-half hour which is as follows: 
(1)  Smoke. As dark or darker in shade as that designated as no. 2 on the Ringelmann Chart, as published by the United States Bureau of Mines, which is made a part of this article. However, the umbrascope readings of smoke densities may be used when correlated with the Ringelmann Chart. A Ringelmann Chart shall be on file in the office of the building department. 
(2)  Other airborne solids. Of such opacity as to obscure an observer's view to a degree equal to or greater than the smoke described in subsection (1) of this section, except when the emission consists only of water vapor. The quantity of gasborne or airborne solids shall not exceed 0.20 grains per cubic foot of the carrying medium at a temperature of 500 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.01)  
Sec. 126-104. - Debris on public roads. 
(a)  Responsibility. The owner and/or permit holder of any site where there is soil removal and/or any filling shall take whatever steps are necessary to avoid any motor vehicle carrying or tracking onto any public right-of-way from the site any mud, dirt, clay, refuse, etc. 
(b)  Obligation to clean. If mud, dirt, clay, refuse, etc., is carried or tracked onto a public right-of-way and it does or might constitute a nuisance or hazard to public safety, the owner and/or permit holder shall clean the right-of-way when and as often as is necessary, presuming weather conditions permit. In any case, an owner and/or permit holder shall not leave any such debris on a public right-of-way after the end of any working day. 
(c)  Notice from city. If notified during a working day by the city of a condition which requires cleaning, the matter shall be taken care of within one hour, weather permitting. 
(d)  Violations. If a nuisance or hazardous condition is left after a working day or is not cleaned up within the one hour after receiving a request from the city, and weather does not prevent the cleanup, the city may issue a citation for the violation of this section due to the allowance of the condition to remain on the highway and/or may clean the right-of-way and charge the owner and/or permit holder with the cost thereof, which may be collected in any court having general jurisdiction. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.02)  
Sec. 126-105. - Drainage. 
(a)  Generally. Under this article, natural drainage shall not be blocked or diverted or altered in such a manner as to cause the natural water flow to back up onto adjacent property or to flow in a different course or rate of flow upon leaving the property upon which the blocking, diversion, or alteration occurs, unless an application is made and a permit is issued by the building department pursuant to plans which provide for a drainage flow that will not be detrimental to surrounding properties. 
(b)  Retention areas. No area designated for and/or used as a drainage retention area shall be altered, filled in, abandoned or used for other purposes, unless it is done pursuant to a permit issued under this section. 
(c)  Permit. A permit shall be required under this section, notwithstanding a permit is not otherwise required by this article. Permit requirements and procedures shall be as adopted by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.03)  
Sec. 126-106. - Drifting and blown material. 
Under this article, the drifting or airborne transmission beyond the property line of dust, particles or debris from any open stockpile, working areas or unplanted areas shall be unlawful and may be summarily caused to be abated. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.04)  
Sec. 126-107. - Electromagnetic radiation. 
Applicable rules and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission in regard to propagation of electromagnetic radiation are made a part of this article and shall be on file in the office of the building department. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.05)  
Sec. 126-108. - Floodplains, watercourses and wetlands. 
There shall be no excavation, soil removal, filling or depositing of materials in any floodplain, watercourse and/or wetlands, the terms being defined in chapter 114 pertaining to floodplains and in article IV of this chapter pertaining to watercourse and wetland protection, without a permit as provided in chapter 114 and in article IV of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.06)  
Sec. 126-109. - Gases. 
Under this article, the escape of or emission of any gas in concentrations so as to be injurious, destructive or explosive shall be unlawful and may be summarily caused to be abated. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.07)  
Sec. 126-110. - Glare or heat. 
Any operation pursuant to this article that produces intense glare or heat shall be performed within an enclosure so as to completely obscure and shield such operation from direct view from any point along the lot line, except during the period of construction of the facilities to be used and occupied. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.08)  
Sec. 126-111. - Light. 
Under this article, exterior lighting shall be so installed that the surface of the source of light shall not be visible from any bedroom window and shall be so arranged as far as practical to reflect light away from any residential use, and in no case shall more than one footcandle power of light cross a lot line five feet above the ground in a residential district. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.09)  
Sec. 126-112. - Odors. 
The emission of noxious, odorous matter in such quantities as to be readily detectable at any point along lot lines, when diluted in the ratio of one volume of odorous air to four or more volumes of clean air, or as to produce a public nuisance or hazard beyond lot lines is prohibited under this article. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.10)  
Sec. 126-113. - Radioactive materials. 
Under this article, radioactive materials shall not be emitted to exceed quantities established as safe by the U.S. Bureau of Standards, as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.11)  
Sec. 126-114. - Sound. 
(a)  Under this article, the pressure level of sounds shall not exceed the following decibel levels when adjacent to the following types of uses and when measured at the common property line: 
Sound Level 	 Adjacent Use 
75 dBA 	Residential 
85 dBA 	Commercial 
90 dBA 	Industrial and other 
 
(b)  The sound levels shall be measured using a weighted decibel measurement (referenced to 20 micropascals) and with a type of audio output meter approved by the U.S. Bureau of Standards. Objectionable noises due to intermittence, beat, frequency, or shrillness shall be muffled so as not to become a nuisance to adjacent uses. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.12)  
Sec. 126-115. - Vibration. 
Under this article, all machinery shall be so mounted and operated as to prevent transmission of ground vibration exceeding a displacement of 0.003 of one inch measured at any property line of its source. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.13)  
Sec. 126-116. - Roads. 
Roads on landfill and soil excavation sites shall be designed and constructed so that traffic will flow smoothly and will not be interrupted by inclement weather. Nonpaved roads between the site and the nearest paved roads, paved roads off the site within one-fourth mile of the site entrance which are used by vehicles and/or equipment traveling to or from the site, and all roads on site shall not be used unless they are treated by sufficient oil, water and/or chemical substance, whichever would be appropriate for the surface, and frequent enough so that they are dustfree whenever used by vehicles and/or equipment. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.14)  
Sec. 126-117. - Soil erosion. 
If a soil erosion permit is required by part 91 of the natural resources and environmental protection act, Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.9101 et seq., MSA 13A.9101 et seq.), no operation shall take place until a permit has been obtained. There shall be compliance at all times with the requirements of the soil erosion permit. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.07.15)  
Secs. 126-118—126-145. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Soil Excavation 
 
Sec. 126-146. - Limits on perimeter. 
No cut or excavation shall be closer than 100 feet from the nearest street, highway, or alley right-of-way line or from the nearest perimeter property line. However, the board of appeals may prescribe more strict requirements in order to give sublateral support to surrounding property where swell or geographic conditions warrant it. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.09.01)  
Sec. 126-147. - Surface water drainage. 
Under this article, the premises shall at all times be graded so that surface water drainage is not interfered with. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.09.02)  
Sec. 126-148. - Standing water. 
Under this article, no soil, sand, clay, gravel or other similar material shall be removed in such a manner as to cause water to stand or accumulate or to result in a place of danger or a menace to the public health or safety. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.09.03)  
Sec. 126-149. - Slopes. 
The slopes of the banks of the excavation shall not exceed a minimum ratio of three feet horizontal to one foot vertical, and where ponded water results from the operation, the slope must be maintained and extended into the water to a depth of five feet. Suitable vegetation shall be planted on all finished slopes to deter erosion. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.09.04)  
Sec. 126-150. - Fence. 
Where there is an excavation in excess of five feet, the permit holder shall erect a fence of at least six feet in height, of wire mesh or such other suitable materials as shall be approved by the board of appeals to afford protection to persons and property. Any gates required shall be kept locked when operations are not carried on. 
(Code 1976, § 4-04.09.05)  
Sec. 126-151. - Signs.
